Weeping Cedar Woman homecoming is a
project endorsed by many groups from the Tofino community.  The District of Tofino is supporting
this project in important ways, but the money required to purchase the piece
from the artist will have to be raised independently.  Only with your help can we bring this conservation icon to
Tofino so she can continue to share her wisdom and story.  
The
Artist:
Godfrey Stephens is an original and
well respected artist from Vancouver Island.  His works are found in many countries, collections and
public places, including two monumental carved cedar pieces in the Victoria
Press Building.  Parks Canada
commissioned him to make a small sculpture, which he presented to Princess Anne
when she dedicated Pacific Rim National Park Reserve in May 1971.  He lived and worked in the Tofino /
Long Beach area for many years before moving to Victoria and Salt Spring.
What We Need & What You Get
The District of Tofino is looking to
provide a permanent home for Weeping Cedar Woman, but a lot still needs to be
done to bring Cedar Woman home. Other community groups including Tofino Arts Council and the
Pacific Rim Arts Society have agreed to help find funding for signage and dedication costs, but this leaves the acquisition cost to be
fundraised. Before launching this campaign roughly 4,000$ of the 20,000$ price tag has already been
donated by the community.  Funds raised above and beyond the acquisition costs will be donated to the artist to help with his current major piece called NevermoreWar, a sculpture integrating retired military
equipment into a plough share.
As thank you’s the community has come
together to offer some perks:
20$ - Signed cards featuring local art or photography50$ - A Sea Wench travel pack
75$ - A 30th anniversary of Meares Island t-shirt
from FOCS
125$ - A print photo of “Eagle” by Tofino Photography
250$ - A print of one of artist Godfrey Stephen's pieces400$ - A signed 10"-12" print of one of artist Godfrey Stephen's pieces
1000$ a 100$ Gift Certificate to dinner at Sobo’s; an authentic
Tofitian dinning experience
The importance of Weeping Cedar Woman
Here are a couple testemonials of the power of the Weeping Cedar Woman, take a look at facebook for more of her significance!

"Come on Canada….Get this
amazing piece of West Coast history back to the home where it belongs. Long
before Tofino was hip slick and cool..before there was a "Park" and
before the tourists took over Godfrey was on the beach at Wreck Bay
carving,drawing and painting and his art and history is an important part of
Tofinos story . Weeping Cedar Woman is a cornerstone for that history.Bring it
back along with the tribute to Godfrey's amazing life and connection to the
area."  
- 
Greg Warnick



"A monumental &
historic work by a monumental & historic artist! Lets bring her back to the
West Coast where she was created and can once again hear the roar of Mother
Pacific." – Rick Jasinski 
"I always have loved and respected
Weeping Cedar Woman as she truly reflects mother earth. This is a very powerful
piece. We truly need to pay more attention and gain more respect to our earth
we walk on. Thank you Godfrey." – Bonnie Fontaine
Other Ways You Can Help
Weeping Cedar Woman Home Coming will
take a huge community push! We need people to help us spread the word (you can
use the handy indiegogo share tools right now!).  We also need people to help us with the actual homecoming
event, and  in kind donations to
help bring Cedar Woman home are always appreciated.The District of Tofino also greatly appreciates letters supporting acquisition of this important piece of public art.  Write to the mayor at:Mayor Josie Osborne121 3rd Street
			PO Box 9
			Tofino BC V0R 2Z0

story:
Capture Magazine is born as a project of two graffiti writers
based in Madrid, with the objective of spreading varied quality
and graffiti around the world. The magazine has three different
versions, which triples the dissemination to different target
audiences.


The magazine is printed in full color on premium paper. The first number will be about 40 pages. The magazine made ​​up of several sections such as: walls, trains, bombing, reporting and hotshot. All texts are in english & spanish.


The process of creating Capture magazine has been long and laborious . The main reason to take this project forward has been the illusion of combining our two passions : Graffiti and graphic design . Our aim is to create a quality product that can reach around the world. 

The fact produce crowfunding generated by a direct relationship between us "creators" and you "buyer" avoiding intermediaries.


We have high hopes , high expectations and many hours of work put into this project, we intend to take this project forward so that we can continue to draw more numbers from our / your magazine and offer a product made and quality .


And we want to thank all the people who follow us by either Facebook , tumblr or our website . And also to all who have sent your material selflessly and you will see that you now rewarded to see your work published .


For real , THANK YOU.


Without you this would not be possible.

Asten, Astro, Axel, Beast, Bond, Brio, Burla, Chase, Cuelli Mangui, Dars, Dilm, Dizer, Dms, Does, Dorek, Emak, Eole, Fasim, Foham, Fork, Freg, Hint, Hiser, Jeas, Jimbo, Kani, Kano, Keko, Kemo, Lanz, Ler, Leran, Marte, Mendo, Meks, Mser, Nask, Nebur, Neiks, Ngha, Nul, Ogre, Orgh, Oveho, Paiko, Pak, Piros, Qeur, Quiero, Rage, Raws, Rekor, Rudi, Rusl, Sea162, Sen2, Serial, Sifo, Skey, Smol, Snaks, Sonrie, Soze, Sril, Sueño, Suepo, Taser, Tegos, Third, Tybet, Wany, Yone, Zeus, Zoeroner and many more!


///////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////


Capture Magazine nace como un proyecto de dos escritores de
graffiti afincados en Madrid, con el objetivo de difundir graffiti
variado y de calidad alrededor de todo el mundo. La revista
consta de tres versiones distintas, lo que triplica la difusión a
distintos tipos de público objetivo.


La revista está impresa a todo color y en papel de primera calidad. El primer número tendrá aproximadamente 40 páginas. El magazine lo componen varias secciones como: walls, trains, bombing, reportaje y hotshot. Todos los textos están en español e inglés.


El proceso de creación de Capture magazine ha sido largo y muy laborioso. El principal motivo de sacar este proyecto adelante ha sido la ilusión de combinar nuestras dos pasiones: El graffiti y el diseño gráfico. Con ello pretendemos crear un producto de calidad que pueda llegar a todo el mundo.
El hecho de producirlo mediante crowfunding genera una relación directa entre nosotros “creadores” y usted “comprador” evitando así intermediarios.


Tenemos mucha ilusión, muchas expectativas y muchas horas de trabajo puestas en este proyecto, nuestra intención es sacar este proyecto adelante para así poder continuar sacando más números de nuestra/vuestra revista y ofrecer un producto elaborado y de calidad.


Queremos y debemos dar las gracias a todas la personas que nos siguen ya sea por el Facebook, tumblr o nuestra web. Y también a todos aquellos que habéis enviado vuestro material desinteresadamente y que os veréis recompensados ahora al ver vuestro trabajo publicado.



De corazón, GRACIAS.

Sin vosotros esto no sería posible.

Asten, Astro, Axel, Beast, Bond, Brio, Burla, Chase, Cuelli Mangui, Dars, Dilm, Dizer, Dms, Does, Dorek, Emak, Eole, Fasim, Foham, Fork, Freg, Hint, Hiser, Jeas, Jimbo, Kani, Kano, Keko, Kemo, Lanz, Ler, Leran, Marte, Mendo, Meks, Mser, Nask, Nebur, Neiks, Ngha, Nul, Ogre, Orgh, Oveho, Paiko, Pak, Piros, Qeur, Quiero, Rage, Raws, Rekor, Rudi, Rusl, Sea162, Sen2, Serial, Sifo, Skey, Smol, Snaks, Sonrie, Soze, Sril, Sueño, Suepo, Taser, Tegos, Third, Tybet, Wany, Yone, Zeus, Zoeroner y muchos mas!



EXAMPLES / EJEMPLOS:


· PHYSICAL COPY


· DIGITAL COPY (IPAD AND TABLETS)

· DIGITAL COPY (PC)

· T-SHIRT

story:
Here's some background info for you:

  • My name is Nicole Louw and I am a junior in high school.
  • I am an artist hoping to pursue a career in animation.
  • CalArts has a summer program for young animators and going would help me greatly build a portfolio.
  • The top animators in the industry will be there and teach along with reviewing sketchbooks and portfolios
  • It is gonna cost a really scary $6500 for everything and I don't have that 
  • I need this course desperately  if I want to build a good enough portfolio, getting my name out there, and I would have big enough scholarship opportunities to make it into CalArts after high school.

(perks are cumulative so every tier includes all the items available through the lower tiers)

$5 Perks: Card!

At this level you will receive one of these lovely cards in the mail. You get to specify which one you want and these 5" x 7" cards are sure to show you just how grateful I am for the donation!

$10 Perks: Mini Prints!


$25 Perks: Button!


This level's rewards is one of these awesome buttons. Who doesn't love buttons? You get to specify which one you'd like and I will send it with lots of love.

$75 Perks: Temporary Tattoos and Stickers!

You can have any three of these as temporary tattoos and three as stickers!! You can pick the same designs or different ones it's totally up to you! 

$100 Perks: Sketch Book!

                         

Some Examples of Artwork That Will Appear:

This is a really cool perk! For a donation of $100, you will receive a copy of a compilation of my favorite sketches and drawings from my actual sketchbooks.

$150 Perks: DVD!

 

At this level I will send you a DVD filled with lessons, speedpaints, and tips and tricks that I like to use in my art!

$250 Perks: Large Print!

$350 Perks: Two Large Prints!

  

This tier gets you not one, but two large (16"x20") high-quality prints of my artwork. You will have a lot of choices to pick from, so don't worry!


What happens if this campaign raises more than the goal?

  • First and foremost, I will use the extra money to counterbalance the cost of all of the rewards I send out and the fees and taxes of everything.

story:
RVA NOISE FEST III is a DIY experimental music fest organized by the RVA NOISE collective in Richmond VA. The fest is currently in its 3rd incarnation since starting 2012. Originally intended to be a showcase of local artists RVA Noise Fest has expanded to include many engaging acts from across the country and we hope to grow even more in the coming years to include artists from all over the world.

Due to the expansions though, we are asking for your help (to be clear- we are asking for money to help pay the artists/venues that make this possible)! We are offering tons of merch from artists involved in the fest and the Richmond experimental scene, including a special promotion involving select choices from the RVA NOISE private collection, as well as some deep cuts from the ANTI-EVERYTHING NOISE vaults. Pre-sale tickets will also be available at STEADY SOUNDS located downtown at 322 W. Broad Street. 

RVA Noise Fest III will be held April 18-20 with performances happening through Richmond at Black Iris, Sound of Music, Strange Matter, and Steady Sounds. Keep updated with our Facebook page for details as we will be updating constantly, and as always even if you cannot donate we hope to still see you out in Richmond come April 18th!! 

But now without further delay, let's get to the important part...

RVA Noise Proudly Presents RVA NOISE FEST III

APRIL 18th - 19th - 20th 

At Black Iris, Sound Of Music, Steady Sounds and Strange Matter

Curated By Jonathan Lee, Matt Boettke and Gary Stevens

Featuring:

story:
What are we doing?

We are three midwestern photographers living and working in Kansas City. We are all seniors in photography at the Kansas City Art Institute. This exhibition is a culmination of our four years at this school. With this money, we hope to reestablish a former gallery space into what will be known as The Red Lady. Our thesis exhibition, which we are calling Continent, will be the first show in this new gallery. We thought we would help take initiative in actualizing this space because we feel there is little opportunity for students, as well as photographers, within the Kansas City area. Aside from preparing the gallery, the thesis exhibition itself will take a lot of funding. As graduating students, the pursuit of this exhibition is significant in our attempts to establish ourselves into the community as working artists.

Where is the money going?

We are asking for $4000. This money will go towards building supplies for new walls, repairing existing walls, patching and painting walls, lighting fixtures, lightbulbs, refreshments for the opening reception, promotional materials, hanging materials, framing, matting, and mounting. We would really love your help, and, because of this, we have set up a few donation gifts:

$5- Three Continent themed buttons

$15- A signed postcard from each artist

$25- All of the above + a mention at our exhibition

$50- The above + a signed, limited edition silk screen Continent poster

$100- The above + an 8x10 signed artist proof from each artist

$250- The above + an 11x17 signed artist proof from each artist

$500- The above + an original signed exhibition show book

$1000- The above + a 16x20 photograph mounted on Sintra from each artist + a HUGE hug

The littlest donation helps. If you can not donate, we would love if you passed this video on. Even if we do not reach our goal, any bit is still appreciated!

Who are we?

Briana Bosworth, born in Olathe, Kansas, works with concepts of temporal isolation. She examines the remnants of the futility of human actions. Her title is TBA.

Casey Holden is from Miami, Oklahoma. Her current work entitled Neither Here Nor There deals with anthropological ideas of the liminal period found within and between cultures.

Victoria Meyers, raised in St. Louis, Missouri, has been developing mal·le·a·ble for over two years. mal·le·a·ble is a comment on how we associate our identities with our environments by means of the domestic space. 



Exhibition Details:

Continent: three bodies of environment & experience

April 4th-6th

______________

Opening Reception

Friday, April 4th: 5PM-11PM

&

Saturday, April 5th: 10AM-5PM

Sunday, April 6th: 10AM-3PM

___________

The Red Lady

1229 1/2 Union Ave.

Kansas City, MO 64101 


Check us out at:

Brianabosworth.com

Caseyleeholden.com

Victoriaannmeyers.com

story:
Short Summary

In: being inclosed by something

Progress: act of moving forward

In-Progress: starting and carrying out a specific task until completion

in/progress- the slash defines a break between ‘in’ and ‘progress’ (the lack of capitalization = an artistic choice)

The breaking of the two words argues that being in-progress is not necessarily a linear, connected, or outcome-focused process. in/progress is the belief that growth and change can come from all facets of life. It is through creative narrative where connections are made.

in/progress is an arts and literary magazine founded by the 2019 Senior Seminar class of 10 Arts Management undergraduate students at the University of Toronto Scarborough. This magazine is a capstone project and a platform for revealing ongoing creative narratives. Through creative visual, literary, and digital story-making we wish to spotlight the unique memories, histories, rituals, and lived experiences that have brought us (together and apart) up to this present moment. in/progress captures identity in transition and asks the question, where do our stories belong, if not in a state of progress? 

What We Need & What You Get

We need $700 to be able to cover the printing costs for our magazine and to fund the performing artists at our end of year launch event .

  • $10 contribution = virtual acknowledgement and "thank you" shoutout (on our Instagram, Website and Facebook page)
  • $20 contribution = 2 free tickets to our launch event and "thank you" shoutout (on our Instagram, Website and Facebook page)
  • $40 contribution = A free copy of the magazine, 2 free tickets to our launch event and "thank you" shoutout (on our Instagram, Website and Facebook page)

The Impact

This magazine will be a platform for revealing the ongoing creative narratives within the surrounding UofT communities and beyond. Through this platform, we want to have the opportunity to give emerging artists the chance to explore their talents and have a published magazine at the end to show for it. We will be taking submissions through our online website, and not only would we (the class) be grateful, but all of the artists involved as well.

Our Values:

-Provide a platform for artistic creation

-Encourages explorative and interdisciplinary art-making

-Foster a sense of belonging through art and literature

Other Ways You Can Help

Please follow us and like us on Facebook and Instagram and tag us in any and all culture related creative works you might be involved with! We would love to hear from you

@inprogressmag

story:
Dear patrons, endless thanks for reading my campaign!


My name is Denise Kathleen Nicholls and I am an artist and designer living and working in the historic Chinatown district of Victoria, British Columbia, Canada.

My art – painting, printmaking, textile art, jewellery design – is greatly influenced by my surroundings, be it nature or urban: my current neighbourhood filled with amazing history, or the wild west coast places close by.

Another lifelong muse has been my inexplicable and intense draw to the UK which has inspired my imagination and art in equal measure.

As a small child, making art was (and is still) my greatest joy. Early drawings and paintings featured imaginary English landscapes filled with sheep, ponies, hedgerows and flowers. After so many years of longing, I am finally planning to be in England for the first time this autumn – fulfilling my dream, discovering my roots, and deciphering perhaps the reasons why I have always been drawn to Britain. This will be an arts-residency of sorts, that will undeniably inspire current and future work for many years to come.

I am most excited to expand on a new simple etching process I have been working with lately, which I have recently used to create mixed-media pieces of Victoria’s Chinatown district. I wish to create a series of new pieces based on the charming English villages I will be visiting in the Cotswolds, Somerset, and the New Forest region in Hampshire.

Funds raised will go towards the expenses of the trip – flights, accommodations, transportation – as well as art materials. Perks will all be original works of art or art experiences. Some will be mailed to patrons from the UK. The new series of etchings will be created upon return to my home studio from source material gathered on the trip. Expected delivery of that perk level will be prior to December 15, 2018. Experience perks will be booked from July 15 - September 15 or after November 15 2018 at a mutually agreeable time.

I will be blogging every day or two while I am on the trip. Anyone can follow and share my blog:
https://adventuresofdandgj.com/

Thank you so much for helping make my dream come true and supporting the next phase of my artistic development!

story:
What is Camp Kayak

Camp Kayak is a Creative Arts Program based on Carriacou, Grenada, WI – servicing local youths from primary school ages 8 - UP, marginalized by economic conditions of small rural West Indien Island community life. All Campers attend three weeks of a dynamic, creative and inspirational summer camp experience, otherwise NOT available to them locally.

Camp Kayak is intended to be a Carriacou resource–celebrating Carriacou people, their talents, their interests, and inviting West Indian and Caribbean artists and professionals to Carriacou to be inspired by all that this island has to offer.

It is also an opportunity to cultivate a vibrant artist community here on the tiny island of Carriacou, encouraging youth and community to focus on indigenous talent and local craft. Maybe one child has an artist within him or her that is just waiting to bloom right here on Carriacou!

Our mission is to enlighten, educate, and inspire through various forms of Creative Arts, Natural Sciences, Sports, Music and Drama.

Scholarships are available to all potential campers, funded by non-profit contribution, allowing Camp Kayak to be accessible to all children with an appetite to discover their own creative potential and take it further.

What do we need:

US$15,000 to run the camp this year.

We have already raised around US$4,000 though various on island fund raisers but we still need an additional US$15,000.

What this will enable us to do:

This will enable the Camp to run for 6 weeks over the summer of 2013.
The camp will run 2 sessions of 2 weeks per session.
Each session will have:
  • 25 students aged between 8 and 11.
  • 5 counsellors in training (ex-students over the age of 11).
  • 5 counsellors, mentors or teachers (both from local and overseas).
  • 1 chef and 1 cleaner.

Our track record:

Camp Kayak was founded in January 2010, initially from a very generous donation from Sandy Armentrout - read more about Sandy here

"Sandra “Sandy” Armentrout; my mother, my mentor, my sponsor & my reason for being. “Sandy” is why Camp Kayak is possible today– her support & underwriting made this project come alive. She funded the initial resource library materials & made many other generous gifts to the camp. We honor her in our inspiration everyday & hopefully we will do her proud!"

Victoria Armentrout - Camp Kayak Founder


Camp Kayak has run for 3 summers and had over 400 students attending so far. The students are ages 8-12 yrs and simply LOVE the camp. It gives them an opportunity to do something in their summer holiday that otherwise they would not get chance to do. Read their blog here

The scholarships given out in the local primary schools - by their principal and are available to all children. They do not have to have exemplary grades just a curiosity to explore. All students attend free. 

We put on a bus service to pick up and drop students home at the end of camp. We even put on a ferry service to include the students who come from our sister island, Petite Martinique. (10 minutes away from Carriacou by ferry).

We provide a hot lunch for all children and often breakfast for those who don't receive it at home before camp.


Here is a link to our website where you can read much much more about our work at Camp Kayak. There are videos made by the kids at Camp - some even went viral on YouTube, there is the camp song by one of our local soca artists and much more.

Camp Kayak

Other Ways You Can Help

We understand that not everyone is able to contribute (but please try however small, it makes such a difference and we are so grateful) but you can contribute in other ways.

  • Share this page on your Facebook profile so we get maximum exposure. Tweet about it if you have Twitter. Digg or Stumble upon and use whatever social media you like best to let everyone know about our great camp.
  • Indiegogo has share tools so please use them to spread the word.

We really want to run the camp this year for the children of Carriacou and are counting on your donations to make it happen.

As a final note here is just one of the many letters we received from one of the campers.


"Greetings to miss victoria armentrout and to all the other various teachers of camp kayak,
Im so glad to be writing you this message because i have not seen you guys in a long time.
I believe you know that i am dione leggard  a.k.a Dixie one of the former students last year.
I enjoyed my stay at camp kayak so very much that I didn't even want to go back to school...but going to camp was worth it!

i really wish i could donate something to help you guys out with the fundraiser.
As you said in your message, things are very hard so its kind of difficult to find money and stuff these days.
i really hope that when i get some money i would be able to help you guys out in the best way that i can.
Give my regards to all the teachers and tell them i said hello.

goodbye and god bless camp kayak,
Dixie"

story:
Atis Rezistans is a Haitian art movement that is transforming lives and creating hope for youth in the ghettos of Port-au-Prince. Project HOPE Art is sponsoring three members from the movement to visit North America and share their first-hand experience about reclamation, resiliency, and creativity.

The Artists

Racine Polycarpe, Claudel Casseus, and Romel Jean Pierre are artists, change makers, and youth leaders. Working with what they find in the street, these artists are reviving traditional Haitian voodoo art with the current conditions of a country struggling to recover from multiple disasters. Their work is profound, in its simultaneous rawness and spiritual refinement.      

Gang membership may often be the only available means of survival for many youth living in the endemic poverty of Port-au-Prince. Atis Rezistans is inspiring action and creating real options and opportunities for communities in Port-au-Prince.    

Project Summary

We need your help to multiply their work by developing the networks and skills of these three change makers as they face the very real challenges of climate change, structural economic inequality and rebuilding after natural disaster.

This is a three phase project, right now we need your help in making Phase 1 possible.

Phase 1:

Developing the leadership skills, networks and creative body of work of Racine, Claudel, and Romel. We will be documenting the process along the way.

Phase 2:

Creating more organizational support for Atis Rezistans, Project HOPE Art, and TeleGhetto and developing more grassroots support for the youth.    

Phase 3:

Scaling up organizations like Project HOPE Art and TeleGhetto for other global projects in zones most affected by climate change, structural inequality, and disaster

How the Project Will Succeed

Here's how we are going to complete the three phase project:

Artists Racine Polycarpe, Claudel Casseus, and Romel Jean Pierre will fly to San Francisco to complete sculptural works at the Artist in Residence Program at Recology, San Francisco's recycling and composting company. Recology has offered the Artists the opportunity to scavenge for materials in their Public Disposal and Recycling building along with use of the student studio space. Recology will host an exhibition of the Artists’ work on Sept. 20th and 21st at the same time as their current artists-in-residence, Kristin Cammermeyer and Chad Hasegawa. Pierre, Polycarpe, and Casseus will be giving artist talks open to the public and some of their work will remain in Recology’s permanent collection. The Artists will also visit Vancouver, BC where they will offer talks and workshops with partnering art collectives and organizations.

Zack Embree and Romel Jean Pierre will be creating a mini-documentary and sharing the story of their journey through social media.   

This project will have 4 major impacts:

1)   Develop confidence, facilitation and leadership skills in three Port-Au-Prince based artists, for their with youth groups in the ghetto.

2)   Demonstrate the power of positive, constructive and creative culture as a way of responding to tragedy and challenge.

3)   Engage social media networks with our story so that will multiply efforts to create hands-on educational programming and creative, sustainable options for youth in areas of the world most affected by climate change, natural disaster and structural inequality.  

4)  Actualize the dreams of 3 young artists and cultivate their skills so that their voice can be heard.


///////

Zack is a canadian documentary photographer, filmmaker and digital storytelling facilitator. His work is focused on supporting social change through compelling images and stories that highlight the strength and values of people who are creating a more just and sustainable world.

story:
I'm Cheryl of cheryl gautier ART-a budding new art business that I have created in my hometown of New Orleans.  I've  painted large ethereal landscapes on canvas, as well as eclectic designs on hundreds of tiny matchboxes for many many years and now as of recently I have a website, am making t-shirts, note cards, tote bags, and prints with my own designs!  My goal is for my art business to sustain itself and flourish!

I joined a co-op gallery in Mobile, Alabama called the Cathedral Square Gallery on 612 Dauphin St in the historic district of downtown Mobile. I love both the location and the artists with whom I share the gallery space!

In December I was notified that I have been accepted into my first juried Art Fair coming up on March 9 and 10 in Gulf Breeze, Florida!  This is very exciting and big news for me!  But will also be expensive....I will need to be purchasing display panels, and an Art Fair tent. These will be used for many years and many more art fairs to come. Up until now, for local shows, I displayed my work on an old room divider that I found in my Mom's shed.  It is held together with duct tape!  And I like it!  But it wouldn't be acceptable for this type of show.  I already ordered my banners and my prints, so all I really have to fund is the display materials!  I need help to do that!  But I have some eclectic and ethereal, wierd and whimsical perks for my funders!  I think you will love them!

story:
Klicke hier um zur deutschen Beschreibung zu springen

Who am I?
As you may know my name is Anja, I'm an artist & writer and of course, I love all kind of art. Please take a look at my work here: https://www.facebook.com/anja.millen.imagery
I'm living right now in Germany, in a city named Trier and it's loud, it's crowded and after all it's kinda uninspiring and nerve-wracking.



The reason:
I'm 47 and I had a very hard time the past years, so after a lot of thinking I decided to move to my "heartland" - to Ireland.
If not now, then when?

The 28th September 2013 is my "Goodbye Deutschland" day.
Arriving on the 29th in Kerry - living there, close to the sea, in a rural, peaceful setting, where I'm also able to go back to my traditional painting roots as well as doing photo shootings from Landscape to Fashion and yes, I will still work digitally and hopefully be able to further my skills.

Naturally this move is accompanied by a lot of expenses that have to be paid and new acquisitions have to be made as well. For example I need to buy a used car, because without one I would be kind of lost in the wilderness :)

And now, because Murphy's Law is my prime law all the time, my good old Canon Camera completely gave up. She had some trouble during the last months but now it's over. R.I.P.

So I shall move to Ireland, but not being able to shoot there?

That's where I'm hoping for your help and support.

"Kerry Me Home"


What am I going to do with the money?
With your backing you support my purchase of a new Camera with 2 lenses and therefore the opportunity to collaborate with some fantastic Designers and Models in unsual settings in the next years, as well as doing wonderful pictures of the Emerald Isle.
I'm planning some new artbooks, calendars and and and, but without a Camera it will be impossible to do so and until I can save enough money all by myself - there are probably years going by without one.



Why do I use flexible funding?
I decided to do a flexible funding because every $ counts for me, even if I cant hit my goal here.
Please be an active part of my Art ♥

 

Your rewards:
I added a list of perks to the right for you as a small thank you for your support, and perhaps you're able to spend a buck or two to help me to have a camera on my 'once in a life time trip'.

Example for Postcards
Limited Prints
The Visitors Sneak Peek
 
The Limited Squares Book

Take a closer look on YouTube



If you don't like any of those perks or don't want to be shown with your name, you may always choose to support as an anonymous backer too. I'm sure you will feel my gratitude without being publicly mentioned :)



Other ways you can help:
If you want to help and cannot afford to do so ... no worries!
I would be so thankful if you just simply spread the word!
Either by sharing it with those buttons, or with the url to this project:
http://igg.me/at/kerrymehome





Wer ich bin?
Wie du vielleicht schon weißt, ich heiße Anja.
Ich bin Künstlerin, Schreiberin und natürlich liebe ich jede Art von Kunst; traditioneller, musikalischer, schriftstellerischer und bildender Weise.
Ich lebe noch in Deutschland, im Herzen von Trier und es ist laut hier, überfüllt, und alles in allem tötet es jede Inspiration, Muse und vor allem Nerven ab.



Der Grund:
Ich bin nun bald 47 und ich hatte eine ziemlich harte Zeit in den letzten 2 Jahren.
Nach langem Grübeln und Überlegen kam ich zu dem Entschluß auszuwandern.
Auszuwandern in meines Herzens Land: Irland.

Wenn nicht jetzt, wann dann?

Der 28. September 2013 ist mein "Auf Wiedersehen Deutschland" Tag.
Dann, ankommen, am 29igsten in Kerry.
Dort Leben, nahe am Meer sein, in einer ländlichen, friedlichen Gegend, wo ich endlich zu meinen Wurzeln der traditionellen Malerei zurückkehren möchte, ebenso wie Photoshootings von Landschaftsbildern bis hin zu Fashionshoots und ja, natürlich werde ich auch weiterhin digital arbeiten und hoffentlich meine Fähigkeiten darin weiter entwickeln.

Natürlich ist dieser Umzug begleitet von vielen Ausgaben und neuen Anschaffungen die gemacht werden müssen. Zum Beispiel muss ich mir ein gebrauchtes Auto kaufen, denn ohne wäre ich wohl etwas verloren in der "irischen Wildnis". ;)

Und nun, weil Murphys Gesetz auch mein oberstes Gesetz ist, hat meine gute, alte Canon Kamera komplett aufgegeben. Sie hatte schon länger einige Macken aber nun ist  sie endgültig verschieden. R.I.P.

Also soll es nun so sein, dass ich nach Irland auswandere, in das Land meiner Inspiration und nicht mehr in der Lage sein dort Bilder zu machen?

An diesem Punkt angekommen hoffe ich auf eure Unterstützung und Hilfe.

"Kerry Me Home"


Was ich mit dem Geld machen werde?
Mit und von eurem Support werde ich mir eine neue Kamera mit zwei Objektiven kaufen und mir damit die Möglichkeit öffnen mit einigen fantastischen Designern 2014 in ungewöhnlichen Settings zusammenzuarbeiten.
Ich plane neue Artbooks, Kalender und und und, jedoch ohne Kamera wird das ein Ding der Unmöglichkeit bleiben und bis ich all das Geld selbst zusammengespart habe - nun ja, würden Jahre vergehen.




Wieso ich flexible Finanzierung ausgewählt habe?
Ich habe mich für flexible Finanzierung entschieden, weil jeder $ zählt, auch wenn ich mein großes Ziel nicht erreiche.
Bitte sei ein aktiver Part meiner Kunst und derer Entstehung!

 

Deine Belohnungen / Perks:
Ich habe eine Liste von Perks auf der rechten Seite hinzugefügt, als Dankeschön für eure Unterstützung, und vielleicht bist du imstande den einen oder anderen Dollar zu spenden um mir zu helfen eine Kamera auf der "Reise meines Lebens" dabei zu haben.
(Die Beschreibung der Perks ist nur in englisch möglich, falls du eine Übersetzung benötigst scheue nicht mich anzusprechen)

Beispiel für Postkarten
Limitierte Drucke
Vorschau für Besucher-Perks
 
Das Limited Squares Buch

Kurzes YouTube-Video zum Buch



Wenn du keine dieser Belohnungen magst oder gar nicht namentlich erwähnt werden möchtest, kannst du auch immer auswählen mich als anonymer Helfer zu unterstützen.
Ich bin sicher du wirst meine Dankbarkeit und Freude auch ohne öffentliche Erwähnung spüren.




Andere Wege wie du helfen kannst:
Wenn du gerne helfen möchtest, aber es dir nicht leisten kannst ... keine Sorge!
Ich wäre dir sehr dankbar wenn du vielleicht einfach diese Seite teilst und etwas publik machst.
Entweder durch teilen mit einer der Buttons hier, oder durch Kopieren des direkten Linkes zu diesem Projekt.
http://igg.me/at/kerrymehome


Back to the top
story_txt:
Klicke hier um zur deutschen Beschreibung zu springen
Who am I?As you may know my name is Anja, I'm an artist & writer and of course, I love all kind of art. Please take a look at my work here: https://www.facebook.com/anja.millen.imageryI'm living right now in Germany, in a city named Trier and it's loud, it's crowded and after all it's kinda uninspiring and nerve-wracking.The reason:I'm 47 and I had a very hard time the past years, so after a lot of thinking I decided to move to my "heartland" - to Ireland.If not now, then when?The 28th September 2013 is my "Goodbye Deutschland" day.Arriving on the 29th in Kerry - living there, close to the sea, in a rural, peaceful setting, where I'm also able to go back to my traditional painting roots as well as doing photo shootings from Landscape to Fashion and yes, I will still work digitally and hopefully be able to further my skills.Naturally this move is accompanied by a lot of expenses that have to be paid and new acquisitions have to be made as well. For example I need to buy a used car, because without one I would be kind of lost in the wilderness :)And now, because Murphy's Law is my prime law all the time, my good old Canon Camera completely gave up. She had some trouble during the last months but now it's over. R.I.P.So I shall move to Ireland, but not being able to shoot there?That's where I'm hoping for your help and support."Kerry Me Home"What am I going to do with the money?With your backing you support my purchase of a new Camera with 2 lenses and therefore the opportunity to collaborate with some fantastic Designers and Models in unsual settings in the next years, as well as doing wonderful pictures of the Emerald Isle.I'm planning some new artbooks, calendars and and and, but without a Camera it will be impossible to do so and until I can save enough money all by myself - there are probably years going by without one.
Why do I use flexible funding?I decided to do a flexible funding because every $ counts for me, even if I cant hit my goal here.Please be an active part of my Art ♥
 
Your rewards:I added a list of perks to the right for you as a small thank you for your support, and perhaps you're able to spend a buck or two to help me to have a camera on my 'once in a life time trip'.
Example for Postcards

Limited Prints

The Visitors Sneak Peek

 
The Limited Squares BookTake a closer look on YouTube

If you don't like any of those perks or don't want to be shown with your name, you may always choose to support as an anonymous backer too. I'm sure you will feel my gratitude without being publicly mentioned :)
Other ways you can help:If you want to help and cannot afford to do so ... no worries! I would be so thankful if you just simply spread the word!Either by sharing it with those buttons, or with the url to this project:http://igg.me/at/kerrymehome

story:
Akrai is an artists-run organization with the smallest budget you can imagine!

Nonetheless, Akrai is strong and solid, as it has dozens of professionals committed to its mission. These professionals are the pillars of our program and all volunteer their time and expertise to deliver a high level program to exceptional international artists. Akrai's innovative program of cultural events will benefit the local community and regional area.

We need your contribution to make it all happen! Help us build a strong community for the arts.

Claudia Cannizzaro & Salvatore Scalora, Akrai's Founders and Directors.

(see who we are here: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=V1i62cAh0wY)

Akrai is an international multidisciplinary arts residency program on the island of Sicily, with a strong emphasis on interaction with the local community and collaboration among peers.

Akrai's mission is to nurture the arts by offering creative individuals an opportunity to develop new work in a stimulating environment. Akrai also offer to its Fellows a platform for a better understanding of the rich and complex heritage of Sicily, with its layers of history and tradition and multifaceted contemporary issues by facilitating a cultural exchange between the local community and artists from across the world.

At the local level, Akrai forges new connections between the surrounding community and the contemporary arts, encouraging community participation in the cultural dialogue.

For a month each year, nine professionals in the fields of visual arts, music, dance, theater, creative writing, and culinary arts, convene in Palazzolo Acreide, Siracusa, to work on individual projects and interact with local students and other community residents. Work done at the residency will culminate in site-specific events and exhibitions throughout this beautiful town, its stunning surrounding hills, and superb archeological sites.

Creative professionals do not pay to participate in the program and are hosted in renovated private apartments throughout the historical center of the town, all within walking distance of a shared studio space.

Residents share a large communal studio with courtyard access, located inside the historical city hall on the main piazza—the meeting point of the town. Here participants can work on individual projects and also collaborate and organize public events such as readings, performances, exhibitions, plays, concerts, and discussions.

The communal studio is conceived as an incubator, laboratory, and meeting place of creative minds.

story:
Hi,

My name is Cristian Mihai. I'm a Romanian self-publisher, blogger, and founder of irevuo, an online magazine whose "mission" is to promote indie artists of all kinds and backgrounds.

This summer we plan to release a showcase of some of the best indie visual artists out there.

It's going to be a great way for those artists to gain exposure, especially because the electronic version of the showcase will be available for free.

What's this showcase exactly?

  

 The first and only issue of our magazine (released in January 2013) had a section called "Showcase," in which two different visual artists presented some of their best works.

We plan to expand this idea into a full length book of sorts. It's going to contain pictures of works of art, bios, artists' statements, and social media links.

Inclusion in this showcase will be free.

What we need

Contrary to popular belief offering something for free does not mean millions of people will download it. We've learned this the hard way with the magazine.

And we want this showcase to reach as many people as possible, so we need to advertise it. Thare are also editing and publishing related costs.

We try to keep everything as low budget as possible, while not making any compromises when it comes to the overall quality of the product.

story:
Follow the Official Facebook Page for the most up-to-date information on the show!

About Us:
We are a group of 3 creative ladies who grew up with a great love and affinity for Sailor Moon.  When we heard about Sailor Moon's 20th anniversary and release of the new anime, we knew we had to find a way to celebrate!  Together, we came up with the idea of curating and exhibiting a tribute show of one of the most popular and beloved anime of all time.

About The Show:
The show will be taking place in Anaheim, CA in the famed Rothick Art Haus.  The show features artwork from artists all around the world.  The show will run for 2 months, starting July and ending in August.  We will also be apart of the Anaheim Art Crawl Experience, which takes place August 9, 2014; giving more exposure about Sailor Moon to the general public and art lovers alike.

How The Funds Will Be Used:
The funds will allow us to prepare events for the opening night (July 5, 2014) and for the Anaheim Art Crawl Experience (August 9, 2014/This date is an approximate date only!)

It will help us with shipping costs, flyer prints, promoting the show and having a great show overall!

Featured Artists:
We were lucky enough to get some famed artists to participate in this awesome show.  We will add more to this list as we get final confirmations!
- Babs Tarr
- Glenn Arthur
- Ann Marcellino
- Kelly Eden
- Bara-chan

Location:
Rothick Art Haus
170 S Harbor Blvd
Anaheim, CA 92805

Dates:
July 5, 2014 (Opening Night)
August 9, 2014 (Anaheim Art Crawl Experience/This date is an approximate date only!)
August 30, 2014 (Tribute Show Ends)

story:
My Dream


I have worked as a professional Makeup Artist in the fashion and beauty industry for over 10 years. I'm completely self-taught, and I work really hard at my craft. I'm constantly teaching myself whatever I can and practicing to perfect my skill set, learn new techniques, or create my own. I have worked so hard to be able to make my living doing makeup quite simply because it's my passion. I can't imagine not doing it for the rest of my life. I've also recently been focusing on my YouTube channel, making tutorials and makeup videos, which is something I truly enjoy doing. I would love to be able to get a new camera. But that's not my main goal for this campaign.

I have always believed that we should never remain stagnant. I want to continue to learn and expand my talents and my expertise and for that I need to go to school and study something new.



When I was around 12 or 13 I watched the films Braveheart and Mrs. Doubtfire, and realized that makeup wasn't just about lipstick and mascara. I wanted to know how that magic was made. I knew, even then, that this was something I wanted to do.



My dream is to do makeup for Film & TV. I want to learn how to create incredible special effects, characters, and creatures with makeup. I want to be able to use my talents to bring any era or landscape to life on screen. Makeup Artistry is my living, and it's my passion.



What I Need

I really need to start experimenting more with special effects makeup, and if (when) I do get accepted into makeup school, I will need to have a comprehensive kit and amateur SFX portfolio.



  • I've set this campaign at $1500 US so that if I fall short of the goal I can still afford to put together a really good kit. I've included in my goal amount the estimated shipping costs and duties to bring the products here to Barbados. If I reach my goal amount I'll be able to get a new camera for my portfolio shots and YouTube videos (currently I do it all with my iphone, which works well, but it's tedious).
  • When you contribute, you'll have access to perks like makeovers, one-on-one makeup lessons, and the chance to have your Halloween or AnimeKon makeup done by me!
  • When you contribute you'll be added to a mailing list, and you'll get regular updates from me about how things are going, both with the campaign and with my practice. You'll be the first to know about any workshops or seminars I'm holding, and you'll also get fun sneak peeks of what I'm working on, as well as the opportunity to weight in, ask me questions or request videos and looks. 
  • If you are not in Barbados I realize I cannot offer you any perks at this time. I can only offer you my undying gratitude. So if you are from another country and you donate anyway, I thank you, truly, from the bottom of my heart.


Why

The International Film Industry is a billion-dollar one, with countless people being employed making countless films every year, and every single one needs a hair and makeup team.



We all know the brilliance in makeup that is the otherwordly spirit, or the zombie, or the monster, or the alien. The Joker, Mystique, the Klingons, Hellboy, The Grinch, Pennywise, Freddie. Did you see the incredible, realistic old-age makeup on Brad Pitt in "The Curious Case of Benjamin Button" or the old wicked witch makeup on Michelle Pfeiffer as Lamia in "Stardust"? What about the evil-looking tribal designs applied on Ray Park as Darth Maul in "Star Wars: The Phantom Menace"? 



But movie makeup isn't just about prosthetics or creating witches or monsters or zombies. It's also not only about age makeup either. Movie makeup ranges from extremely subtle to outrageously involved and creative. It's not only about applying the makeup, it's about designing and creating the look/effect/creature itself! Of course all wigs, bruises, cuts, wounds, dirt and so on are also the purview of the hair & makeup team on any film or TV set, as are body special effects like dismembered limbs and live-action injuries. But there is also a subtlety to makeup artistry.





Have you watched "Star Trek: Into Darkness"? Did you notice the blue and purple shadows around actor Benedict Cumberbatch's eyes and the hollows of his face? You may not have, because you weren't supposed to. That was very subtle and incredibly effective makeup. In addition to his unparalleled acting, those simple shadows made Khan look incredibly menacing, making the viewer very uneasy to look at him. How about Angeline Jolie's sharp prosthetic cheekbones as "Maleficent"? Such a simple detail that instantly changed her appearance. This subtlety is in stark contrast to the brilliant makeup on Linda Blair in "The Exorcist", who was made to look progessively more and more possessed with lots of clever makeup and prosthetics. Did you know that the infamous "pea soup vomit" scene was a creation of the talented lead Makeup Artist Dick Smith (RIP) and assistant Rick Baker (both oscar award-winning makeup artists)? Among all the other effects, they created prosthetics that hid a special tube and mouthpiece that could spew out pea soup at the flick of a switch!




Have you seen "The Hunger Games"? The crazy, futuristic makeup in that movie was artistic and beautiful and the work of an exceptional makeup team (headed by the oscar-winning Ve Neill, who happens to be affiliated with the Cinema Makeup School, which is my dream school). That makeup helped separate the residents of the Capital from the Districts: they were weird and stylish to the point of insanity, and helped you feel how far removed they were from the reality of life in the Panem Districts. Ve Neill is also the creator of the makeup effects on the film Beetlejuice and Mrs Doubtfire, among others. That goes to show the range that these talented people have.



How about Kristen Stewart as a pregnant and deathly ill-looking Bella Swan in "Twilight: Breaking Dawn Part 1"? That makeup utterly captivates and fascinates me. They gave her amazing 'natural' prosthetic cheekbones, jawline, chin, collarbones and forehead, paired with incredible painting and shadows to make her look emaciated and sunken, as though her flesh had shrunk onto her bones, and like she was at death's door. Same goes for the makeup on Jared Leto as Rayon in "Dallas Buyers Club". It absolutely breaks your heart to see him in that film. A similar effect was achieved decades ago in "Stephen King's: Thinner" on actor Robert John Burke, whose body, with the help of progressive prosthetics and makeup, went from being very fat to wasting away throughout the movie as a result of a curse.




Pick any period piece and you delve even deeper into the world of makeup: Look at "Pride and Prejudice" starring Keira Knightly. You need makeup under the unforgiving lights and HD cameras, but how do you make it so that characters that could not afford makeup or that were living in a time before most modern makeup was invented look like they're not wearing any? What about their hair, eyebrows? You may think it's insignificant, but the way the characters look in a film set you up, on an intellectual and emotional level, to receive the movie, to believe the characters and the setting. Look at the ethereal yet fierce and mesmerizing Elves in "The Lord of The Rings" and "The Hobbit" films. Their pale, porcelain smooth skin isn't just CGI, it's 85% makeup.




This whole world just calls to me. I know I'm creative enough and passionate enough to do well as a Film & TV Makeup artist. 

I don't just want to work on blockbuster films, though I definitely am aiming for that too! Barbados has a blossoming film and cosplay industry and I want to be able to give my talents to that community as well. We have a lot of talent here, and if I have the training and the kit, I can be a part of that. And believe me, I will wave the Bajan flag no matter where in the world I end up! This is where I started and learned and made invaluable friends and gained mentors and supporters along the way.




I've played around with what materials I can get, like latex and Nose & Scar Wax (see the photo of Ben as Walter White) and face and body paint (See Dexter as Electro or my skull makeup). But there are many other materials and techniques that I need to know but cannot teach myself. The film & tv makeup artist is not just scultping from clay or silicone or latex or learning how to make mechanical special effect parts that blend seamlessly into the makeup, (s)he's also working on a living, breathing human body 90% of the time. I have taught myself a lot but there are many more things I need to learn in the control and safety of a classroom. 



I need to assemble a kit with the kinds of materials I can safely experiment with so that I can build a comprehensive amateur portfolio for when I apply for scholarships, grants and finally acceptance to the schools.

I appreciate each and every contribution with my whole heart. If you can't contribute, please spread the word. I will be equally grateful because the more people know about this, the more likely it is that I'll reach my goal. 



(Many thanks to photographers Alyson Holder, Risée Chaderton, Andre Williams and Louise DeCourcey-Dawe for the use of some of their images. Thanks to the models and clients you see in the photos: Shannon Harris; Anke Griffith; Natasha Smith on her wedding day; Cathy Brown; Dexter for the AnimeKon Charicature Files; Leslie Humphrey; Gigi Ma'at; Ben Norris; and Malissa Alanna. Thank you to all my friends that previewed this and gave me invaluable feedback, especially Knicky, whose fine-toothed-comb skills are unmatched, and who gave me honest, critical feedback and suggestions. Special thanks also to AnimeKon. All makeup in the photos is by me.)

I've set this campaign at $1500 US so that if I fall short of the goal I can still afford to put together a really good kit. I've included in my goal amount the estimated shipping costs and duties to bring the products here to Barbados. If I reach my goal amount I'll be able to get a new camera for my portfolio shots and YouTube videos (currently I do it all with my iphone, which works well, but it's tedious). When you contribute, you'll have access to perks like makeovers, one-on-one makeup lessons, and the chance to have your Halloween or AnimeKon makeup done by me!
When you contribute you'll be added to a mailing list, and you'll get regular updates from me about how things are going, both with the campaign and with my practice. You'll be the first to know about any workshops or seminars I'm holding, and you'll also get fun sneak peeks of what I'm working on, as well as the opportunity to weight in, ask me questions or request videos and looks. 
If you are not in Barbados I realize I cannot offer you any perks at this time. I can only offer you my undying gratitude. So if you are from another country and you donate anyway, I thank you, truly, from the bottom of my heart. 





  Why The International Film Industry is a billion-dollar one, with countless people being employed making countless films every year, and every single one needs a hair and makeup team.




We all know the brilliance in makeup that is the otherwordly spirit, or the zombie, or the monster, or the alien. The Joker, Mystique, the Klingons, Hellboy, The Grinch, Pennywise, Freddie. Did you see the incredible, realistic old-age makeup on Brad Pitt in "The Curious Case of Benjamin Button" or the old wicked witch makeup on Michelle Pfeiffer as Lamia in "Stardust"? What about the evil-looking tribal designs applied on Ray Park as Darth Maul in "Star Wars: The Phantom Menace"? 





But movie makeup isn't just about prosthetics or creating witches or monsters or zombies. It's also not only about age makeup either. Movie makeup ranges from extremely subtle to outrageously involved and creative. It's not only about applying the makeup, it's about designing and creating the look/effect/creature itself! Of course all wigs, bruises, cuts, wounds, dirt and so on are also the purview of the hair & makeup team on any film or TV set, as are body special effects like dismembered limbs and live-action injuries. But there is also a subtlety to makeup artistry.



Have you watched "Star Trek: Into Darkness"? Did you notice the blue and purple shadows around actor Benedict Cumberbatch's eyes and the hollows of his face? You may not have, because you weren't supposed to. That was very subtle and incredibly effective makeup. In addition to his unparalleled acting, those simple shadows made Khan look incredibly menacing, making the viewer very uneasy to look at him. How about Angeline Jolie's sharp prosthetic cheekbones as "Maleficent"? Such a simple detail that instantly changed her appearance. This subtlety is in stark contrast to the brilliant makeup on Linda Blair in "The Exorcist", who was made to look progessively more and more possessed with lots of clever makeup and prosthetics. Did you know that the infamous "pea soup vomit" scene was a creation of the talented lead Makeup Artist Dick Smith (RIP) and assistant Rick Baker (both oscar award-winning makeup artists)? Among all the other effects, they created prosthetics that hid a special tube and mouthpiece that could spew out pea soup at the flick of a switch!




Have you seen "The Hunger Games"? The crazy, futuristic makeup in that movie was artistic and beautiful and the work of an exceptional makeup team (headed by the oscar-winning Ve Neill, who happens to be affiliated with the Cinema Makeup School, which is my dream school). That makeup helped separate the residents of the Capital from the Districts: they were weird and stylish to the point of insanity, and helped you feel how far removed they were from the reality of life in the Panem Districts. Ve Neill is also the creator of the makeup effects on the film Beetlejuice and Mrs Doubtfire, among others. That goes to show the range that these talented people have.




How about Kristen Stewart as a pregnant and deathly ill-looking Bella Swan in "Twilight: Breaking Dawn Part 1"? That makeup utterly captivates and fascinates me. They gave her amazing 'natural' prosthetic cheekbones, jawline, chin, collarbones and forehead, paired with incredible painting and shadows to make her look emaciated and sunken, as though her flesh had shrunk onto her bones, and like she was at death's door. Same goes for the makeup on Jared Leto as Rayon in "Dallas Buyers Club". It absolutely breaks your heart to see him in that film. A similar effect was achieved decades ago in "Stephen King's: Thinner" on actor Robert John Burke, whose body, with the help of progressive prosthetics and makeup, went from being very fat to wasting away throughout the movie as a result of a curse.






Pick any period piece and you delve even deeper into the world of makeup: Look at "Pride and Prejudice" starring Keira Knightly. You need makeup under the unforgiving lights and HD cameras, but how do you make it so that characters that could not afford makeup or that were living in a time before most modern makeup was invented look like they're not wearing any? What about their hair, eyebrows? You may think it's insignificant, but the way the characters look in a film set you up, on an intellectual and emotional level, to receive the movie, to believe the characters and the setting. Look at the ethereal yet fierce and mesmerizing Elves in "The Lord of The Rings" and "The Hobbit" films. Their pale, porcelain smooth skin isn't just CGI, it's 85% makeup.



This whole world just calls to me. I know I'm creative enough and passionate enough to do well as a Film & TV Makeup artist. 
I don't just want to work on blockbuster films, though I definitely am aiming for that too! Barbados has a blossoming film and cosplay industry and I want to be able to give my talents to that community as well. We have a lot of talent here, and if I have the training and the kit, I can be a part of that. And believe me, I will wave the Bajan flag no matter where in the world I end up! This is where I started and learned and made invaluable friends and gained mentors and supporters along the way.





I've played around with what materials I can get, like latex and Nose & Scar Wax (see the photo of Ben as Walter White) and face and body paint (See Dexter as Electro or my skull makeup). But there are many other materials and techniques that I need to know but cannot teach myself. The film & tv makeup artist is not just scultping from clay or silicone or latex or learning how to make mechanical special effect parts that blend seamlessly into the makeup, (s)he's also working on a living, breathing human body 90% of the time. I have taught myself a lot but there are many more things I need to learn in the control and safety of a classroom. 





I need to assemble a kit with the kinds of materials I can safely experiment with so that I can build a comprehensive amateur portfolio for when I apply for scholarships, grants and finally acceptance to the schools.
I appreciate each and every contribution with my whole heart. If you can't contribute, please spread the word. I will be equally grateful because the more people know about this, the more likely it is that I'll reach my goal. 




(Many thanks to photographers Alyson Holder, Risée Chaderton, Andre Williams and Louise DeCourcey-Dawe for the use of some of their images. Thanks to the models and clients you see in the photos: Shannon Harris; Anke Griffith; Natasha Smith on her wedding day; Cathy Brown; Dexter for the AnimeKon Charicature Files; Leslie Humphrey; Gigi Ma'at; Ben Norris; and Malissa Alanna. Thank you to all my friends that previewed this and gave me invaluable feedback, especially Knicky, whose fine-toothed-comb skills are unmatched, and who gave me honest, critical feedback and suggestions. Special thanks also to AnimeKon. All makeup in the photos is by me.)

story:
Quilomboarte

Peripheral Cultural Production Conglomerate / Conglomerado de Producción Cultural Periférica

Quilomboarte is a platform that has as its objective the creation of alternative networks of solidarity between counter-hegemonic artists and the systemically invisibilized around the world. We defend a decolonial agenda that arises from the historical margins of our own bodies. We are an extended family of creators. We are a cooperative entity that established itself as a proactive resistance front toward the mercenary and colonial cultural industries.

Quilomboarte es un conglomerado de producción cultural periférica; una plataforma que tiene como objetivo tejer redes de solidaridad alternativas entre el trabajo artístico contra-hegemónico y diversas comunidades invisibilizadas sistémicamente  alrededor del mundo. Defendemos una agenda decolonial desde los márgenes históricos de nuestro propio cuerpo. Somos una entidad cooperativa que forma un frente de resistencia proactiva con respecto a las industrias culturales mercenarias y de perfil colonial.

Photo: Quilomboarte in Havana, Cuba, August 2013.

Multi-disciplinary art assumes its social responsibility based on the context that defines it without diminishing the aesthetic language and forms of execution, which is coherent and affirmative with our historic conditions of existence, solidifying the reproductions of relevant narratives and knowledge which constitute themselves as models and vehicles such as rap or spoken word translated into critical pedagogy exercises born out of the sweat of melanin. Concerts, workshops, lectures, film screenings, theater, cultural exchanges, artistic residencies, are just some of the production formats that we have been developing since 2005.

Arte multidisciplinario que asume la responsabilidad social del contexto que lo determina , sin demeritar en las formas de ejecución y lenguaje estético, el cual es coherente y afirmativo con nuestras condiciones históricas de existencia, solidificando la reproducción de narrativas y conocimiento relevantes las cuales se constituyen como modelos  en la utilización de vehículos como el Rap o el Spoken Word  traducidos a ejercicios de pedagogía critica crecida al calor de la melanina. Conciertos, talleres, lecturas, muestras de cine, presentaciones teatrales, residencias artísticas, intercambios culturales, son algunos de los formatos de producción bajo los cuales hemos trabajado desde el 2005.

Photo: Quilomboarte Decolonial Studies Project, Mexico City, Mexico, March 2014,  

2014 brings the development of two transgressive projects: a documentary film and a project of intervention in public spaces.

Quilomboarte is in the research and development phase of production of a documentary film, in which we will visually expose an analogy between processes of current counter-hegemonic cultural production and colonial era maroon societies in Mexico, the United States, Colombia and Brazil. The historic yuxtaposition fulfill the urgent need of establishing decolonial work, critical pedagogies, and vehicles of expression, such as rap or Spoken Word, as relevant platforms and systems of information for emancipatory movements and agendas. Recognizing the high impact of visual language, we choose the format of film—in order to share this invisibilized chapter of our history with the widest of audiences. Quilomboarte, through self-generated funds has already secured camera equipment and lenses, and highly talented human capital. Money raised will be designated for the following: air fare and travel expenses for film crew to/from site locations.

Photo: Quilomboarte 7th anniversary show, Mexico City, Mexico, May 2012.

El 2014 representa el lanzamiento de dos proyectos fundamentales y transgresores: un documental y un proyecto de intervención en el espacio público.

El primer proyecto consiste en la elaboración de un documental a través del cual expondremos visualmente una analogía entre el proceso de creación de cultura contra-hegemonica actual por parte de diversos creadores en diferentes  formatos de producción y las sociedades cimarronas existentes en la época colonial, enfocados en 4 comunidades especificas ubicadas en México, Georgia/E.U, Colombia y Brasil. Una yuxtaposición histórica que cumple con la necesidad urgente de establecer al trabajo decolonial, a la pedagogía critica y a vehículos como el Rap o el Spoken Word como  sistemas de conocimiento y plataformas relevantes en diversas agendas emancipatorias. Es asi que a través del lenguaje visual, el cual reconocemos como de alto impacto, intentaremos compartir con el numero mas grande de audiencia posible este gran segmento invisibilizado de nuestra historia. Los fondos generados seran utilizados para los siguientes propósitos: pasajes aeréos y gastos generados por el viaje. 

Photo: Fuerzas Basicas!. (B.I.M.), Quilomboarte building with the youth, California, 2013.

Itinerant Quilombo is a project of intervention in public spaces. When we speak of physical spaces in the context of the dominant hegemonies,  we must necessarily look at the diameters that state and corporativist entities have established as norms to commodify time and its relation to the civic body as merchandise. Public space, in which marginalized peoples can co-exist, interact, or enjoy free or affodable cultural offerings are increasingly more difficult to encounter in major metropolis of the globe. Aware of this complex process we have created the project Itinerant Quilombo in which we revert the centralization of culture by mobilizing our project directly to the heart of communities. Itinerant Quilombo will bring multi-disciplinary production, music showcases, spoken word, film screenings, theater, workshops and lectures to strategic neighborhood enclaves in Mexico and then replicated internationally. Money raised will secure the purchase of needed elements for program implementation, including an HD projector and a mobile sound system.

El segundo lleva por nombre “Quilombo Itinerante”; el cual es un proyecto de intervencion del espacio publico. Cuando hablamos de espacio en el marco dominante de las hegemonías nos remontamos indistintamente hacia los diámetros  que el corporativismo o el estado han normativizado y diseñado para mercantilizar el tiempo en relación con la existencia del ser cívico. Pensar en espacios públicos en los cuales los sectores menos favorecidos de la población puedan coexistir , interactuar o disfrutar de una oferta cultural gratuita son cada vez mas difíciles  de encontrar en las grandes ciudades del mundo. Conscientes de este proceso avasallador hemos creado la iniciativa de un Quilombo Itinerante, bajo la cual revertimos el efecto centralizador mediante la movilización de nuestro proyecto directamente al corazón de las comunidades a través del montaje completo de una actividad multidisciplinaria (presentación musical, poética,  muestra documental, fragmentos de obras de teatro, lecturas y talleres) en alguno de los enclaves  estratégicos del barrio en especifico, contando siempre con la participación directa de agentes locales propios de la comunidad los cuales idealmente lograran replicar estos programas. Las dos primeros ejercicios se realizaran en el mes de Mayo en la ciudad de Oaxaca y Puebla, con la intención de ser ejecutadas periódicamente en diferentes ciudades. El dinero recaudado asegurará la compra y financiamiento de todos los elementos necesarios para la implementación de los programas, así como del proyector y sistema de sonido mobil. 

Photo: Quilomboarte Youth event, Watsonville, California, 2014

Your support is essential! With your help and solidarity we will be able to solidify two of our most transgressive projects to date. Not only do you have the ability to support Quilomboarte's upcoming projects but we are also offering a variety of unique indiegogo perks! Perks range from unreleased music, original canvas totes designed by Dr. Befa, American Apparel tees and hoodies, to unique experiences and exclusive artistic collaboration. 

Tu apoyo es fundamental! Con tu ayuda y solidaridad seremos capaces de concretar dos de los proyectos más relevantes dentro de nuestra agenda. Además de apoyar nuestros proyectos recibirás a cambio una serie de productos y/o gratificaciones que van desde música inédita, prendas exclusivas y de edición limitada, hasta colaboraciones artísticas. 

Exclusive indiegogo perk: wearable art! Get a canvas tote with original art by Dr. Befa

Exclusive collaboration: Cambio will direct you next music video!

Thank you for your support. Spread the word! Gracias por tu apoyo. Corre la voz!        Fuerza!

Quilomboarte: Peripheral Cultural Production Conglomerate.

Photo: HacheST, Cambio, Bocafloja.
