story:
Concept

  Where the elements of circus, acrobatic, contemporary dance, theatre, body percussion, song and instrumental music meet and intertwine, there begins the real challenge for the contemporary art initiative „tanz.labor.labyrinth“ directed by Ulduz Ahmadzadeh. We would like to utilize these crossroads as new and inspiring dance and performance methods.


The world famous book “The Little Prince” takes us through a socially critical discussion, including the authentic biography of the author Antoine de Saint-Exupéry. As an international group, we take on the artistic task to freely interpret his stunning story. The choreography will be supported in numerous ways by strong and musically arranged texts, accompanied by live music.  This time the team will focus on bringing the interdisciplinary and contemporary art into the public space, including to every interested person on the street/in parks and the like, making it available to everybody, and giving the opportunity to spontaneously enjoy high quality art for little economical contribution. Arising from our own interpretation of the piece, we wish to create a mobile theatre, being convinced that the privilege to experience and enjoy art, should be made accessible to as many people as possible, including to small cities and towns.  The stage design will be adapted to the mobility of the theatre and to begin with, we will be touring with one bus around Austria. Furthermore we will also travel to neighbouring countries. The grand opening will take place in a public space in Vienna and further appearances in this city are planned. In regard to this matter, the respective authorities have been contacted and informed. The Company stays true to it’s basic concept and wants to give the opportunity to as many professional international artists as possible, to exchange, develop and rediscover themselves in this creative process.


Team


Ulduz Ahmadzadeh -Director/ Dancer

was born 1981 in Theran /Iran, she began to dance as a child and followed this passion in a country where dancing is actually forbidden. Secretly she took dance lessons and managed despite difficult circumstances to perform a couple of times with the dance company Harekat (1999-2004), whereupon she got arrested. After she promised never to work as a dancer again she managed afterwards to gather experiences as a choreographer with different dance ensembles under the pseudonym of “theatre without words”. In this time she became familiar with artistic works amongst others as a coordinator of a performer group of forty people during 2004-2008. In 2007 she accomplished her studies in direction at the university of art in Soureh in Teheran, where she produced experimental films such as Centre less circle (2001) and Sleepers (2004). Since 2008 Ulduz lives in Vienna and works as a dance educator and choreographer. Uldusz took it as her personal task to conserve the traditional classical Persian folk dance as cultural goods. She studied dance pedagogics at the Konservatorium Vienna and since 2013 she accomplishes her master in social design at the university of Applied Arts. Since 2012 she established the contemporary company tanz.labor.labyrinth which produces in cooperation with different artists such as music, composition, and new medias, theatre pieces which were shown in Vienna, Linz and Bratislava: Call for freedom (2009) Seit Ewigkeit (2012), Falling Up (2013) Seven Cities of Love (2014). In July 2013 Ulduz was chosen for Ö1 talent exchange and was introduced on the radio. Currently she is working on her dance-circus-theatre project “The little Prince” for the summer 2014.


Adrián Artacho -Composition

Adrián Artacho was born in Málaga/Spain in 1981. After obtaining his diploma in piano, and a Masters degree in Languages, he studied composition in the Konservatorium Wien University in Vienna, where he graduated with honours in 2012. He is since 2009 artistic director of Neues Atelier, an european organization for contemporary music & art.

 

His compositional work extends to a variety of fields such as Theater (Josephine, Sobre un escenario / On a Stage, Spot, Acreedores/Creditors), Film (Wildnis wurde gezeigt in der FIlmserie Wienersommerkino 2011, Músico competes at the moment in different Filmfestivals), Dance (Call for freedom, Falling up), musical theatre (Buchstabenblut/Bloody Alphabets, Espejos en La menor/Minor Mirrors gewann den Hauptpreis in Theaterwettbewerb „Málaga Crea“), as well as highly experimental works and Multimedia (Giovanni 2.0, Practice Room, Lob der Narrheit, human FLOCKS).  His pieces are performed internationally (Germany, Spain, USA, Indonesia) as well as in Vienna (Mozarthaus, Cervantes Institut, Alte Schmiede, Palais Kabelwerk) where he lives since 2007. He is currently composer in residence of the Lux Festspiele and music director of the contemporary dance company Tanzlabor Labyrinth. 


Eliel Gomez Segura -Performer

Was born in 1986 in México city. He started his artistic formation in theatre studies, combined with Capoeira training, where he received the grade of formed student. In 2006 he moved to Europe to begin his profesional circus studies at the “Ecole de cirque Rogelio Rivel” in Barcelona. In 2008 he especialized as an acrobat in “CODARTS University of arts” in Rotterdam. Since the year 2011 resides in Brussels, where he continued his education as a contemporary dancer at “Danse Centrum Jette”.


Manaho Shimokawa -Dancer 

 

Was born 1991 in Fukuoka/Japan. At age 5 she started to learn Classical Ballett under Konami Kubota. Since 2009 she studied Contemporary dance at Konservatorium Privatüniversität in Vienna. She had worked to create with Volkhard Samuel Guist, Tatiana Diara-Bauer, Patou Bernd Mis-Spitzer, Niki Adler, Elio Gervarsi, Douglas Becker, Darrel Toulon, Esther Balfe, Willie Donner, Virginie Roy-Nigl, Aichenger Manfred, Christina Medina und Michael Turinsky. 2013 she was selected to participate Workshop Crossings #3 in Sounth Africa, Cape Town, Which was held by Choreographer Vincent Mantsoe and Germaine Acogny.  Currently she works as a freelance dancer based in Europe. 


Santo Pablo Krappmann -Performer/Stage Designer 


Was born 1993 in Billabeck, Germany in handmade circus wagon (his parent built some years before when they started to travel as a circus). At the age of three years he started to perform on the stage. Until he was fifteen years old he travelled with his parents and five brothers and sisters in wagons pulled by horses performing up to four times a week. In this time he got to learn many different circus abilities such as juggling, acrobatics, monocycle, walk on rope, and play Diablo and was able to gather many experiences in organization, communication, clownery, and acting At the age of sixteen he moved to Vienna to accomplish an apprenticeship as a joiner and woodworker. Until he was twenty years old he worked in different carpentries, social projects, Film productions, and theaters as a joiner and stage technician. Since 2013 he is studying stage design and performance at the University of Applied Arts in Vienna.


Till Jasper Krappmann -Performer/Designer

Was born 1990 in Kassel (Germany) in a little circus family which is travelling through Europe by horse-drawn waggons. At the early age of 3 years Till started to take part in the shows. Turning 6 years old he could improve his abilities in juggling, acrobatics, rope-walking, and other circus activities well enough to start having his own numbers and roles in the performance. 2006 he started an apprenticeship at the Veterinarian University in Vienna, Austria as a Forge- and Metaltecnician which he finished in October 2010.He passed his exam as a Farrier the same month and started to work independently,  founding his own company. Meanwhile he studied Acupuncture and Phisiotherapy for domestic animals in Germany.2011 Till travelled to South America where he earned his living with street performances and clownery. 2014 he came back to Vienna where he started working on the Project “The little Pince” with the company tanz.labor.labyrinth.
story_txt:
Concept
  Where the elements of circus,
acrobatic, contemporary dance, theatre, body percussion, song and instrumental
music meet and intertwine, there begins the real challenge for the contemporary
art initiative „tanz.labor.labyrinth“ directed by Ulduz Ahmadzadeh.
We would like to utilize these crossroads as new and inspiring dance and
performance methods.

The world famous book “The Little
Prince” takes us through a socially
critical discussion, including the authentic biography of the author Antoine de
Saint-Exupéry. As an international group, we take on the artistic task to
freely interpret his stunning story. The choreography will be supported in
numerous ways by strong and musically arranged texts, accompanied by live
music.  This time the team will focus on bringing the interdisciplinary
and contemporary art into the public space, including to every interested
person on the street/in parks and the like, making it available to everybody,
and giving the opportunity to spontaneously enjoy high quality art for little
economical contribution. Arising from our own interpretation of the piece, we
wish to create a mobile theatre, being convinced that the privilege to
experience and enjoy art, should be made accessible to as many people as
possible, including to small cities and towns.  The stage design will be
adapted to the mobility of the theatre and to begin with, we will be touring
with one bus around Austria. Furthermore we will also travel to neighbouring
countries. The grand opening will take place in a public space in Vienna and
further appearances in this city are planned. In regard to this matter, the
respective authorities have been contacted and informed. The Company stays true
to it’s basic concept and wants to give the opportunity to as many professional
international artists as possible, to exchange, develop and rediscover
themselves in this creative process.




Team

Ulduz Ahmadzadeh -Director/ Dancer






was born 1981 in Theran /Iran, she began to dance as a child and followed this
passion in a country where dancing is actually forbidden. Secretly she took
dance lessons and managed despite difficult circumstances to perform a couple
of times with the dance company Harekat
(1999-2004), whereupon she got arrested. After she promised never to work as a
dancer again she managed afterwards to gather experiences as a choreographer
with different dance ensembles under the pseudonym of “theatre without words”. In this time she became familiar with
artistic works amongst others as a coordinator of a performer group of forty
people during 2004-2008. In 2007 she accomplished her studies in direction at
the university of art in Soureh in Teheran, where she produced experimental films such as Centre less circle (2001) and Sleepers (2004). Since 2008 Ulduz lives in Vienna and works
as a dance educator and choreographer. Uldusz took it as her personal task to
conserve the traditional classical Persian folk dance as cultural goods. She
studied dance pedagogics at the Konservatorium Vienna and since 2013 she accomplishes
her master in social design at the university of Applied Arts. Since 2012 she established the contemporary
company tanz.labor.labyrinth which
produces in cooperation with different artists such as music, composition, and
new medias, theatre pieces which were shown in Vienna, Linz and Bratislava: Call for freedom (2009) Seit Ewigkeit (2012), Falling Up (2013) Seven Cities of Love (2014). In July 2013 Ulduz was chosen for Ö1 talent
exchange and was introduced on the radio. Currently she is working on her
dance-circus-theatre project “The little Prince” for the summer 2014.


Adrián Artacho -Composition

Adrián Artacho was born in Málaga/Spain in 1981. After obtaining his
diploma in piano, and a Masters degree in Languages, he studied composition in
the Konservatorium Wien University in Vienna, where he graduated with honours
in 2012. He is since 2009 artistic director of Neues Atelier, an
european organization for contemporary music & art. 
 His compositional work extends to a variety of fields such as Theater (Josephine,
Sobre un escenario / On a Stage, Spot, Acreedores/Creditors),
Film (Wildnis wurde gezeigt in der FIlmserie Wienersommerkino 2011, Músico
competes at the moment in different Filmfestivals), Dance (Call for freedom,
Falling up), musical theatre (Buchstabenblut/Bloody Alphabets, Espejos
en La menor/Minor Mirrors gewann den Hauptpreis in Theaterwettbewerb „Málaga
Crea“), as well as highly experimental works and Multimedia (Giovanni
2.0, Practice Room, Lob der Narrheit, human FLOCKS).
 His pieces are performed internationally (Germany, Spain, USA, Indonesia)
as well as in Vienna (Mozarthaus, Cervantes Institut, Alte
Schmiede, Palais Kabelwerk) where he lives since 2007. He is
currently composer in residence of the Lux Festspiele and music director of the
contemporary dance company Tanzlabor Labyrinth. 
Eliel Gomez Segura -Performer


Was
born in 1986 in México city. He
started his artistic formation in theatre studies, combined with Capoeira
training, where he received the grade of formed student. In
2006 he moved to Europe to begin his profesional circus studies at the “Ecole
de cirque Rogelio Rivel” in Barcelona. In 2008 he especialized as an acrobat in
“CODARTS University of arts” in Rotterdam. Since
the year 2011 resides in Brussels, where he continued his education as a
contemporary dancer at “Danse Centrum Jette”.





Manaho Shimokawa
-Dancer 


 
Was born 1991 in Fukuoka/Japan. At
age 5 she started to learn Classical Ballett under Konami Kubota. Since 2009
she studied Contemporary dance at Konservatorium Privatüniversität in Vienna. She
had worked to create with Volkhard
Samuel Guist, Tatiana Diara-Bauer, Patou Bernd Mis-Spitzer, Niki Adler, Elio
Gervarsi, Douglas Becker, Darrel Toulon, Esther Balfe, Willie Donner, Virginie
Roy-Nigl, Aichenger Manfred, Christina Medina und Michael Turinsky. 2013
she was selected to participate Workshop Crossings #3 in Sounth Africa, Cape
Town, Which was held by Choreographer Vincent Mantsoe and Germaine Acogny.  Currently she works as a freelance dancer based in Europe. 


Santo Pablo Krappmann -Performer/Stage Designer 
Was born 1993 in Billabeck, Germany in handmade
circus wagon (his parent built some years before when they started to travel as
a circus). At the age of three years he started to perform on the stage. Until
he was fifteen years old he travelled with his parents and five brothers and
sisters in wagons pulled by horses performing up to four times a week. In this
time he got to learn many different circus abilities such as juggling,
acrobatics, monocycle, walk on rope, and play Diablo and was able to gather
many experiences in organization, communication, clownery, and acting At the age
of sixteen he moved to Vienna to accomplish an apprenticeship as a joiner and
woodworker. Until he was twenty years old he worked in different carpentries,
social projects, Film productions, and theaters as a joiner and stage
technician. Since 2013
he is studying stage design and performance at the University of Applied Arts
in Vienna.

Till Jasper Krappmann -Performer/Designer

Was born
1990 in Kassel (Germany) in a little circus family
which is travelling through Europe by horse-drawn waggons. At the early age of
3 years Till started to take part in the shows. Turning 6 years old he could
improve his abilities in juggling, acrobatics, rope-walking, and other circus
activities well enough to start having his own numbers and roles in the
performance. 2006 he started an apprenticeship at the Veterinarian University
in Vienna, Austria as a Forge- and Metaltecnician which he finished in October
2010.He passed his exam as a Farrier the same month and started to work
independently,  founding his own company.
Meanwhile he studied Acupuncture and Phisiotherapy for domestic animals in
Germany.2011 Till travelled to South America where he earned his living with
street performances and clownery. 2014 he came back to Vienna where he started
working on the Project “The little Pince” with the company
tanz.labor.labyrinth.

story:
Die :.PixelHELPER International SARL hat es sich zur Aufgabe gemacht, gegen Ungerechtigkeiten vorzugehen

Bei einer Summe von 2.000€ werden wir eine Lichtkunstkarikatur auf ein Gebäude projizieren und die entstandenen Fotos und Videos der Aktion medienwirksam verteilen. Wir können alternativ auch eine Aktivismus Drohne mit 8 Lautsprechern für weitreichende Aufmerksamkeit einsetzen. Je nach Inhalt der Aktion haben wir viele alternative Möglichkeiten für eine Umsetzung.

Eines unserer großen Themen ist die Kritik an der Kirche. 

Um gegen die Verschwendung von Geldern durch die Kirche zu demonstrieren, hat Licht- und Aktionskünstler Oliver Bienkowski bereits mehrfach mit provokativen Lichtkunstaktionen auf diesen Missstand aufmerksam gemacht. Zahlreiche Medien berichteten darüber. 

Um auch in Zukunft dafür zu kämpfen und Licht- und Kunstaktionen durchzuführen, starten wir dieses Crowdfunding. 

Wir bitten um eure Unterstützung, damit wir Ungerechtigkeiten nicht länger hinnehmen müssen, sondern gemeinsam dagegen vorgehen und protestieren können! 

Durch das kaufen der einzelnen Perks, könnt ihr nicht nur uns helfen, unsere Aktionen zu realisieren, ihr seid dadurch auch selbst Teil der Aktionen.

Jede unserer Aktionen wird auf Video fest gehalten, für deine Unterstützung wirst du namentlich im Abspann unserer Videos genannt.

Hilf' uns jetzt dabei, etwas zu bewegen und gegen die Ungerechtigkeiten in dieser Welt vorzugehen! 

+++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++

Spendenkonto:IBAN: DE70 8105 3272 0641 0339 40

Bank: Sparkasse Magdeburg

Inhaber: PixelHELPER International SARL

story:
About the Artist

American Artist Nathaniel Evans

Nathaniel Evans was raised in a strict, religion home in Appalachia. This experience led him to question the role of faith and beliefs in the world scene, and has been chasing the answers ever since. His artwork reflects the anxiety and oppression that come hand in hand with groups who have disconnected with the world around them, leaving their conscience behind.
There is a great failure in any faith or ideology that disassociates us from conscience. Faith can be intolerant. Faith can be seductive. Coming from a background of a strict religious upbringing, Nathaniel create paintings that are ghost stories of faith and ideology. His work attempts to find the heart of the divide between conscience and faith, reaching out with questions that have no answers. Images of believers provide a religious context and act as a vehicle for dialogue about problematic ideology. Anxieties are given form, becoming over-romanticized notions of mortality.

Artist In Residence

The Collaboration:

  • A full month in resdence at Espositivo to create new works for the exhibition. The goal of $2,000 will go to supplies to create as well as basics for survival.
  • Art supplies are expensive, especially in the quantities needed for a large exhibition and in such short time.
  • Anything helps, even if the goal isn't met this is what will fund the exhibition as a whole.

World-Wide Collaboration

Not everyone who follows the work of the artist can make the trip to Madrid. That's why the indiegogo campaign is expanding the collaboration include everyone.

  • Every collaborator(contributor) will have a chance to recieve original work and sketches from the artist.
  • Large works will be given in a raffle contest
  • Plans to create a book that highlight the important works of the exhibition will depend on contributions, and if it comes to fruition, many collaborators will recieve a copy.

Why a Collaboration?

The works are ambitious. But that doesn't mean that they can't be realized. The greater the scale of collaboration the greater the scale of the exhibition.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

  • If you know anyone who may be interested in collaborating, or even visiting the exhibition, share the campaign with them.
  • You can also wish the artist luck on his journey. He'll appreciate it.

Follow the artist on Instagram at: instragram.com/nevans_art

story: Bonjour, je me présente: mon nom est Eric Braün, je suis un artiste et galiériste situé à Montréal, au Québec. Je m'occupe de la galerie d'art autogérée USINE 106U qui, depuis bientot 10 ans, présente une expo collective mensuelle regroupant une trentaine d'artistes. Depuis 2 ans, j'ai démarré le projet 106U MAGAZINE, une revue d'art trimestrielle de 32 pages couleur, format 9" X 12" tirée à 3000 exemplaires et distribuée gratuitement. Le tirage est entièrement financé par les publicités, qui sont de plus en plus difficiles à trouver, c'est pourquoi je fais appel à votre aide, pour pouvoir continuer ce projet bénévole et passionné qui permet de promouvoir l'art qui sort des sentiers battus. Pour ce 9e numéro, je choisis de rendre hommage à Martine Birobent, une artiste multidisciplinaire dont la démarche unique, brute et expressive est reconnue mondialement, son talent versatile multipliant les créations étonnantes et magnifiques.

story:
We hope to introduce thousands of community members, artists and people worldwide to the idea that art & technology -is- and -can- be accessible to all ages no matter their financial income. Beyond, we will continue to help our community learn and create meaningful work — at a space made for YOU.

 


WHO WE ARE & WHAT WE DO

Motion Media Arts Center proud to announce the opening of Austin Cinemaker Space, a sister program to the Austin School of Film and expansion of Austin School of Film at a new location in Austin, Texas.

Austin Cinemaker Space is an artful creative hub providing a co-working makerspace and membership program launching in September of 2016 and is a program offered through 501 C 3 non-profit, Motion Media Arts Center. Since 2003, we have provided accessibility to art through artists services, and education in digital media, media arts and technology serving 100,000 people directly and reaching millions of people world wide through the creation of new meaningful work by aspiring artists and people of all ages.

Austin Cinemaker Space will merge media arts education and community, demand fluency with the ever evolving technologies, create a fostering more active learning process and directly serve as a reflection of the changing norms in educational and creative environments in digital media and film for the Austin Community.

We are a community of thinkers, creators, artists, entrepreneurs and inventors who gather in mutual support to work, create, and learn. Our space will inhabit nearly 20,000 square feet of a repurposed industrial warehouse in East Austin and offer over 500 classes, workshops and events yearly in arts + technology and membership program allowing us to directly serve 10,000 people per year,  tripling the amount of previous years.

We advocate for those whose stories aren’t being told, and provide access to anyone to tell their stories, share their work and involve their communities in a safe creative environment.

Changing norms in education and accessibility in art + technology is not as easy as it sounds -the first step is a creative safe space with resources to meet our goals.

With the experience of 15 years of programing and thousands of people directly served since 2003, we are ready to get this party started! The cost above will complete the build out and initial start-up supplies for the new space. We have funded 75% of the overall build-out cost to-date through grants, fundraising and individual donations.

Our programs span the entire spectrum of media arts + technology (in terms of genre, scale and ambition) and are designed to fuel the momentum of the region’s nascent, but growing cultural activity. We support local artists and creators in the development of their skills through currently offering 250 classes and programs and in the creation, presentation and promotion of work through artist events and showcases. We celebrate cultural diversity to give voice to and bring together communities across the region’s demographic landscape through our outreach programs such as Cine Joven: Filmmaking in Spanish. 95% of works completed at or through us have been exhibited in regional, national, and international showcases.



Let’s party like it’s 2002!

In 2002, Center for Young Cinema and Austin Cinemaker Co-op merged to create Motion Media Arts Center, a creative space to develop and educate emerging artists of all ages in film, art, and digital media.

In 2004, Motion Media Arts Center is renamed as the Austin School of Film because “What is media arts and why should I learn about it?” - a term, now well established was still a slight mystery to the community at large. With technology evolving at rapid speed and computers becoming a household staple — we launch a membership program to provide access to computers, creative software such as Adobe Flash and Final Cut Pro, resources and equipment and launch an Apple Certified Training lab.

While we begin adding more and more educational resources and classes every day to our catalog, we stop - we stop and think for a minute. There is a gap with reaching people of color within media arts in Austin, Texas. More specifically, Hispanic and Latinx youth. Essentially, if Austin's Hispanic/Latinx youth was underrepresented at the Austin School of Film, then why not take the ASoF – instructors, gear, and all – to them? ....And that is exactly what we did! Our first programming for Cine Joven: Filmmaking in Spanish was hosted at San Juan Diego High school in Austin, Texas. It was the perfect way to offer both younger kids and older teens from the potentially lower-income Latino, Mexican-American, and immigrant communities a way to find their own unique voices in a rapidly expanding global media-scape.

In 2005, the Austin School of Film launches our first certificate program, Digital Video Certificate Program (DVCP). DVCP was designed as an affordable series of classes in video production and post-production that prepare students to work in the industry and/or on their own indie productions. Training classes in HD Camera, Lighting, Sound, Production Management, editing on industry standard software platforms. Placing 65% of ASoF certificate graduates into jobs in their desired career field.

In 2007, ASoF hosted and produced the 18th Annual National Alliance for Media Arts & Culture Conference. Bringing together over 300 leaders in the media arts & visual arts for an intensive inquiry of the current state of the field and its future. Media artists, media center staff/board, funders, programmers, educators, activists and more from 30 states, Mexico and Canada gathered.

From 2008-2015, we have held over 1,500 current members in our 4,000 square foot facility and provided a space for people of all ages to come and explore their artistic imaginations in an interactive, hands-on environment without financial risk of taking on ideas alone. We do this by providing short & long term programs attracting the community, visitors, touring artists, and Filmmaker’s Connection participants. The possibilities that arise out of a cross-cultural exchange bare part of what makes any art scene vibrant, and it is the interaction between new talent and learned colleagues that paves the way towards new careers, new work and new cinema. We provide a place for education, exhibits and tools to share our city’s growing and unique art culture.

And now?

In 2015, we acquired our new home! A 20,000 square foot warehouse located in at 2200 Tillery in East Austin. We worked with local developers and support to raise funds for overhaul and build out of the industrial warehouse to expand existing and new services and programs including: a creative makerspace, three new certificate programs within arts + technology, expanded class catalog, affordable art studio space for lease and a new partnership and shared community space with Studium. Studium is an arts and education non-profit organization dedicated to the publication and presentation of rigorous and creative work. We have big plans ahead of us and cannot wait to share our collaborative efforts. 

Since 2005, Motion Media Arts Center has offered over 250 classes year round at an accessible or free tuition cost for the community at our downtown East Austin location. We employee a full time staff and over 100 local teachers and artists, which enables us to serve over 3,000 people directly every year including at-risk adults and teens, international, regional and of course, the local community.


Even if you can’t donate, here’s how you can help!

Motion Media Arts Center is and will always be an organization that is financially accessible to any person interested in the community — whether it’s a place to work, learn or create. With this in mind, we are aware some of you may not be able to spare funds. Whether you are able donate to our community campaign or not, you can still help us make our futures brighter, educated and creative.

Ways you can help:

  • Share this video or campaign!
  • ​Spread the word about the #SupportASoF mission and launch of #AustinCinemakerSpace on Facebook or Twitter.
  • Amazon.com customers: Do your shopping at smile.amazon.com to donate a % of all purchases to Motion Media Arts (austinfilmschool.org)!
  • Stay connected. Follow Austin School of Film on Facebook, Twitter and Instagram to stay up-to-date on the movement of our campaign.


What the FAQ? Frequently Asked Questions!

Are you a non-profit organization? Are donations tax-deductible?

Yep! Motion Media Arts Center registered as a public 501(c)(3) nonprofit. Any donations (including in-kind) are tax-deductible to the by law. Motion Media Arts Center tax ID number is: 36-4533347

How can I get a tax deductible receipt?

When you donate funds to our campaign, you will receive an email from FirstGiving (Indiegogo’s nonprofit payments processor) confirming your contribution amount. This email receipt can be used for tax deductible purposes. For all contributions over $200, you will receive an official receipt for tax-reporting purposes by email after the the campaign ends from Motion Media Arts Center.

What payment methods do you accept?

Indiegogo accepts all major credit cards.

Is shipping included?

Yes, it is included at checkout! Or alternatively, you can choose to pick up at our new home and take a tour!

Large Donations! How can I make a contribute over $10,000?

FirstGiving’s non-profit payment processor is able to handle transactions for this community campaign of all sizes! If you are interested in making a donation of $10,000 or more, please contact us at communityfund@austinfilmschool.org. We will put you in touch with a specialistic at IndieGoGo who will assist in the contribution process for larger sums.

Still have some questions? Contact us!

If you still have some questions about our community campaign or general questions about our organization, contact us at: community@austinfilmschool.org and we’ll get back to you as soon as we can!

There is a gap with reaching people of color within media arts in Austin, Texas. More specifically, Hispanic and Latinx youth. Essentially, if Austin's Hispanic/Latinx youth was underrepresented at the Austin School of Film, then why not take the ASoF – instructors, gear, and all – to them? ....And that is exactly what we did! Our first programming for Cine Joven: Filmmaking in Spanish was hosted at San Juan Diego High school in Austin, Texas. It was the perfect way to offer both younger kids and older teens from the potentially lower-income Latino, Mexican-American, and immigrant communities a way to find their own unique voices in a rapidly expanding global media-scape.In 2005, the Austin School of Film launches our first certificate program, Digital Video Certificate Program (DVCP). DVCP was designed as an affordable series of classes in video production and post-production that prepare students to work in the industry and/or on their own indie productions. Training classes in HD Camera, Lighting, Sound, Production Management, editing on industry standard software platforms. Placing 65% of ASoF certificate graduates into jobs in their desired career field.In 2007, ASoF hosted and produced the 18th Annual National Alliance for Media Arts & Culture Conference. Bringing together over 300 leaders in the media arts & visual arts for an intensive inquiry of the current state of the field and its future. Media artists, media center staff/board, funders, programmers, educators, activists and more from 30 states, Mexico and Canada gathered.From 2008-2015, we have held over 1,500 current members in our 4,000 square foot facility and provided a space for people of all ages to come and explore their artistic imaginations in an interactive, hands-on environment without financial risk of taking on ideas alone. We do this by providing short & long term programs attracting the community, visitors, touring artists, and Filmmaker’s Connection participants. The possibilities that arise out of a cross-cultural exchange bare part of what makes any art scene vibrant, and it is the interaction between new talent and learned colleagues that paves the way towards new careers, new work and new cinema. We provide a place for education, exhibits and tools to share our city’s growing and unique art culture.And now?In 2015, we acquired our new home! A 20,000 square foot warehouse located in at 2200 Tillery in East Austin. We worked with local developers and support to raise funds for overhaul and build out of the industrial warehouse to expand existing and new services and programs including: a creative makerspace, three new certificate programs within arts + technology, expanded class catalog, affordable art studio space for lease and a new partnership and shared community space with Studium. Studium is an arts and education non-profit organization dedicated to the publication and presentation of rigorous and creative work. We have big plans ahead of us and cannot wait to share our collaborative efforts. Since 2005, Motion Media Arts Center has offered over 250 classes year round at an accessible or free tuition cost for the community at our downtown East Austin location. We employee a full time staff and over 100 local teachers and artists, which enables us to serve over 3,000 people directly every year including at-risk adults and teens, international, regional and of course, the local community.Even if you can’t donate, here’s how you can help!Motion Media Arts Center is and will always be an organization that is financially accessible to any person interested in the community — whether it’s a place to work, learn or create. With this in mind, we are aware some of you may not be able to spare funds. Whether you are able donate to our community campaign or not, you can still help us make our futures brighter, educated and creative.Ways you can help:

Share this video or campaign!


​Spread the word about the #SupportASoF mission and launch of #AustinCinemakerSpace on Facebook or Twitter.
Amazon.com customers: Do your shopping at smile.amazon.com to donate a % of all purchases to Motion Media Arts (austinfilmschool.org)!
Stay connected. Follow Austin School of Film on Facebook, Twitter and Instagram to stay up-to-date on the movement of our campaign.
What the FAQ? Frequently Asked Questions!Are you a non-profit organization? Are donations tax-deductible?Yep! Motion Media Arts Center registered as a public 501(c)(3) nonprofit. Any donations (including in-kind) are tax-deductible to the by law. Motion Media Arts Center tax ID number is: 36-4533347How can I get a tax deductible receipt?When you donate funds to our campaign, you will receive an email from FirstGiving (Indiegogo’s nonprofit payments processor) confirming your contribution amount. This email receipt can be used for tax deductible purposes. For all contributions over $200, you will receive an official receipt for tax-reporting purposes by email after the the campaign ends from Motion Media Arts Center.What payment methods do you accept?Indiegogo accepts all major credit cards.Is shipping included?Yes, it is included at checkout! Or alternatively, you can choose to pick up at our new home and take a tour!Large Donations! How can I make a contribute over $10,000?FirstGiving’s non-profit payment processor is able to handle transactions for this community campaign of all sizes! If you are interested in making a donation of $10,000 or more, please contact us at communityfund@austinfilmschool.org. We will put you in touch with a specialistic at IndieGoGo who will assist in the contribution process for larger sums.Still have some questions? Contact us!If you still have some questions about our community campaign or general questions about our organization, contact us at: community@austinfilmschool.org and we’ll get back to you as soon as we can!

story:
Whitehorse, Yukon, Canada, Art

UP-DATE:January 7th, 12 hours left

We'll have a set of art cards for the person that breaks the $17,000 mark. And the last contributor gets a Daphne Mennell Gilclee Print!

UP-DATE: December 30th, 2014  - 9 days left

Thank you! We're nearly at $16,000. Help us  reach our stretch goal of $20,000 with whatever is comfortable for you and/or share this request with your e-mail network, on Facebook or other ways of sharing in your community.

Based on quotes recently received from local businesses, we have enough to cover the furnace replacement including the new chimney insert and ducting required. And we can cover some of the renovations required for the second washroom.  We'd love to avoid a bank loan for the balance of the renovations and the modernized retail equipment. Please share far and wide.

UP-DATE: December 18th, 2014 ....THANK YOU!  from all of us at YA@W. With your help we have now passed the $15,000 mark! 

We're not sure if Erin Dixon or Lynda Ehrlich put us over our mark, as the donations occurred within one second and the transactions were entered differently in two locations!! So they both get a set of 5 Art Cards. And MJ Warshawski gets a set too for putting us so close to the mark!

We'll have  more extra perks as we pass other milestones, so keep on sharing this campaign.

UP-DATE: December 6th, 2014

WOW! Yukoners and the art loving community are sooooo awesome! We have surpassed our goal. Please don't let that stop you from contributing.

When we began this crowd-funding campaign, we were apprehensive, and therefore conservative in placing our goal at $11,000. We are amazed by the generosity out there. We can make good use of additional funds for our renovations, reducing the amount of our bank loan required for this project. THE NEW STRETCH GOAL IS $20,000. Please encourage those in your community of friends and family  to support with a contribution of whatever feels right to them.


What is Yukon Artists at Work?  And what’s the big excitement?

Who is YA@W?

Yukon Artists at Work (YA@W) is a non-profit visual arts cooperative with the vision of rejuvenating itself in a downtown location. Conceived in 2003 as a supportive community for artists to take control of their own careers by creating their own venue to promote their art, YA@W has built a strong reputation in the Yukon. Membership fluctuates between 30 and 40 members as artists come and go, lives change focus, or some dear friends pass on. YA@W was listed as one of the top 10 hidden gems of Canada by the global tourism website Trip Advisor, and has been visited by notable people like former Governor General, Michaëlle Jean and 2010 Olympics CEO, John Furlong.

We work very hard and do lots of cool stuff:

YA@W hosts 12 exhibitions every year with free opening events, conducts free school and adult tours and a range of artist talks and demonstrations. YA@W has spearheaded many community projects through its active members. The Yukon Artists Relief Fund to assist local artists and their families dealing with medical emergencies or financial struggles was initiated by YA@W members. This year YA@W conducted a special project for youth and seniors involving a series of art-based workshops through autumn, winter and spring. YA@W members held the annual week-long Plein Air Festival, where visual artists do their art in specific outdoor locations for tourists and locals to come out and enjoy.This culminated in an exhibition hosted YA@W. Through the years, YA@W has helped hundreds of artists, welcomed thousands of visitors, and become an important part of our northern community. We believe that everyone, every single person, should be able to have art in their lives and feel welcome at our space.

Why do we need to move? 

Our gallery is currently located in the industrial area, up a long flight of stairs, on top of a warehouse in Whitehorse. YA@W has come to realize this location is hindering its effectiveness and its ability to maximize benefits to the community. This is evident in comments from gallery visitors, like this one: “The gallery is awesome and by far my new favourite gallery north of 60; such a group of fantastic artists.  The location sucks though….” Members are also feeling the same dissatisfaction with the current location.

In a downtown location, YA@W will have a bigger, richer, and more lasting impact for our wonderful community of artists and the art-loving community as a whole. This move will be a shot of adrenaline that picks us up and moves us on to a whole new level of artist support and community involvement. It's a new beginning. YA@W will be an even more beloved, iconic destination.

What do we need funds for?

We found a funky building in a fantastic downtown location but it requires substantial work for occupancy.  We need to remove and replace the furnace and ducting, a second washroom, other renovations and some upgraded retail equipment. Since YA@W does not profit from its activities, a reserve of funds to draw upon does not exist. This is where you come in. 

We are asking you to help YA@W meet our funding goal, and receive 50% of that same amount in a gallery gift certificate to spend after the first year in the new location, when YA@W will be well on it’s feet and financially able to repay your kindness. And there are more perks too!

YA@W perks!

Our perks give back to you with a big thank you for your support. We love doing what we do in the Yukon, and we want each of you who donate to have art in your lives and to experience the excitement of our new beginning. Our perks that help us reach this goal vary according to donor categories and are: 

-  the gratitude of over 30 Yukon artists,

-  YA@W pins,

-  a listing of your name online and in our gallery, indicating donor category

-  a gift certificate of 50% of your donation to spend in our gallery after the first year in the new location, when YA@W will be well on it’s feet and financially able to repay your kindness.

-  we have four categories where we’ll name a room in your honour (eg. The Smith room).

-  A private party! ... use our gorgeous new gallery for one private 2015 event with 2 or 3 artists present to assist during your event.

When, where, how?

All this is all taking place in Whitehorse, Yukon in Canada. The new Whitehorse location is the blue building at #4129, 4th Avenue. Have a look at the map and the photo of the bright blue building in the Gallery section. YA@W will move locations in January 2015. We have assessed needs and are currently acquiring firm competitive quotes for various aspects of the work.

The work will be managed by YA@W members and performed by local contractors and suppliers, the membership and volunteers.  Many of our members had previous careers that will ensure our move will go smoothly and renovations will be managed cost effectively. Among us we have engineers, set designers, stage carpenters, project managers, financial managers and more.

And we will keep everyone updated on what we’re doing, how we’re doing and answer any questions!

How you can help:

Donate here and now. Share the campaign online. Tell somebody about it. Tell everybody about it. The bigger the network, the more likely we are to reach our goal. Get co-workers or friends together to go in on a big perk... have a great private party! Write an article about the project. Get excited for our grand new beginning in 2015!

From all of us at YA@W, thank you so very much for your interest, we hope you will check out our web-site, facebook page, pictures, and get involved.

http://www.yaaw.com/

https://www.facebook.com/pages/Yukon-Artists-at...

story:
The Artist and Social Responsibility (ASR) class, a new project of The Artblog, unites teens from the Philadelphia School District and undergrads from area colleges to investigate questions about art’s role in society.

Some examples of the urgent questions we are discussing in this alternative model college course held at the Village of Arts and Humanities include:

  • How can an artist from outside a community work comfortably with a community — and vice versa?
  • What are the ethics involved with unpaid volunteers vs. paid community helpers?
  • Can art that is practical (giving people jobs or housing or a playground or park) still be art?

The History

Philadelphia has a strong history of activism in its many neighborhoods and communities.  Over the last ten years, artists have flocked to the city in unprecedented numbers. Many of them work on art projects with neighborhood or ethnic communities.   The Artblog, a leader in the Philadelphia art community founded by two artist activists, responded to this need and interest with the creation of the Artist and Social Responsibility class to engage college students. As artists and citizens of this region’s future, young adults in the class are exactly the ones who should be focusing on this topic.


The Need

The Artblog was awarded a generous $50,000 project grant from the Knight Foundation for the launch of this unprecedented project, and we need your support to raise an additional $4,000 to ensure the project’s success. Artblog is a 501(c)(3) nonprofit organization, and all donations are 100% tax-deductible. Reaching this Indigogo fundraising goal will set The Artblog on strong footing to raise the remaining funds for the Artist and Social Responsibility Project from individuals and foundations.

We are coming to you for help. We need funds for our operational costs in 2015; and we need funds to help us plan for the ASR project’s continuation in 2016 and beyond.

Funds from you will help underwrite:

  • Program implementation
  • Facility fees
  • Materials and supplies
  • Artist and Social Responsibility professional project staff compensation
  • Stipends for the non-college program participants who are true “apprentice” college students
  • Program evaluation

The Impact - A Laboratory for Social Responsibility

Philadelphia’s undergraduate population is a great, untapped resource in a city that was recently called the poorest big city in the country. Many undergraduates see the needs in the city, but do not know how to get involved or how to make a difference in their own community. The project helps students investigate the practice of community art and channels their energy, enthusiasm and skills in a meaningful project that will become a “laboratory for social responsibility” and an incubator for future leaders in the community art movement. Young adults meet with the national thought-leaders, arts directors, and community change agents, building a professional network to fuel their studies and career path. They work together on community issues of importance to the Village of Arts and Humanities.

Participating high school students are challenged by an underfunded and broken School District. The ASR class provides the students an entry to college in a direct way they will not experience otherwise. The college-level work they are doing in this class will lay the groundwork for further education beyond high school.

Who’s taking the class?

This 3-credit college class rounds up 8 students from 5 local colleges —

  • Arcadia University
  • Moore College of Art and Design
  • Saint Joseph’s University
  • Temple University 
  • University of Pennsylvania

And pairs them with 6 students from 3 high schools and a community college —

  • Community College of Philadelphia
  • Mastbaum High School
  • Math, Civics and Science Charter School
  • Ben Franklin High School

People and Partners for Powerful Results

  • The Artblog is working in collaboration with the Village of Arts and Humanities, renowned for its work in North Philadelphia and for its commitment to social engagement through art.

  • Artblog co-founder and Artist and Social Responsibility project director Roberta Fallon was art critic for the Philadelphia Weekly (1999-2011) and wrote the Philadelphia Story column for artnet.com (2000-2005).  She teaches Professional Practices at Saint Joseph’s University, and has taught at Tyler School of Art and University of the Arts and has lectured frequently in the region about the importance of art to society. 

  • Artist and Social Responsibilityproject instructorTheresa Rose is founder of the micro-granting project, Philly Stake, and former Percent for Art Project Manager for the City of Philadelphia. She is an instructor in Moore College of Art and Design’s new Community Art graduate program. 

  • Our laboratory class is held at an independent location in North Philadelphia operated as a project space by the Village of Arts and Humanities.

The Collaborators - Two Amazing Arts Organizations

The Artblog is an independent online magazine that fosters dialog and community through commentary and discussion about art and culture. We believe that discussion about issues of beauty, truth, value and power in the context of art will make the world a better place.  Our goal, which we achieve through our publications and educational programs, is to educate our community about the importance of art to civil society primarily on the Philadelphia region.  We aim especially to raise the profile of marginalized artists – the young, minorities and women -- who have been left out of the conversation. 

The Artblog is a facilitator, sharing information, educating people and creating dialog and excitement among all members of the art community. We have a 12-year proven history of working with many people of diverse backgrounds, and jumping up to this next level of leadership is appropriate for us. The time is right for this innovative social responsibility project, and The Artblog's deep regional connections in the arts community, successful track record and dedicated leadership will ensure its success. 

The Village of Arts and Humanities (The Village) is a multifaceted arts organization dedicated to community revitalization through the arts. Through The Village’s new Artist in Residence Project, SPACES, artists share their expertise and creative practices with a neighborhood experiencing the effects of decades of disinvestment. In exchange, their practice is enriched by the gifts and insights of our own community, and by the process of collaborating to create social equity in North Central Philadelphia and make art and experiences of lasting value.

Other ways to help

  • Sign on to follow The Artblog
  • Share this page with family and friends, advocate for the Artist and Social Responsibility Project and ask for their support.
  • Join us for the upcoming Artblog event in Philadelphia on March 23.

The Artblog and Artist and Social Responsibility project team thank you for your support!

If you have questions, contact Roberta Fallon at robertafallon@gmail.com.

and Social Responsibilityproject
instructorTheresa Rose is
founder of the micro-granting project, Philly Stake, and former Percent for Art
Project Manager for the City of Philadelphia. She is an instructor in Moore
College of Art and Design’s new Community Art graduate program. 


Our laboratory class is held at an independent location in North Philadelphia operated as a project space by the Village of Arts and Humanities.


The Collaborators - Two Amazing Arts Organizations

The Artblog is an independent online magazine that fosters dialog and community through commentary and discussion about art and culture. 
We believe that discussion about issues of beauty,
truth, value and power in the context of art will make the world a better
place.  Our goal, which we achieve through our publications and educational programs, is to educate our community about the importance of art to civil society primarily on the Philadelphia region.  We aim especially to raise the profile of marginalized artists – the young, minorities and women -- who have been left out of the conversation. 
The Artblog is a facilitator, sharing information, educating people and creating dialog and excitement among all members of the art community. We have a 12-year proven history of working with many people of diverse backgrounds, and jumping up to this next level of leadership is appropriate for us. The time is right for this innovative social responsibility project, and The Artblog's deep regional connections in the arts community, successful track record and dedicated leadership will ensure its success. 
The Village of Arts and Humanities (The Village) is a multifaceted arts organization dedicated to community revitalization through the arts. Through The Village’s new Artist in Residence Project, SPACES, artists share their expertise and creative practices with a neighborhood experiencing the effects of decades of disinvestment. In exchange, their practice is enriched by the gifts and insights of our own community, and by the process of collaborating to create social equity in North Central Philadelphia and make art and experiences of lasting value.
Other
ways to help


Sign on to follow The Artblog

Share this page with
     family and friends, advocate for the Artist and Social Responsibility
     Project and ask for their support.
Join us for the
     upcoming Artblog event in Philadelphia on March 23.


The Artblog and Artist and Social Responsibility
project team thank you for your support!
If you have questions,
contact Roberta Fallon at robertafallon@gmail.com.

story:
Summary

I'm bringing the Reflection Tree to Burning Man 2016, and I need your help to offset the costs! 

The Reflection Tree captures the environment around it, and reflects the most significant colors over time up the trunk of the tree.

The tree has already been installed at Firefly 2016, but improvements, transportation and installation costs for Burning Man are significant, so I'm doing a short no-frills campaign to help me get over the finish line. 

Perks

There are no perks for this campaign. I am solely focused on bringing art to the playa, but you'll have my ever-lasting gratitude. 

What We Need

I'm hoping to raise $500, or a little bit more. I was the recipient of a Firefly Art Grant, but that only covered a portion of the costs. This money is going to cover:

  • Improved vision processing system (4 Raspberry Pis)
  • Improved waterproofing
  • Heavy gauge extension cords that can be buried to reach a generator
  • Transportation/shipping costs
  • Building a crate to ensure safe arrival on shipping container
  • Repair to some LEDs damaged at Firefly

The Installation

The Reflection Tree will be across from The Hive village at Esplanade & 8:30. It's also scheduled to be installed at NECTR 2016.

Risks & Challenges

I've already created the art piece, but anything can happen on the playa. The main risk is that damage from the shipping container journey makes the piece inoperable.

story:
Hello,

This campaign is to raise funds for Mateo Marquis, and his online design company. Mateo is serving time for a traggic situation that occured while defending a friend after being jumped by many men on the beach. He is finishing a 7 year sentence and will be returning to his community in February of 2014, exactly the month of his 27th birthday.

Mateo will use his new business MTM Illuminated as a channel for conscious awareness through art, music and connection to others. He will start with graphics that he sends to me from inside. I, his mother, will print as wearable art or print art and sell online. Or he can also design a logo of your choice that works with stylized type, rendered by hand.

Mateo will be able to come home to a functioning outlet which can provide support and viability. His goals besides a continued progression with his music as well as to become a Graphic Designer, are to use his many gifts to work with youth as an inspirational resource.

If you would like to support Mateo's new business MTM Illuminated, please make your donations through this site. If you would like to further connect with Mateo, please email me for his contact information.

In loving light,

 

Marsea and Mateo Marquis

story:
Our Story

We are a group of creative and motivated friends: architects, artists, photographers and writers who have come together with a shared love for Tankwa Town.

 

Tankwa Town is the name given to the collection of art, people and co-operation that is AfrikaBurn - an official regional event of the Burning Man Festival - held in the Tankwa Karoo, South Africa. AfrikaBurn upholds the guiding principles of Burning Man. It is a public art festival, promoting the creative arts and radical expression through building a temporary community of collaborative arts projects, non-commercialism and collective participation. For those that have been no explanation is necessary, for those that haven't descriptions seem to fall short. 

Having attended AfrikaBurn 2011, friends Christo Van Der Hoven and Andrew Moerdyk were interested in how they would approach building a structure for the festival. As architecture students, they reflected on the amount of time at university spent talking rather than making. “You end up getting shoved into an office after being taught so much but don't have anything to show for it. I mean I understand you don't give a surgeon a knife and let him start cutting immediately, but there are certain things we can experiment with and Khamsin is one of those instances. AfrikaBurn has given us the opportunity to create something beautiful and learn through making," notes Christo.



We still needed someone who could make this a reality. Enter honours year sculpture student, Haroon Gunn-Salie. Haroon's invaluable experience in organising collaborative arts projects and events was the key piece missing for the project to move forward. His role in the team has helped take Khamsin from the drawing board into reality.

AfrikaBurn is the perfect context for such a theoretical and technical exercise - it's the middle of nowhere, the perfect place for experimenting with temporary space-making. With support from the University of Cape Town and engineering assistance from the internationally renowned engineering firm, Arup, Khamsin got underway.

The project is inspired by the Khamsin - a five day period of sandstorms in North Africa.

 


 

The structure is an experiment in rapid design and construction, responding to the vastness of the Tankwa Karoo and exuberance of AfrikaBurn. The project makes use of new and innovative intervention methods and processes within a emergent platform for radical expression. Rather than a traditional timber structure, Khamsin will be constructed from a cardboard composite - digitally fabricated and slot joined. 

 


The short lifespan and unique location offer a challenging and unique context within which to test, explore and share ideas. Expressed as a dynamic surface, whipped into form and frozen, the design is articulated as a gridded structure that serves as both formal expression and structural system. 

 

What We Need

After being selected as a piece for this year's event, Khamsin was awarded the largest grant given by AfrikaBurn in its history, to facilitate the execution of the project. However, in line with the creative grant policy of AfrikaBurn, this grant represents only half of the total costs of the project. Therefore we need your help to get Khamsin to the desert. By helping us reach our target you will be part of making one the largest and most technically advanced scupltures in AfrikaBurn history.


Other Ways You Can Help

You can visit our website and find out ways in which you can volunteer. You can also find us on Facebook. At our core we are collaborators and open to people who want to help contribute to Khamsin. Like it, share it, spread the word.

story:
Jaunt is a quarterly publication of stories, providing the reader with an opportunity to take an excursion into the unusual and unexpected, encouraging curiosity and exploration.

Seeking to spark thought and creativity, each issue of Jaunt will curate varied features with a focus on contemporary photo reportages, as well as profiles of new and emerging creatives, and in the process prompt an escape from the ordinary.

To bring Jaunt to life, we need your help. Any donations to the project will be gratefully received, and rewarded with gifts from the magazine.

Thank you!

Any donations to the project will be gratefully received, and rewarded with gifts from the magazine.Thank you!

story:
Ms. Connections is a non-verbal clown who suffers from loneliness and papers her walls with Yellow Pages pages to comfort herself. She is reading 7 Habits of Highly Effective People and practicing proactivity; so she has moved her entire house to the Abrons Underground, hired entertainment, procured snacks, and engaged staff in order to properly and safely receive unknown guests.

You May Meet Her is an IRL RPG centered on a blind playdate with a socially anxious extrovert, her house & her hired help. An entirely immersive and interactive installation You May Meet Her is set with 60-plus action items that, once triggered, activate a response that may delight the (singular) guest in an experiment in choice, if/then scenarios, social contract, etiquette, unfamiliar embodied interactions, and surprises.

Moving is expensive.

What Is Needed & What You Get

Ms. Connections needs to buy some furniture so that her living room is more guest friendly.  She promises to shop second hand.

Ms. Connections needs to pay for her awesome distant cousin/service animal/butler/bouncer/friend who has just arrived to help with the guests and now is expecting food and needs new glasses.

Ms. Connections needs to pay the guest artists she hired to make the guests so happy.  They are so fresh these artists and they don't ask for much.  New underwear or a train ticket, a drink and a sandwich isn't so much to ask.  Zhen would like to be able to help Ms. C give them that.

The PERKS:
  • Look to the right!

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can contribute $ please do, and if you can contribute $ and spread the word about the project then please really do, and if you can't contribute money but can spread the word please really really do.

  • Get the word out and make some noise about this campaign & about people being able to visit Ms. C's house!


Other Buddies involved/on this ride:  Nikki Calonge, Whitney Dearden, Mia Torres, Cate Giordano, Ani Taj, Emily Wexler, Dr. Lucky Ph.D, Leah Aron, Adrienne Anemone, & more!

story:
For years I have been asked to teach art from my studio. For years I have said no. Two young children, a very small studio, and limited funds have necessitated this answer every time I have been asked. My kids are now old enough to be helpful and I have access to a larger space. As I present this idea to my current students and their parents I am being met with such love and enthusiasm that I cannot wait to start.

My idea is to use what is currently an old garage that used to serve as my art studio. I am setting the goal of opening my doors this summer. To that end I have enlisted my father and brother, restoration builders extraordinaire, to help transform the space from dank garage/old studio/workshop into cool, hip, art studio. 

Because our funding is limited, groups will be small, ranging from private lessons to small groups of 4 or so. 



My inventory is slowly being uploaded if you would like to see available work for your contribution:

http://www.flickr.com/photos/119879964@N04/

If you see something you like that is close to what you donated feel free to make me an offer:-)

story:
Scorri in basso per la versione italiana

WHO AM I?

My name is Sara Simon and next year I am going to join the team at Art Refuge UK to bring my work as an Art Therapist to Nepal. 

WHAT IS 'Send your Postcard to Nepal' ABOUT?

Send your postcard to Nepal is a campaign I have created to fundraise for my collaboration with Art Refuge UK. If you would like to support my work as an art therapist in Nepal you can donate on this page. You will receive a handmade postcard - a little piece of art made by other art therapists and artists that support this campaign. 

You can see all the postcards currently available from this gallery, and when you donate you can specify which postcard you wish to receive. I will do my best to send it to you (although sometimes it may be that the postcard you have chosen has been sold in the meantime, but I will make sure to send you another one!) 

WHY Art Refuge UK?

Since volunteering in India in 2009, I have always wished to work in Asia as an Art Therapist, and it was as a result of this experience held in a school for children with special needs and learning disabilities, that I decided to pursue a career as an Art Therapist. I discovered the work of Art Refuge Uk through the course of my study and I decided, once graduated, to do my best to join the Art Refuge UK Programme, which reflects the ideals I have always believed in.

Art Refuge UK is a British charity that aims to provide emotional support to displaced children and young people from Tibet who, have arrived in Nepal to search for a better future. Since the devastating earthquake Art Refuge UK have intensified their support in the area of Katmandu and require help from trained art therapists. 

Please donate to support art therapies in a multicultural and international context, and to help create awareness of the vital work being done by Art Refuge UK in Nepal and Europe.

For updates on my campaign please follow

www.sarasimon.it and Facebook !

Sara

P.S. If you cannot contribute with a donation you can still help me by sharing and advertising my campaign! Be loud and creative!


_______________________________Italian version_________________________________


CHI SONO?

Ciao a tutti, sono Sara Simon, una ragazza italiana trapiantata a Londra che il prossimo anno si unirà al team di Art Refuge UK per portare il mio lavoro come Arte Terapeuta in Nepal.

CHE COSA é 'Send your Postcard to Nepal'?

Send your postcard to Nepal è una campagna di raccolta fondi che ho creato per finanziare la mia collaborazione con Art Refuge UK.

Per aiutarmi in in questa impresa puoi contribuire alla raccolta fondi  acquistando la tua #postcardtonepal, cioè una cartolina realizzata a mano da arte terapeuti ed artisti internazionali, con lo scopo di finanziare il mio progetto di collaborazione con Art Refuge UK. 

Puoi vedere tutte le cartoline disponibili su questa gallery.

Con la tua donazione puoi specificare quale postcard desideri ricevere, ed io farò il possibile per fartela avere! (Nel caso la cartolina da te scelta sia già stata 'inviata' te ne manderò un altra altrettanto bella!) 

WHY Art Refuge UK?

Nel 2009 dopo un' esperienza di volontariato in India in una scuola per bambini disabili, ho preso la decisione di proseguire i miei studi dedicandomi all' Arte Terapia. Da quel giorno ho sempre sognato di tornare in Asia come arte terapeuta. 

Durante il Master in Art Psychotherapy presso la Goldsmith University of London, sono venuta a conoscenza del programma di Art Refuge, e condividendone gli ideali ho deciso di unirmi al loro progetto.

Art Refuge UK è una ONG inglese che si occupa di dare un supporto emotivo attraverso l'arte terapia a bambini e giovani rifugiati Tibetani che arrivano in Nepal alla ricerca di un futuro migliore. Dopo il devastante sisma che ha colpito il Nepal nell' Aprile - Maggio 2015, Art Refuge UK chiede l’ausilio di Arte Terapeuti per rispondere alle richieste di aiuto delle autorità nepalesi e di organizzazioni internazionali.

Nelle zone colpite dal sisma gruppi di volontari specializzati in Arte Terapia (registrati all’albo nazionale Inglese) lavorano in collaborazione con organizzazioni locali e internazionali , pianificando attività terapeutiche di gruppo, con lo scopo di ristabilire la normalità per le strade di Kathmandu.

Nonostante lo scopo principale rimanga quello di dare un aiuto ai rifugiati Tibetani, l’associazione ha accolto la domanda di espansione di un network di educazione all’Arte Terapia rivolto a professionisti nel settore della sanità e dell’educazione.

Art Refuge UK ha creato e co-facilita gruppi di supporto per la popolazione locale e gruppi di condivisione per gli operatori psico-sociali, artisti e insegnanti che stanno lottando per rispondere alle esigenze attuali create dalla situazione di emergenza causata dal sisma.

Con la tua donazione potrai contribuire a diffondere l’importante ruolo dell’Arte Terapia in contesti di vulnerabilità, infanzia, e migrazione, e valorizzare il grande impegno di Art Refuge UK nei suoi progetti in Europa e all'estero. 

Per rimanere aggiornato sul progetto 'Send Your Postcard to Nepal' puoi seguirmi su www.sarasimon.it e su Facebook !

Grazie di cuore

Sara

Per aiutarmi in in questa impresa puoi contribuire alla raccolta fondi  acquistando la tua #postcardtonepal, cioè una cartolina realizzata a mano da arte terapeuti ed artisti internazionali, con lo scopo di finanziare il mio progetto di collaborazione con Art Refuge UK. Puoi vedere tutte le cartoline disponibili su questa gallery.Con la tua donazione puoi specificare quale postcard desideri ricevere, ed io farò il possibile per fartela avere! (Nel caso la cartolina da te scelta sia già stata 'inviata' te ne manderò un altra altrettanto bella!) WHY Art Refuge UK?Nel 2009 dopo un' esperienza di volontariato in India in una scuola per bambini disabili, ho preso la decisione di proseguire i miei studi dedicandomi all' Arte Terapia. Da quel giorno ho sempre sognato di tornare in Asia come arte terapeuta. Durante il Master in Art Psychotherapy presso la Goldsmith University of London, sono venuta a conoscenza del programma di Art Refuge, e condividendone gli ideali ho deciso di unirmi al loro progetto.Art Refuge UK è una ONG inglese che si occupa di dare un supporto emotivo attraverso l'arte terapia a bambini e giovani rifugiati Tibetani che arrivano in Nepal alla ricerca di un futuro migliore. Dopo il devastante sisma che ha colpito il Nepal nell' Aprile - Maggio 2015, Art Refuge UK chiede l’ausilio di Arte Terapeuti per rispondere alle richieste di aiuto delle autorità nepalesi e di organizzazioni internazionali.Nelle zone colpite dal sisma gruppi di volontari specializzati in Arte Terapia (registrati all’albo nazionale Inglese) lavorano in collaborazione con organizzazioni locali e internazionali , pianificando attività terapeutiche di gruppo, con lo scopo di ristabilire la normalità per le strade di Kathmandu.Nonostante lo scopo principale rimanga quello di dare un aiuto ai rifugiati Tibetani, l’associazione ha accolto la domanda di espansione di un network di educazione all’Arte Terapia rivolto a professionisti nel settore della sanità e dell’educazione.Art Refuge UK ha creato e co-facilita gruppi di supporto per la popolazione locale e gruppi di condivisione per gli operatori psico-sociali, artisti e insegnanti che stanno lottando per rispondere alle esigenze attuali create dalla situazione di emergenza causata dal sisma.Con la tua donazione potrai contribuire a diffondere l’importante ruolo dell’Arte Terapia in contesti di vulnerabilità, infanzia, e migrazione, e valorizzare il grande impegno di Art Refuge UK nei suoi progetti in Europa e all'estero. Per rimanere aggiornato sul progetto 'Send Your Postcard to Nepal' puoi seguirmi su www.sarasimon.it e su Facebook !Grazie di cuoreSara

story:
We created a unique clock collection made of old vinyl records, which consist of 4 Themes: Urban, Funny Zoo, Legends and Minimal.

It’s all about emotions:

  • Urban - the spirit of journeys; 
  • Funny Zoo - sweet memories about childhood;
  • Legends - power of charisma of outstanding people;
  • Minimal collection - the genius of simple things.

 Everybody can find something special for themselves.

Urban


Funny Zoo

Legends 

Minimal

Added new design


Eight special minimalistic dials were designed for you to choose the one you like best.

We use Quartz Mechanism with Silent Movement

  How The Funds Will Be Used

1. Wholesale purchase of quartz mechanisms.

2. Wholesale purchase of clock hands.

3. Mass production of dials.

4. Lease of a production facility for laser machining.

We need your help to bring this unique product to market. We gained huge and valuable experience from our previous successful  campaigns:

the T1 handmade LED lamp,

T2 Minimalistic Led Lamp and

Layering Master - Make Your Own Perfect Cocktails And More!

ABOUT US




Risks & Challenges

Our team is ready to get you the latest product by October 2015. We take pride in keeping our backers informed and will regularly post updates on our development progress. So back us and share with your friends!

Sincerely yours, Artzavod team.

story:
The Defenceless Container

Hello! I'm India Dickinson, I work as a freelance curator, and with my latest exhibition I hope to widen the discussion of environmental issues through an immersive and interactive installation. Having spent the last three years working with young contemporary artists and curating exhibitions, this will be the most exciting project to date.

By sponsoring this project, not only will you be assisting in creating one of the most inspiring art installations to ever hit the coast of Bembridge, but you'll also get some excellent rewards in return.
The project is in two parts:

1. An installation created by the artist collective BASK will take place in the World War II bunker on the beach. This installation involves filling the entire space with salt, and submerged within this salt will be a series of wooden sculptures. This immersive work represents the barren seascape it overlooks.

2. We have commissioned photographer Claudia Legge to create a series of underwater photographs, exhibited in a nearby basement gallery. These photographs will be for sale, the proceeds will be going to the Blue Marine Foundation to further develop their sustainable fishing program in the Isle of Wight.

We hope this project will not only leave a lasting impression on all those who see it, but also help to support the solent oyster development.

The Blue Marine Foundation aims to transplant ten million oysters to the Solent  by 2020 to revive what was once the biggest fishery of native oysters in Europe. BLUE is raising money to purchase the 10 million hatchery-reared juvenile oysters to re-seed oyster beds and increase the coverage of oysters in the Solent with the long-term aim of enabling the sustainable harvesting of oysters. This money raised will help to fund the five year plan for oyster re-introduction. 

http://www.bluemarinefoundation.com/2016/06/07/...

Where Your Money Will Be Spent:

We need your help to raise a total of £4144 to complete this project.

The money raised will firstly and most importantly be spent on the raw materials to make this artwork;

- 8 tonnes of salt to fill the entire bunker

- 2 tonnes of reclaimed oak to make five large wooden sculptures

- Speacialist printing of Claudia Legge's photographs

And any additional money raised will go to THE BLUE MARINE FOUNDATION.

Whatever support  you can offer is hugely appreciated: every contribution will help us get closer to developing this unique and important work. 

Your donations will not go unrecognised! We have arranged some superb gifts in exchange for our backers.


Why is this project important?

We need to stop ignoring this problem and stop assuming it will "all be all right in the end...."

This exhibition will not only highlight the important issues we face with unsustainable fishing but it also offers a positive local programme that people can support and help develop in the Solent. 

The nearby gallery space, where Legge's photographs will be exhibited, will also be hosting talks and film screenings related to overfishing. The Defenceless Container website will be filled with information that people can access with up to date facts and figures and information about the development of The Blue Marine Foundation's work on the Solent.


Challenges

The fundamental challenge is to make sure that this exhibition successfully communicates the issues to its audience and does raise awareness of overfishing. I want to present a localised solution that is accessible and easy to do!


Other ways you can help us....

- By sharing the project with friends on social media.

- Coming to visit the exhibition when it opens in July!

- And do get in contact if you have any questions.
