story:
Emotions & Commotions

Throughout October 2016 Berlin welcomes once again the largest German festival for photography, the 7th European Month of Photography. As Associated Partner of the EMOP Berlin the first edition of the Berlin Foto Biennale  - and 4th edition of the Biennial for Fine Art and Documentary Photography - will take place at the elegant Palazzo Italia, situated in the historic heart of Berlin, in a venue of 24,000 sq/mt. After Madrid, Buenos Aires and Malaga, Berlin was chosen as a new base to promote emerging talents and established artists from all over the world. Emotions and Commotions Across Cultures  will present 1230 photos by 446 contemporary artists from 41 countries of all continents – among them 65% women, who have been awarded in different editions of the Julia Margaret Cameron Award for Women Photographers .

The works represent a wide spectrum of styles ranging from documentary and wild life, to portrait and experimental photography. Recognizing a wide array of artistic expression across diverse cultures, the Biennial presents a contemporary overview of the different schools of thought emerging from the United States to China, from Australia to Turkey and from Senegal to Mexico.

The Biennial also contains selected works by Steve McCurry. His solo exhibition 'Retrospective' forms part of the Biennial as special invitee.

© Steve McCurry/Magnum Photos, 2007, Jodhpur, India 

The works on display here showcase emotions that can be tricky to understand within ourselves, since many of them increase the likelihood of chaos and provoke a state of confused and noisy disturbance. Such are the images of “Disorder,” the portfolio of Andrea Star Reeves, which shows the abuse in mental institutions in Indonesia. 

© Andrea Star Reese, from the Series Disorder, Indonesia

Such also are the images of Yusuke Suzuk chronicling the civil insurrection in Syria against a government that has transformed civilians into soldiers of the Syrian Free Army. Suzuki also puts us in a state of commotion by revealing the crisis facing immigrant families on the Island of Lesbos.

© Yusuke Suzuki, 2013, Aleppo, Syria

©  Yusuke Suzuki, 2015, Lesbos, Greece

A group of photographers composed by Vienne Rea, Quyen Pfeifer, Beth Burstein, Aliza Augustine, Hannah Kozak, and Sebastian Holzknecht disturb our senses by showing us subtle images of a past that it is still among us; they convince us that only our memory will help us avoid repeating the horrors of genocide.

© Sebastian Holzknecht, 2014, Jacob, KZ survivor.

And among these necessary testimonies, fine art emerges from the ashes of the past, with Jack Curran’s landscapes, Haydee Yordan and Lee Musgrave’s intriguing abstractions, Deb Young and Francisco Diaz’s depictions of the innocence of childhood  ritual, and Christofer Ruane’s black and white images that offer a surrealistic interpretation of the reality around us.

© Jack Curran

 

© Haydee Yordan

 

ç

© Lee Musgrave

© Deb Young & Francisco Diaz

 

© Beatrix Jourdan

It is impossible to mention here all of the many talented artists exhibiting in the Biennale and featured in the book object of this campaign. There are hundreds of photographers, most of them women selected for inclusion in several editions of the Julia Margaret Cameron Award for women photographers, that exhibit over 1,200 images on the ways this world, the streets, the people, the landscape, and the pure abstraction of the architectural forms impact our emotions and commotions.

Pre-order and get this book, and enjoy how photographers react to the emotions and commotions of this world according to their own countries and cultures, and try to get hold of the spirit of their visual legacies.

This Biennale is perhaps one of the largest photography exhibitions ever held in a single venue in Europe, and, indeed, the largest exhibition of women photographers. And we're proud  to introduce this book full of creative talents, and proud as well of having curated this unique exhibition with the curators Dr. Analy Werbin, Victoria Werbin, and Julio Hirsch-Hardy.

The selection of works has been made by the jurors, Jill Greenberg, Andréa Holzherr, Chema Madoz, Frank Meo, and Laura Noble.

Part of the revenue from artwork sales will be donated to Save the Children . The book the the Berlin Foto Biennale 2016 will be published by Kehrer Verlag. The book is ready to enter in production and to be delivered on October 5, 2016. Your support by pre-ordering the book is important to us because it will allow to do a state-of-the-art book published by one of the best art publishing house of Europe. Kehrer is one of the five publishers (and juror) of the European Publishers Book Award in Photography (formerly Leica Book Award).

Pre-ordering will allow us to make a reasonable edition in terms of volume and consequently have a reduced price of $45 for a hard cover book of 252 pages.

Your contribution (pre-order of the book) will help also our mission to promote emerging talents and to help others further their careers.

When you pre-order the book you may also get signed copies by the editor and curator Julio Hirsch-Hardy, and in other perks the book plus a signed limited edited print of The Hand, a several times awarded image by Julio Hirsch-Hardy. The available editions are: edition of 100 sized 12 x 9 inches; edition of 20 sized 24 x 18 inches, and edition of 5 sized 40 x 30 inches.

© Julio Hirsch-Hardy, 2008, The Hand, form the series Easter Processions.

The funds collected will help financing the publishing of the book, which has already been designed and waiting to enter into production.

As organizers of the Biennials and The Julia Margaret Cameron and Pollux Awards we have already published 15 books of photography, but all were on-demand at high prices and relatively low quality. This is the very first time that we decided to make an offset photography book of the highest quality. 

There are no risks involved in the making of the book. Even if we don't fulfill out funding target our firm commitment is to finance it by other means. But if you help us with your contributing pre-order, of course it will make our life much easier. If you can't contribute or don't want to order right now, help us promoting this campaign with your friends and colleagues. Thank you!

story:
Introduction

There are circumstances in our country and in our world that divide us. If we feel we must pick a side, whatever side we choose, let’s come together and have faith in the children and young adults in our communities and beyond.

The goal of the National Youth Art Movement Against Gun Violence is to help our youth move past an attitude of anger and apathy toward life and instead cultivate an attitude of purpose and persistence, one that gives them a reason to live and to respect life. Psychology tells us that acts of violence are often externalized manifestations of fear and anger, committed out of a sense of powerlessness and hopelessness: feelings to which many of us can surely relate. Let's take action to empower youth all across the country so that they no longer feel it necessary to take up guns or have to fear becoming victims of gun violence themselves.      

The Issue

Dangerous levels of gun violence permeate Chicago neighborhoods filled with long-time residents of families and children. Within the last 3 years, this decades long problem, has outdone itself in the number of lives it has taken or wounded.

In 2014, there were 461 homicides by gun and 2,619 wounded in gun shootings; in 2015, 509 homicides by gun  and 2,995 wounded in gun shootings; and in 2016, 796 homicides by gun and 3,665 wounded in gun shootings – that’s well over a 100% increase in gun violence. Of those numbers, 13-to-25 year olds account for more than 50% of the homicides and nearly 60% of those wounded. These are school-aged children and college-aged young adults who, instead of looking forward to a future, are terrified of what tomorrow will bring. Based on the numbers, it’s projected that a person is shot in the city roughly every 2 hours. Even if they aren't personally killed or crippled, they may have to deal with the fall out of a friend or family member who instead becomes a victim.

The effect of gun violence on youth is not exclusive to Chicago. Numerous cities in the U.S. have victim rates that are on par with some of the most violent countries in the world, according to a map published by the Atlantic Online in 2013.

In fact, in analyzing the data on gun violence and youth in the US, a Carnegie-Knight News21 investigation discovered that “for every U.S. soldier killed in Afghanistan during 11 years of war, at least 13 children were shot and killed in America.”

The Carnegie Knight News21 report further stated, "At least 28,000 children and teenagers were killed by guns over an 11-year period."

Although the majority of those affected are youth, the news reports don’t give the public the opportunity to understand the unique story and perspective of this vulnerable population. Instead, what we hear and see mostly are the numbers of victims, their ages and the reaction of parents and community leaders – the adults. But where is the voice of the youth, our children? Where can youth exercise their political power – their voice – to influence what happens to their peers, in their neighborhoods, in their schools, in their cities?

National Youth Arts Movement Against Gun Violence

The National Youth Art Movement Against Gun Violence (NYAM) seeks to reduce gun violence in America’s hardest hit cities by reshaping people’s relationship to their city, their neighbors, and the youth using art and activism as catalysts for civic engagement and leadership.

The project targets at-risk youth in urban areas and the adults in the larger city community where these youth reside in the hopes of developing mutually supportive behaviors and increased levels of self and social awareness in both these populations.

The project utilizes the What? So What? Now What? Learning Framework. The “What” is addressed by giving youth in schools and community groups the opportunity to reflect on the impact of gun violence in their lives and to share their unique perspective through visual artistic expression. The artwork becomes the “So what” that engages the broad community in developing a deeper awareness of the issue as these images, drawn by the victims (children and young adults), will be placed on buildings in numerous neighborhoods where residents work, live, and play. Performances by local youth will take place at designated art tour sites to be inclusive of other artistic talents and to further activate the work of the art tour. Community discussions about the art and performances will also be facilitated with residents to explore the “habits of mind” that perpetuate stereotypes and a lack of individual and community response to participate in problem-solving the issue and protecting the city’s youth population. The “Now what” will be discovered by all city residents who view the billboard murals as each piece, equipped with augmented reality overlays, will provide information on how to volunteer with organizations dedicated to overcoming the rise of violence in the city. Also, the “Now what” will be revealed to the youth artists when they participate in educational workshops and then use what they’ve learned to co-lead the development of art exhibits with their peers in other cities besieged by gun violence.  

*Kolb's Experiential Learning Cycle

The selected youth artists will take part in workshops to learn the history of visual activism, gain skills for creating augmented reality multimedia as an overlay to their 2D art, and deepen their knowledge of the psychology of art in creating imagery that influences behavior by motivating people to think more deeply about their communities. Then they will take what they’ve learned to cities like Baltimore to co-develop similar art exhibits annually. Thus, in the same way that charter schools scale their operations by adding a new grade a year, the project seeks to add a new city a year in order to galvanize a national youth movement and to provide these youth with educational and career opportunities in the arts and public service.

In Year 1 (2017), the project starts with an outdoor youth art exhibit in Chicago (launching during the Taste of Chicago and ending at the close of Lollapalooza) that expands out from Grant Park through the neighborhoods providing a broad and compelling visual understanding of the youth experience in the city. The outdoor art exhibit/tour will place the selected work of 35+ youth artists in Chicago (using wallscapes and augmented reality) on city buildings and a coordinated schedule of youth performance art will be offered at designated sites. In addition, a complementary web series will serve to broaden the awareness of the gun violence issue beyond Chicago and to further showcase the lives of the selected youth artists by documenting the work of the project.

What will my money support?

 

How We Measure Success

The National Youth Arts Movement Against Gun Violence will use the BYAEP framework to measure our success in helping youth to build creative problem-solving skills, empower a sense of identity and persistence, and to strengthen their connection to their communities in order to effect healing and awakening around this issue among all city residents.  The Boston Youth Arts Evaluation Project (BYAEP) brought together several youth arts organizations to collaboratively develop an evidence-based framework for assessing success with arts intervention programs seeking to add value to the lives of youth and their communities.

National Youth Art Movement Against Gun Violence is a sponsored project of Fractured Atlas, a nonprofit arts service organization. Contributions for the charitable purposes of National Youth Art Movement Against Gun Violence will be made payable to Fractured Atlas and are tax-deductible to the extent permitted by law.
story_txt: IntroductionThere are circumstances in our country and in our world that divide us. If we feel we must pick a side, whatever side we choose, let’s come together and have faith in the children and young adults in our communities and beyond.The goal of the National Youth Art Movement Against Gun Violence is to help our youth move past an attitude of anger and apathy toward life and instead cultivate an attitude of purpose and persistence, one that gives them a reason to live and to respect life. Psychology tells us that acts of violence are often externalized manifestations of fear and anger, committed out of a sense of powerlessness and hopelessness: feelings to which many of us can surely relate. Let's take action to empower youth all across the country so that they no longer feel it necessary to take up guns or have to fear becoming victims of gun violence themselves.      The IssueDangerous levels of gun violence permeate Chicago neighborhoods filled with long-time residents of families and children. Within the last 3 years, this decades long problem, has outdone itself in the number of lives it has taken or wounded.In 2014, there were 461 homicides by gun and 2,619 wounded in gun shootings; in 2015, 509 homicides by gun  and 2,995 wounded in gun shootings; and in 2016, 796 homicides by gun and 3,665 wounded in gun shootings – that’s well over a 100% increase in gun violence. Of those numbers, 13-to-25 year olds account for more than 50% of the homicides and nearly 60% of those wounded. These are school-aged children and college-aged young adults who, instead of looking forward to a future, are terrified of what tomorrow will bring. Based on the numbers, it’s projected that a person is shot in the city roughly every 2 hours. Even if they aren't personally killed or crippled, they may have to deal with the fall out of a friend or family member who instead becomes a victim.The effect of gun violence on youth is not exclusive to Chicago. Numerous cities in the U.S. have victim rates that are on par with some of the most violent countries in the world, according to a map published by the Atlantic Online in 2013.In fact, in analyzing the data on gun violence and youth in the US, a Carnegie-Knight News21 investigation discovered that “for every U.S. soldier killed in Afghanistan during 11 years of war, at least 13 children were shot and killed in America.”The Carnegie Knight News21 report further stated, "At least 28,000 children and teenagers were killed by guns over an 11-year period."Although the majority of those affected are youth, the news reports don’t give the public the opportunity to understand the unique story and perspective of this vulnerable population. Instead, what we hear and see mostly are the numbers of victims, their ages and the reaction of parents and community leaders – the adults. But where is the voice of the youth, our children? Where can youth exercise their political power – their voice – to influence what happens to their peers, in their neighborhoods, in their schools, in their cities?National Youth Arts Movement Against Gun ViolenceThe National Youth Art Movement Against Gun Violence (NYAM) seeks to reduce gun violence in America’s hardest hit cities by reshaping people’s relationship to their city, their neighbors, and the youth using art and activism as catalysts for civic engagement and leadership.The project targets at-risk youth in urban areas and the adults in the larger city community where these youth reside in the hopes of developing mutually supportive behaviors and increased levels of self and social awareness in both these populations.The project utilizes the What? So What? Now What? Learning Framework. The “What” is addressed by giving youth in schools and community groups the opportunity to reflect on the impact of gun violence in their lives and to share their unique perspective through visual artistic expression. The artwork becomes the “So what” that engages the broad community in developing a deeper awareness of the issue as these images, drawn by the victims (children and young adults), will be placed on buildings in numerous neighborhoods where residents work, live, and play. Performances by local youth will take place at designated art tour sites to be inclusive of other artistic talents and to further activate the work of the art tour. Community discussions about the art and performances will also be facilitated with residents to explore the “habits of mind” that perpetuate stereotypes and a lack of individual and community response to participate in problem-solving the issue and protecting the city’s youth population. The “Now what” will be discovered by all city residents who view the billboard murals as each piece, equipped with augmented reality overlays, will provide information on how to volunteer with organizations dedicated to overcoming the rise of violence in the city. Also, the “Now what” will be revealed to the youth artists when they participate in educational workshops and then use what they’ve learned to co-lead the development of art exhibits with their peers in other cities besieged by gun violence.  *Kolb's Experiential Learning CycleThe selected youth artists will take part in workshops to learn the history of visual activism, gain skills for creating augmented reality multimedia as an overlay to their 2D art, and deepen their knowledge of the psychology of art in creating imagery that influences behavior by motivating people to think more deeply about their communities. Then they will take what they’ve learned to cities like Baltimore to co-develop similar art exhibits annually. Thus, in the same way that charter schools scale their operations by adding a new grade a year, the project seeks to add a new city a year in order to galvanize a national youth movement and to provide these youth with educational and career opportunities in the arts and public service.In Year 1 (2017), the project starts with an outdoor youth art exhibit in Chicago (launching during the Taste of Chicago and ending at the close of Lollapalooza) that expands out from Grant Park through the neighborhoods providing a broad and compelling visual understanding of the youth experience in the city. The outdoor art exhibit/tour will place the selected work of 35+ youth artists in Chicago (using wallscapes and augmented reality) on city buildings and a coordinated schedule of youth performance art will be offered at designated sites. In addition, a complementary web series will serve to broaden the awareness of the gun violence issue beyond Chicago and to further showcase the lives of the selected youth artists by documenting the work of the project.What will my money support? How We Measure SuccessThe National Youth Arts Movement Against Gun Violence will use the BYAEP framework to measure our success in helping youth to build creative problem-solving skills, empower a sense of identity and persistence, and to strengthen their connection to their communities in order to effect healing and awakening around this issue among all city residents.  The Boston Youth Arts Evaluation Project (BYAEP) brought together several youth arts organizations to collaboratively develop an evidence-based framework for assessing success with arts intervention programs seeking to add value to the lives of youth and their communities.National Youth Art Movement Against Gun Violence is a sponsored project of Fractured Atlas, a nonprofit arts service organization. Contributions for the charitable purposes of National Youth Art Movement Against Gun Violence will be made payable to Fractured Atlas and are tax-deductible to the extent permitted by law.

story:
This Spring [INTERFACE] will go LIVE. JUNE 13th to 16th!!! Join us!!


ABOUT THE PROJECT

Welcome to [INTERFACE] Edmonton. [INTERFACE] was initiated by a duo of art advocates who have trained and worked locally and internationally in the arts sector. Mo Ossobleh draws on his connection to activist groups and training with art advocacy organizations both locally and internationally, and works as a visual artist himself. Justine Hartlieb-Power has developed the tools to execute exhibitions from inception to installation, drawing on her internship with the Smithsonian American Art Museum in Washington, DC, as well as training with local organizations and non-profits. They both have developed the tools to execute their exhibition with integrity and passion, and would like to invite you to be a part of their effort.

While the exhibition itself is the brainchild of Mo Ossobleh and Justine Hartlieb-Power, the project as a whole is comprised of many other contributing artists, musicians and creative minds. Mo and Justine currently live in Edmonton, and while they love their city, they recognize a distinct lack of independently run exhibitions. They therefore hope to create a space that not only challenges the way art is disseminated within their city, but also challenges the way Edmontonians interact with their communities and each other. Justine and Mo aim to be collaborative in both the execution of this project as well as in the event itself, as community is an essential part of their mandate.

By activating this project we seek to activate awareness on the systems of oppression that permeate our daily existence. In our effort in providing a safe space we must confront oppression collectively and it starts with recognizing that this land, Edmonton, sits on indigenous territory. Through this awareness we may confront oppression and symptoms of colonization more effectively and honestly. 

“We at [INTERFACE] believe that art and community are fundamental building blocks for any city, and we recognize that we cannot execute our aims without the help of the greater Edmonton community.”

http://interface-edmonton.tumblr.com/

Join us Edmonton!

Why us? Why [INTERFACE]?

Edmonton is a beautiful city, with depth and passion intrinsic to its core. We recognize this at [INTERFACE], and we hope to expand people’s perceptions of Edmonton through an exhibition that focuses on the various ways in which technology has impeded or enhanced our ability to interact with one another on a daily basis.

Community engagement is at the core of our mandate. We aim to express this through an exclusively Edmonton based roster of artists, all of whom recognize the artistic potential of this city and situate their practice within this city. We are working with the Alberta Public Interest and Research group, also known as APIRG (http://apirg.org/), to help create a safe, inclusive environment! Thanks APIRG!!!

[INTERFACE] will also host a speaker series during the exhibition. The [INTERFACE] forum is designed to create a dialogue that honors the voice of our community, acting as a bridge whereby multiple, seemingly disparate community sectors (art, politics, music and activism) can debate the merits of our Third Spaces. We are hopeful that the forum will generate a framework for sustained connections throughout our municipality. The community will be engaged through a visual art exhibition, open forum, and cross media performance (there’s live music!).

HOW CAN YOU SUPPORT [INTERFACE]?

[INTERFACE] is 100% self-initiated, self-directed, and self-funded. While our passion for art and community is insatiable, the fact that [INTERFACE] is both a self-directed and self-funded program necessitates the community’s support in order for the project to reach it’s full potential.

Recommended Donations at $10, equivalent to an entrance fee but YOU get to be a part of executing [INTERFACE] and providing FREE and ACCESSIBLE programming for the community.

There are many ways of supporting our project beyond donating funds: volunteering time, sharing our page on social media so as to expand the reach of our project, attending events, and just generally visiting arts institutions and spaces throughout the city.

WHERE WILL YOUR MONEY GO?

In our effort to keep the programs free and completely accessible to the public, we are asking our community to help initiate our project, either by donating their time or their funds to our campaign.

Funds raised through this platform will help to cover the rental of the exhibition and forum site,

Rental costs of Tangerine Fab

·  $800 for the 4 day project at $200/day (We know its high but we hope you’ll love the space as much as we do!!)

Material costs

·  $300 for equipment rentals, hardware, safety materials, and print marketing

Any gratuitous funds will be allocated with the artists, musicians and speakers invited to the project.


We think art and community are vital.

Join us.

story:
Help Us Tell Our Stories

Black Women’s Blueprint has organized a historic delegation to the United Nations Review of U.S. actions under the Convention on the Eradication of Racial Discrimination (CERD) to occur in Geneva, Switzerland.

This is a historical moment in U.S. Black Feminist history as we give our own account, testify and bear witness in voice and action; speak our narratives and center the lives of Black women and girls and their experiences with rape, beatings, shootings and other violation squarely within the context of “broader” racial justice concerns of our communities.

It is by telling our own life stories and by writing new narratives towards healing that we practice liberation, heal ourselves and shift the current paradigm—lifting the foot of oppression off our necks so we can be free.

       Here is Where We Need You.

Of the 6 of us headed to Geneva, only one received a scholarship. For one other sister artist and activist, Frances, the cost is not yet covered.

As survivors, we need each other and we need your support.

If you know a survivor who is family, a co-worker, a loved one, a daughter or son; if you are an advocate for survivors, or just care about what happens to our bodies, we ask you to consider making a contribution.

Give $10, $25, $30
Give anything you can to help make our load just a little lighter as we journey and bear witness to truth, justice, healing and reconciliation.

Why This Is So Important

_Black women deserve to be recognized and often there are very few of us represented at any table.

_We Go to the U.N. so we can stand for and with all the Black girls, the sisters left in back alleys, in heaps on their bedroom or living room floors.


_We go to the U.N for those left in building hallways, staircases, backroom parties and basement garages.
_We go for those who've been led to believe that they are alone;
We go for those no one believed and those no one helped.
_We go for those who have found their voice and those still trying to find it.
_We go and we speak for our ancestors, and those future generations yet to come.

For all those reasons, we ask you to give anything to support this historical trip to the U.N. in Geneva where we will represent women from our communities.

Help Make it Possible for All of Us to Be Represented.

  • $1,500 will help pay for Frances' air fare to Geneva.
  • $900 will help with lodging for Frances and another sister.
  • $500 will help with food for the 6 days we're there for Frances and another sister.
  • $600 will help with printing materials about Black women's issues, ground transport, and emergencies.
  • If we raise more than we ask here, your generosity will support an additional sister going to Geneva.

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Please tell your friends by emailing them this campaign page, post it on Facebook and Twitter and everywhere.
  • Write an Article or Blog about this by contacting Farah Tanis at ftanis@blueprintny.org
  • Talk about it. Go to www.myfreedomlounge.com to learn more about our Truth Commission.
  • Ask your friends, colleagues, family to give anything.
  • Use the Indiegogo share tools right here on this site!
Who Are We?

  • Black Women's Blueprint is the convener of the first Truth and Reconciliation Commission to focus on Black women and their experiences with Sexual Assault right here in the U.S. and this our chance to send a handful of women to the U.N. to speak of Black women’s experiences of sexual assault to the international community.
  • We're gathering and telling our stories and believe as the great Audre Lorde said, "Our speaking will permit others to speak, until laws are changed and lives are saved and the world is altered forever."
  • This first delegation of the Truth Commission includes: Farah Tanis,  Christina Jaus, Aishah Shahidah Simmons, Nikki Patin, Sherley Accime and Frances Nielah Bradley. 
    With Gratitude. - All of us at Black Women's Blueprint

story:
Our Story

Hey there! I'm Tamarakay, one of the founders of Dye with Dignity. My journey with the creation of art began during the 2011 burn (my first!) when I was conscripted into painting boobies at Barbie Death Camp for the Critical Tits bike ride. I'd never painted or thought I could, but ended up with a line of beautiful women wanting me to create beautiful designs on them! Back home after the burn there was a serious lack of people willing to disrobe for me, so I found silk. I dyed, painted, sewed, ripped to shreds and knit with, SILK. And the idea for Dye with Dignity was born. The next year we brought 300 scarves and 50 sarongs to the burn and helped that many people create their own work of art on Monday. Completely out of scarves our first day! It was exhilarating and exhausting. Tuesday while working my ice shift I saw several people in line with their silk scarves created at our camp wrapped around their faces as dust masks. My heart exploded. 


What We Need & What You Get

But let's face it. Silk is expensive. It's getting harder and harder for my husband and I to both afford the trip AND purchase the silk and dyes for our camp. That's where we need your help. Our camp mates and I have been busy these past few months creating gifts from our hands and hearts. We have painted, knit, sewed, embellished, and sculpted to reward you with unique from the heart gifts for your generous donations. Every penny raised in this campaign will be used to purchase silk, dyes, snow cone supplies, and wine. Mostly silk and dyes, cause that is our primary mission. Spread the love through the gift of creation and self expression!

The Impact

Our Website contains pictures from last year's dye event. The look on people's faces when they open up that silk and see what they created is the most amazing heart exploding gift I receive on the playa. I have received pictures and stories from burners who have gone back to their default lives and began creating art, and how being exposed to this art form at burning man was a turning point in their creative lives. Plus, let's face it, it's just a way cool thing to do in the desert!

Other Ways You Can Help

Thank you for helping us spread the word! Please consider sharing this campaign through your favorite social media and help us get the word out about what we do and why. 

Also, if you are at the burn and want to help out come on by! We always need more hands and hearts. Dye days include the Wheel of Shame, passing out umbrellas to those waiting in line, misting the line with cooling scented water, pouring juice and wine to thirsty passers by, making snow cones, stilt walkers, buskers, dye mixers, photographers, and table assistants. We have been told that standing in line at our camp was an adventure in and of itself! Dye With Dignity loves to spread the love!

story:
Short Summary

My name is Adam Gibson Bernath and I have a passion for pottery. I studied at the Alberta College of Art & Design and earned a Bachelor of Fine Arts degree in 2004. I have always been creatively active in many ways. Working in clay has captured my love and attention more than any other medium.

I am very pleased to have been accepted for the Wood and Soda Fire ceramic arts residency program at The Banff Centre for the Arts taking place from April 27 - May 22 2015.

This residency promises to be a very powerful and rewarding learning experience and I find that as the time approaches I can barely contain my excitement.

I feel there is tremendous value in having the blessing of completely focused immersion in ceramic studio practice. Perhaps the most exciting aspect is the chance to connect and share with many other artists who share the love for this kind of work, and it all takes place within a world class facility!

The program will be directed by two highly respected and experienced artists Robin Dupont and Dan Murphy. We will gather around the theme of atmospheric firing approaches which utilize the kiln and the spirit of the fire itself to produce striking and beautiful unique surfaces on the work. A process I have always been drawn to and very much enjoyed.

With your support I will be empowered with the means to dedicate this time to honing and strengthening my skills and knowledge as an artist, elevating the work that I make to new heights and stoking my creative fire! I have long felt that the highest aspiration we as people can hold is the desire and commitment to create beauty. Making fine pottery is one of the unique ways that I feel called to bring more beauty into this world and make it a better place for us all.

What We Need & What You Get

My goal is to raise $ 2,250 to cover the program fees ($1,600), supply costs($300), Indiegogo fees ($100-$200), and the cost of shipping the perks available ($200). I am very happy to be able to offer a little selection of my works that are all handmade and full of love. They also make wonderful gifts!

Any support  generated through this campaign is enormously appreciated and will be of profound help in advancing the pursuit of my artistic development. Thus strengthening the gift that I am able to give. For this I wish to express my deepest gratitude. This helps me to realize my dream and activate my purpose in life. 

The Impact

I feel this program will be breakthrough in many ways. The exposure to the insights of so many other creative souls, and the combined experience and perspectives of all participants will set the stage for massive inspiration and a deeply enriched creative life.

I had the great fortune of participating in a similar type of residency opportunity shortly after graduating school and it proved to be a very concentrated dose of inspirational amazement. It allowed me to learn things I would not have experienced during my formal studies and also to cultivate very special friendships and connections with other professionals, opening doors and nourishing inspiration. 

Risks & Challenges

The life of a potter is one with many unique, interesting and sometimes vexing challenges. I find the best way to meet with these challenges is to embrace them as part of the journey, knowing that the practice is all about showing up, experimenting, opening up to discovery, observing the results, absorbing and integrating the information and bringing the insights to future works. We cannot fail if we keep showing up with the willingness to learn.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you wish to spread the word of my campaign I am super grateful for your help. Please use the Indiegogo share tools!

Many many thanks to you all.

Short Summary
My name is Adam Gibson Bernath and I have a passion for pottery. I studied at the Alberta College of Art & Design and earned a Bachelor of Fine Arts degree in 2004. I have always been creatively active in many ways. Working in clay has captured my love and attention more than any other medium.
I am very pleased to have been accepted for the Wood and Soda Fire ceramic arts residency program at The Banff Centre for the Arts taking place from April 27 - May 22 2015.
This residency promises to be a very powerful and rewarding learning experience and I find that as the time approaches I can barely contain my excitement.
I feel there is tremendous value in having the blessing of completely focused immersion in ceramic studio practice. Perhaps the most exciting aspect is the chance to connect and share with many other artists who share the love for this kind of work, and it all takes place within a world class facility!
The program will be directed by two highly respected and experienced artists Robin Dupont and Dan Murphy. We will gather around the theme of atmospheric firing approaches which utilize the kiln and the spirit of the fire itself to produce striking and beautiful unique surfaces on the work. A process I have always been drawn to and very much enjoyed.
With your support I will be empowered with the means to dedicate this time to honing and strengthening my skills and knowledge as an artist, elevating the work that I make to new heights and stoking my creative fire! I have long felt that the highest aspiration we as people can hold is the desire and commitment to create beauty. Making fine pottery is one of the unique ways that I feel called to bring more beauty into this world and make it a better place for us all.   What We Need & What You Get
My goal is to raise $ 2,250 to cover the program fees ($1,600), supply costs($300), Indiegogo fees ($100-$200), and the cost of shipping the perks available ($200). I am very happy to be able to offer a little selection of my works that are all handmade and full of love. They also make wonderful gifts!
Any support  generated through this campaign is enormously appreciated and will be of profound help in advancing the pursuit of my artistic development. Thus strengthening the gift that I am able to give. For this I wish to express my deepest gratitude. This helps me to realize my dream and activate my purpose in life. 



The Impact
I feel this program will be breakthrough in many ways. The exposure to the insights of so many other creative souls, and the combined experience and perspectives of all participants will set the stage for massive inspiration and a deeply enriched creative life.
I had the great fortune of participating in a similar type of residency opportunity shortly after graduating school and it proved to be a very concentrated dose of inspirational amazement. It allowed me to learn things I would not have experienced during my formal studies and also to cultivate very special friendships and connections with other professionals, opening doors and nourishing inspiration. 
    Risks & Challenges
The life of a potter is one with many unique, interesting and sometimes vexing challenges. I find the best way to meet with these challenges is to embrace them as part of the journey, knowing that the practice is all about showing up, experimenting, opening up to discovery, observing the results, absorbing and integrating the information and bringing the insights to future works. We cannot fail if we keep showing up with the willingness to learn.
    Other Ways You Can Help If you wish to spread the word of my campaign I am super grateful for your help. Please use the Indiegogo share tools!
Many many thanks to you all.

story:
Hola, soy Lizeth León y este es mi proyecto Fachadas bogotanas.

Fachadas bogotanas integra la escritura y la ilustración para contar, a través de sus fachadas, las distintas formas de habitar Bogotá más allá de sus trayectos turísticos y los estereotipos que hay sobre ella.

Por eso, el 26 de enero de este año decidí que me dedicaría, por cuatro meses, a recorrer las veinte localidades de la ciudad, a dibujar a diario una fachada producto de esos recorridos, y a recoger historias y visiones de ciudad. Además, quise incluir en mi itinerario dos municipios, Soacha y Chía, como muestra del continuo proceso expansivo de Bogotá.


El libro 

La idea, desde el principio, fue hacer un libro con una selección de este material. Por eso, esta 'empresa fachada' no es solo mi proyecto, sino el de Fredy Ordóñez, amigo y editor. Con su ayuda, Fachadas bogotanas se convertirá en un libro y será el comienzo de Ediciones Milserifas, el proyecto de Fredy de crear una editorial de libros bonitos, cuidados, no costosos y hechos con mucho corazón, sin intermediarios entre los autores y sus lectores.

Fachadas bogotanas incluye una selección de 47 ilustraciones y pequeñas historias, además de siete textos con formas de leer a Bogotá a partir de la inagotable variedad de estilos de sus casas. Su formato será de 17x17, en tapa rústica, a cuatro tintas y con cerca de 160 páginas. El libro incluye, además, un mapa ilustrado de Bogotá.

Las cuentas de esta empresa fachada

Necesitamos recaudar 8.500 dólares (¿todoooesooo?) para hacer realidad el libro más bonito posible. Por eso, cada aporte estará destinado a pagar la impresión, diseño editorial, embalaje y distribución. Queremos hacer un libro de la mejor calidad, pero que no sea costoso; que ustedes lo puedan tener.

Las recompensas 

Para lograr construir esta casa entre todos, hemos diseñado 9 grupos de recompensas que incluyen no solo la opción de preordenar el libro a un precio especial de $15, sino de llevarse ediciones limitadas de otros objetos hechos a partir de las ilustraciones. 

Todas las recompensas son exclusivas de esta campaña. Si preordenas 5 libros o más con cualquiera de nuestros grupos, recibirás, además, 4 tarjetas en papel fotográfico con las miniaturas del mes a mes.

**Todos los grupos de recompensas incluyen gastos de envío a cualquier destino nacional. Si vives fuera de Colombia, la logística de envío la acordaremos luego para buscar la opción más segura y económica. Si tienes dudas, no dudes en escribir a ediciones@milserifas.com o lizeth.leon@cucharitadepalo.co

· Este proyecto está hecho con disciplina, corazón, y el trabajo colaborativo de muchos de ustedes ·

Todo aporte cuenta. También puedes contribuir difundiendo este proyecto. 

Cuando cumplamos la meta y logremos 'meterle plancha a esta casa', ¡cerramos la cuadra y hacemos fiesta!

story:
Hello! My name is Leonard Peng and I am a senior illustration student at the Maryland Institute College of Art. “Small Creatures Such Is We” is a collaborative gallery show featuring 15 talented MICA illustrators.

This show is a collection of miniature compositions that offer an intimate glimpse of a tiny world. Each image is 3" x 3" and focuses on small moments distilled from the vastness of human experience. From the extraordinary to the mundane, each image is a window into the realm of people. We created this show with the hopes that viewers would enter as giants among the illustrations, and would leave as small as the people in them.

We have created 750 of these 3x3 illustrations and they are just waiting to be printed and hung in a fantastic gallery space at MICA.  Your funding will help make this show a reality and allow you to enjoy it even if you do not live in the area.

    "For small creatures such as we the vastness is bearable only through love."

                                                                                                   -Carl Sagan

Here is a list of the contributing artists and links to their blogs/ portfolios

Xanthe Bouma        Joe Casanova         Shirley Chan

Alison George         Evyn  Fong             Erin Lux

Kate MacDonald     Nicole Mannino       Leonard Peng

Jennifer Phan         Mickey Quinn          Matt Rockefeller

Daniel Shaffer         Rachel Suggs         Boya Sun


What We Need

Our goal for this project is $500. This amount will cover the following:

Printing

  • Each illustrators artwork (750 pieces total)
  • Vinyl lettering
  • Promotional materials
  • Prizes for sponsors

Installation

  • Paint
  • Massive quantity of pins


What You'll Get

  • $10 – 2  signed, limited edition prints of the contributor’s choosing
  • $20 – 5 signed, limited edition prints of the contributor’s choosing
  • $50 – Accordion book containing 1 piece from each of the 15 artists, selected at random
  • $100 – A commissioned 3x3 from one of the shows founders – Leonard Peng, Matt Rockefeller, or Xanthe Bouma. Subject matter and artist can be requested by the contributor.

Perks are tiered, so if you contribute the highest amount you will receive the prizes for all subsequent amounts.

If goal is not reached, all funding will be used towards printing the artwork.


What Else Can I Do?

Any and all contributions will be greatly appreciated. If you can’t contribute, please let other people know about our show and help spread the word!!!!!

THANK YOU!

story:
WHO WE ARE

We are an international group of world-class Healing Arts teachers and practitioners dedicated to creating a more sustainable, compassionate and “life-serving” world.

We work in inspiring and empowering locations around the world with focus on community service. We offer trainings and retreats designed to support embodiment, quiet the mind and free the spirit in a field of holistic and preventative health care such as: Esalen® Massage certifications, wide range of bodywork, Holotropic™  breathwork, Yoga, SpiritDance, SoulSong, Gabrielle Roth's 5Rhythms™ dance, meditation, Neural Somatic Integration®, diet, permaculture, nutrition and more.

These movement forms provide a powerful catalyst for personal and collective transformation by raising awareness. The expanded perspective leads to a greater range of choice and assists us in going beyond our habitual patterns and limiting thoughts. The only requirements are curiosity, fascination, and permission to explore and experience new ways of moving, breathing and being.

While drawing students from many countries and backgrounds, we provide scholarships to local people in need. We teach them sustainable employment skills while fostering cross-cultural learning and appreciation that bridges racial, religious, economic and social differences. We offer a rich and varied integral learning environment devoted to cultivating deep change in self and society.

OUR MISSION

Our mission is to be of service by promoting personal and social transformation worldwide and to actualize those extraordinary capacities of “human potential”. that have been repressed by modern cultures We look beyond dogma to explore deeper spiritual possibilities, forge new understandings of self and society and pioneer new paths for change. We all have powerful capacities for evolving consciousness through self-inquiry, reflection, and relationship. When we take the time to realize and develop these capacities, we can transform our lives, communities, and the world.

WHAT IS THIS MONEY FOR

Our goal is to raise $100,000.00 to establish our new Healing Arts location in Croatia. The money will help purchase a 36 feet event Dome, 15 massage tables, 50 yoga mats, 50 pillows, 5 tables, 50 chairs, sound equipment and supplies such as sheets, oils, lotions and other basic supplies.

WHY CROATIA

With over a thousand islands, rivers, waterfalls and numerous National Parks, the atmosphere and culture of the Dalmatian coast of Croatia provides a beautiful natural environment and serves as a place of refuge, reverence, healing and contemplation honoring nature as our source and greatest teacher. This fits perfectly with our intention to immerse ourselves into moving meditation practices as a path toward healing, self-exploration and transformation. We believe in the deeply transformative power of this place.

We want to offer scholarships for those still traumatized by violence from the recent war – Croatian, Bosnian and Serbian woman and man and help them overcome fear and anger and promote healing and forgiveness.

WHY SHOULD I SUPPORT THIS

Human possibilities vastly exceed our imagination. Realization of the human potential transcends religious and scientific dogma. Mental, physical, emotional, spiritual, and social dimensions of our being are inextricably joined. Transformation of consciousness is the basis for transformation of the world; individually, collectively, and in social systems. All share the potential to love, learn, feel, and create.

By contributing to our program and helping fund this project, you will be personally invested in our project and perpetuating the healing arts.

The world needs those who believe in our common humanity, who understand and promote the development of all individuals and communities. We are extremely grateful for everyone supporting our mission and we hope to inspire other similar programs throughout the world.

Thank you for your interest in making a donation to our programs. It is through the generosity of friends like you that we can continue our mission of developing human potential.

Any funds that exceed our goal will help us begin our second season.

Thank you for believing in us and helping fund this project.

story:
My Story

Hi! It's Miranda. As many of you may know, I've been looking into art schools since I was nine years old. I love to create, mainly through the mediums of watercolor and oil paint. One particular school I've been looking at, the Milwaukee Institute of Art and Design (MIAD), offers a summer "Precollege" intensive program for high school students interested in pursuing a career in fine arts. MIAD offered me $1500 in scholarship money, based on merit. Unfortunately, they can't pay the fee for room and board, because they're renovating their dorms over the summer. I do work a part time job, and try to cover most of my expenses, but I have $600 left to cover. They extended their priority deadline for my decision to Thursday, June 12th. This summer camp, a three week intensive in figure drawing, would allow me to develop my portfolio and obtain a "Precollege" experience, before I head off to art school in 2015. It would be the opportunity of a lifetime!


Your Compensation

In order to raise $600 by the up and coming deadline, I am willing to take commissions (kids, portraits, families, pets, etc)! These will be completed by no later than the end of September. I will individually contact all the donors to about their artistic requests. (: 

  • $5-$20- Drawing 
  • $21-$50- Watercolor or drawing
  • Over $50- Oil, watercolor, or drawing 
  • Over $100- WHATEVER U WANT, REALLY 4REAL 

The Impact

The experience of attending a college level art camp will help me grow as an artist, expose me to the college experience, and help further develop my portfolio! (:

    Risks & Challenges

    I'm risky.

    I learned I've got one week as of today, but with your help, we can pull this off! (:

      Other Ways You Can Help

      If you choose not to donate, I'd appreciate if you circulated this link, I've just learned I've only got a week! (: 

      Thanks!

      If you'd like to check out MIAD, their website is www.miad.edu

story:
This campaign is now closed. You can now preorder bindings here; https://www.kickstarter.com/projects/1427643595/strewth-step-in-snowboard-bindings 

                Kickstarter - Preorders close 22nd September 2014




What is Strewth SLS?

The Strewth SLS is the natural evolution of the original "Step-In" snowboard bindings, combining the ease and speed of a step-in with the performance and feel of a traditional two strap binding.. 

For those who don't know, "step-in" snowboard bindings were popular in the mid 90's. The advantage of these bindings was you could just step in and ride, without having to stop and strap in before every run.

The original "step-ins" weren't very good for performance though, and used specialised stiff boots. Although they had great potential for improvement, these early models were never developed further and eventually all were discontinued.


Our Inspiration

A lot of riders loved the step-ins, and while they are not available on the market today we believe there is still a demand for a high quality, high performance, step-in binding.

The majority of snowboarders today swear that only traditional two strap bindings provide the best in feel & performance, and we agree! 

After trying all the current offerings on the market, including the “rear-entry” bindings such as Flow’s or Fastecs, we found there was nothing that met our desire for a high performance binding with the speed and ease of a step-in.

As nobody was making the bindings we wanted we realised we would have to do it ourselves, and set out to design the ultimate high performance step-in binding. After several years of designs, revisions and prototypes the end result is the Strewth SLS.


How Does It Work

The Strewth SLS provides step-in functionality in a traditional two strap binding by using your body weight to automatcally close and lock the binding.

As you place your boot in the binding and press down on the footbed, the ankle strap is automatically tightened, the Hi-Back returns to the closed position, and the binding is automatically locked.

All this happens in an instant allowing you to ride straight from the lift without stopping & often without even looking down.

The straps return to your preset tension every time. Set your straps once at the start of the day and don't touch them again. 

Due to the leverage created in the system, only a small amount of pressure is required on the baseplate to close and lock the binding, even with the tightest strap settings. This is especially useful in powder, and ensures easy entry anywhere on the mountain.

Exit is via a simple flick of the release lever.



Strewth Advantages

The ability to step into your bindings and ride away without bending down to tighten straps is the most obvious advantage of the Strewth SLS. This means more time riding, more powder, and no more sitting down to strap in. 

Riders of other speed entry systems, such as Flow, GNU/Fastech, or K2 Cinch will know that while these bindings offer some convenience when on flat hard packed snow, they can be extremely difficult to enter on steep slopes and deep snow. This is due to the clearance required for the opening hiback and the cable locking mechanism attached to the hiback. On steep slopes and deep snow these bindings become far more difficult to enter than traditional strap bindings, therefore losing the benefit of the speed entry system.

With the Strewth SLS we have removed the limitations of the existing "speed entry" systems, meaning you can step-in effortlessly anywhere on the mountain, even on the steepest slopes and deepest snow.

The Strewth SLS is the only binding providing a truly automatic "hands free" step-in entry system ! 

"A game changer in snowboard binding technology!"



Reliability and Quality

Reliability and quality has been a key focus for us from day one. 

Although it sounds complicated, the design has been kept simple with a minimum number of moving parts. We have also removed the majority of nuts and screws found in other bindings. Losing a screw has been the ruin of many a great day on the hill, and the best warranty in the world won't save you when you're stuck on top of a mountain. We use permanent fasteners to ensure you are not let down when it matters most.

Our bases are made of the highest grade glass infused nylons for maximum strength and minimum weight. 

Our heel-cups are made only from the strongest aircraft grade aluminum. No crappy plastic heel-cups here!

To ensure the best reliability and quality, we have been working closely with some of the best snowboard designers in the business and have partnered with one of the largest binding factories (who currently make bindings for many of the biggest brands) to ensure Strewth bindings are manufactured to the highest possible standards.  

We are 100% committed to building our bindings to perform day in day out, season after season! 

 



Where we're at now, and why we need your help.

We have built and tested our functional prototypes (seen in the video) and are now ready to move into the production design phase. This next phase involves working with the factories to make the final design modifications, and to build the molds and tools required to manufacture the bindings. The outcome of this phase will be the first production run of Strewth bindings for our Indiegogo backers.

Your contributions will help fund:

- Production tooling 
- Production prototyping and testing
- Initial Production Run

The cost of making the tools and molds needed for production is high, and our goal for this campaign is to help cover these costs, and to meet the minimum order numbers required for our first production run of Strewth  bindings.

Your contributions will help us fund these costs and get Strewth bindings into production and onto the mountains.

In reward for your help you will be among the first to be riding Strewth bindings, a whole year before everyone else! Be first to every powder stash next season, while everyone else is still strapping in!



What is the time table to production?

  • Prototype CAD updates & testing - January 2013
  • Factory Tool & Mould Making - February/March 2013
  • Production Samples - April / May 2013
  • Final On Snow Testing - June / July 2013
  • Manufacturing and Shipping - August / September 2013
  • First Orders Delivered - October  2013

Our first run bindings will be shipping in October and be on your doorstep ready and waiting for winter 2013. 

Rewards/Perks

In return for your support we are offering some great rewards.

We have great rewards like stickers, t-shirts, and hoodies.  But the best reward is getting your own bindings.  We've got an early bird special for our first 250 domestic and international backers of $185. These will also be the first bindings to ship, from our pre-production run.

If you miss out on the early bird offer you can still get your own set of bindings for only $195. These will be on your doorstep in October, ready for opening day of next season.

The retail price for these bindings will be $295, so you're saving at least $100.

As a backer you will be riding these bindings a year before they are available in stores. 

Every backer will become part of the development team. We'll be asking for your feedback on everything from form & function, to simple aesthetics. You will be part of shaping the bindings of the future.

You will get to come along on the development process with us via regular updates and see how a product like this is brought to market.

Get a back stage pass as we tour the factories, test production parts and trial final prototypes on the mountain

Price Comparison

For reference, below are the recommended retail prices for some of the more popular "speed entry" bindings on the market today;

Flow NX2 GT $369.99
Flow NX2 RS $349.99
Flow NX2 AT $299.99

K2 Cinch CTX $299.95

GNU (Fastech) Agro $309.95
GNU (Fastech) Mutant $289.95

As you can see, at $185 or $195 for our Indiegogo backers we are offering huge savings on the cost of comparitive bindings. 

Pledge now, and have the best bindings on mountain next season, at a rediculously cheap price!

About Us

Strewth Snowboards is a startup company based in Sydney Australia, purely focused on the advancement of snowboarding through innovative and high performance product design. 

Our initial product, the Strewth SLS binding, is in response to all those riders looking for a better binding system. When we started out snowboarding in the mid 90's, step-in bindings were just starting to explode onto the market, and having ridden step-ins for several years, especially the Switch X system, it was clear these held great potential, but more development was needed. 

Ultimately cost, compatability issues, weight, and problems with performance caused the demise of step-in bindings, and as the major snowboard companies chose to focus on traditional two strap bindings all step-in lines were eventually discontinued.

This began the search for a better binding and endless nights creating rough prototypes out of old binding parts, creating and discarding concepts, until finally perfecting what is now the Strewth SLS system.

With a solid concept ready for further development we searched out some of the best industrial designers and snowboard designers to help turn the idea into the Strewth SLS prototype you see today.

Ultimately the Strewth SLS is the result of one riders obsession over almost 10 years and the skill and generosity of several talented designers and snowboarders who have helped out along the way.

Help Spread the Word...

Let's use the power of social media to help get the word out. If you want to see these bindings in stores in the future, you have the power to make it happen now.

We need you to help us raise awareness and support by tweeting, blogging, Facebook posting, post in your favourite snowboard forums, email everyone in your contact list to help spread the word.

Just include this link: www.indiegogo.com/strewthsnowboard 

We're calling on all our fellow snowboarders who want to ride these bindings and have them in stores in the future to join together with us and make this a success. You can be part of launching a new brand and a new binding technology.

Use the share tools (at the top of the page under the main video) to help promote awareness of the project. 

Posting the campaign link www.indiegogo.com/strewthsnowboard on your Facebook page is probably the easiest and best way to get the word out.

Comps and Prizes

For some extra incentive we're running a couple of competitions with some extra rewards for the most active supporters;

1) The person who generates the most referrals for this campaign will win one free set of bindings. (make sure to use the share tools on this page)

2) The person to generate the most awareness in thier favourite snowboard forums or Facebook will also win one free set of bindings (Send us a link to your post, so we can track your progress)

International Shipping

Shipping within USA and Australia is free for all perk levels.

International backers please choose the International Backer perks, which include the $40 international shipping cost. 

International backers will be responsible for applicable tariffs and customs fees. Please check with your local customs office for likely charges.

Payment Options

PayPal is our preferred option for payment. You can use your credit card via PayPal even if you don't have a PayPal account. We prefer Paypal due to the extra tracking and easy administration available.

If PayPal is not available to you, there is also an option to pay directly via credit card.

International Patent Pending

The Strewth binding is currently Patent Pending. Provisional Patent Application number 2012905391.

FAQ

Below are some frequently asked questions. Feel free to contact us with any more questions you have and we will add them to the list below.

Can I use standard snowboard boots with Strewth bindings?

Yes. Strewth Bindings are just like any standard two-strap binding when 
riding. You can use any standard snowboard boot with your Strewth 
Bindings.

Are the bindings heavy?

No. The bindings are made from the same materials as most high-end 
snowboard bindings, ie; Glass infused nylons, and aircraft grade 
aluminium. Plus we have cored out our baseplates to remove any excess 
material. Strewth bindings are equivalent in weight to the lighter 
bindings on the market today.

Are the bindings affected by snow clogging or jamming?

No. Addressing the issue of snow clogging has been a core driver in the 
design from day one. We have insured there is no part of the binding 
affected by snow clogging. An amount of snow will always enter any 
binding, and we have allowed for this to ensure the binding is 
not affected by snow entering the binding.

Can I use the straps like a standard binding?

Yes. The binding has standard straps and ratchets. If you want to, you can use 
the straps and ratchets just like a normal binding, however we doubt you will ever want to.

I like my straps really tight. Will I need to use more force to enter or exit 
the bindings if I have my straps set super tight?

No. This is one of the key features of the system. Due to the leverage 
created in the strap system, no matter how tight your straps are set 
you will only need minimal pressure on the baseplate to lock the binding. 
This is especially useful in powder!

How does the performance & flex compare to other bindings on the market.

The binding performance is equal to any top-end binding available. The 
flex for this model is a stiffer flex, aimed more towards all mountain 
performance.

Where and when can I get a pair?

At the moment, this IndieGoGo campaign is the only place you can get them, 
and only up until February 28th. After that the bindings will be in stores for the 2014-15 season. Put your pledge in now and don't miss out!

  

 

 

 

What is Indiegogo.com?

Indiegogo.com is a fund raising platform for creative projects. Every day people with new ideas and products are creating campaigns and raising the funds needed to make thier dreams a reality.

This new type of funding is often referred to as "crowdfunding". There are several websites such as Indiegogo, Kickstarter, and Rockethub dedictaed to crowdfunding new and exciting projects.

The traditional methods of funding startup projects are loans provided by banks, or venture capitalists making large investments. These types of funding are simply not viable for many smaller projects and therefore crowdfunding is making these projects possible.

Thousands of new projects and products have been launched via this innovative new fund raising movement. A browse through the Indiegogo or Kickstarter websites will show the types of successes so far.

Why do people back projects?

People contribute to projects for many reasons, but usually it’s because they want to be involved in what the project is doing or because they want the perks that are part of the campaign. Backing a project is more than just giving someone money, it's supporting their dream to create something that they want to see exist in the world.

When you pledge your support for a project you are not "buying a product" but providing your support to help the project creators achieve thier goals. The reward for your support is the Perk you have nominated when making your contribution.

A successful project is a win/win for everyone involved. A realised dream for the project creator, and a reward (Perk) for the backer and satisfaction of being part of creating something new. The most succesful projects are those where the creator and backers share a common passion or interest and both have a desire to see this new idea become reality.

The Strewth project is for everyone who shares a passion for snowboarding. If you were an old step-in user and have longed for thier return, or are just a rider who wants a better binding system, now is your chance to have an impact. We need your support to help make this project a success and to take this exciting new binding technology onto mountains worldwide! Thank you.
story_txt:
This campaign is now closed. You can now preorder bindings here; https://www.kickstarter.com/projects/1427643595/strewth-step-in-snowboard-bindings                 Kickstarter - Preorders close 22nd September 2014
What is Strewth SLS?
The Strewth SLS is the natural evolution of the original "Step-In" snowboard bindings, combining the ease and speed of a step-in with the performance and feel of a traditional two strap binding.. 
For those who don't know, "step-in" snowboard bindings were popular in the mid 90's. The advantage of these bindings was you could just step in and ride, without having to stop and strap in before every run.
The original "step-ins" weren't very good for performance though, and used specialised stiff boots. Although they had great potential for improvement, these early models were never developed further and eventually all were discontinued.




Our Inspiration
A lot of riders loved the step-ins, and while they are not available on the market today we believe there is still a demand for a high quality, high performance, step-in binding.
The majority of snowboarders today swear that only traditional two strap bindings provide the best in feel & performance, and we agree! 
After trying all the current offerings on the market, including the “rear-entry” bindings such as Flow’s or Fastecs, we found there was nothing that met our desire for a high performance binding with the speed and ease of a step-in.
As nobody was making the bindings we wanted we realised we would have to do it ourselves, and set out to design the ultimate high performance step-in binding. After several years of designs, revisions and prototypes the end result is the Strewth SLS.

How Does It Work
The Strewth SLS provides step-in functionality in a traditional two strap binding by using your body weight to automatcally close and lock the binding.
As you place your boot in the binding and press down on the footbed, the ankle strap is automatically tightened, the Hi-Back returns to the closed position, and the binding is automatically locked.
All this happens in an instant allowing you to ride straight from the lift without stopping & often without even looking down.
The straps return to your preset tension every time. Set your straps once at the start of the day and don't touch them again. 
Due to the leverage created in the system, only a small amount of pressure is required on the baseplate to close and lock the binding, even with the tightest strap settings. This is especially useful in powder, and ensures easy entry anywhere on the mountain.
Exit is via a simple flick of the release lever.

Strewth Advantages
The ability to step into your bindings and ride away without bending down to tighten straps is the most obvious advantage of the Strewth SLS. This means more time riding, more powder, and no more sitting down to strap in. 
Riders of other speed entry systems, such as Flow, GNU/Fastech, or K2 Cinch will know that while these bindings offer some convenience when on flat hard packed snow, they can be extremely difficult to enter on steep slopes and deep snow. This is due to the clearance required for the opening hiback and the cable locking mechanism attached to the hiback. On steep slopes and deep snow these bindings become far more difficult to enter than traditional strap bindings, therefore losing the benefit of the speed entry system.
With the Strewth SLS we have removed the limitations of the existing "speed entry" systems, meaning you can step-in effortlessly anywhere on the mountain, even on the steepest slopes and deepest snow.
The Strewth SLS is the only binding providing a truly automatic "hands free" step-in entry system ! 
"A game changer in snowboard binding technology!"

Reliability and Quality
Reliability and quality has been a key focus for us from day one. 
Although it sounds complicated, the design has been kept simple with a minimum number of moving parts. We have also removed the majority of nuts and screws found in other bindings. Losing a screw has been the ruin of many a great day on the hill, and the best warranty in the world won't save you when you're stuck on top of a mountain. We use permanent fasteners to ensure you are not let down when it matters most.
Our bases are made of the highest grade glass infused nylons for maximum strength and minimum weight. 
Our heel-cups are made only from the strongest aircraft grade aluminum. No crappy plastic heel-cups here!
To ensure the best reliability and quality, we have been working closely with some of the best snowboard designers in the business and have partnered with one of the largest binding factories (who currently make bindings for many of the biggest brands) to ensure Strewth bindings are manufactured to the highest possible standards.  
We are 100% committed to building our bindings to perform day in day out, season after season! 
 

Where we're at now, and why we need your help.

We have built and tested our functional prototypes (seen in the video) and are now ready to move into the production design phase. This next phase involves working with the factories to make the final design modifications, and to build the molds and tools required to manufacture the bindings. The outcome of this phase will be the first production run of Strewth bindings for our Indiegogo backers.
Your contributions will help fund:
- Production tooling - Production prototyping and testing- Initial Production Run
The cost of making the tools and molds needed for production is high, and our goal for this campaign is to help cover these costs, and to meet the minimum order numbers required for our first production run of Strewth  bindings.
Your contributions will help us fund these costs and get Strewth bindings into production and onto the mountains.
In reward for your help you will be among the first to be riding Strewth bindings, a whole year before everyone else! Be first to every powder stash next season, while everyone else is still strapping in!

What is the time table to production?

Prototype CAD updates & testing - January 2013
Factory Tool & Mould Making - February/March 2013
Production Samples - April / May 2013
Final On Snow Testing - June / July 2013
Manufacturing and Shipping - August / September 2013
First Orders Delivered - October  2013

Our first run bindings will be shipping in October and be on your doorstep ready and waiting for winter 2013. 
Rewards/Perks

We have great rewards like stickers, t-shirts, and hoodies.  But the best reward is getting your own bindings.  We've got an early bird special for our first 250 domestic and international backers of $185. These will also be the first bindings to ship, from our pre-production run.

story:
Short Summary

Hello my name is Shania and I'm the brain child of Bella Designz. I've been drawing since I was a young girl. Often times being told I couldn't make a living off of my unique art. Janurary of this year I got hurt on my job and to this date I'm recovering from surgery. It was during my recovery after surgery that my passions for art began to pour from with in. I realize it will take some sacrificng to get my business going. We as a society have come a long way from paper, crayons, pens and colored pencils. Now everything has become digital. Since starting my digital work a few years back, I saw how easy it was to produce an artwork for a client and send the file to them by computer and the internet. Giving the client the power to print the artwork themselves or have it printed elsewhere.

What We Need

There is only so much I can do with my art using a mouse. With your help I'm trying to raise $5,000 to get my business going.

1-$2,000 for a Cintiq 21Ux-digital pen and tablet. Instead of pen and paper, its pen and tablet with the feel that I'm sketching or drawing.

2-$200 for Inkling-Digital sketch pen that while I'm on the go and I can't take Clintiq 21ux becuase its to big, I can take this along with a sketch book and draw and record until I'm able to upload the images to a computer.

3-$1,500 for a laptop. Right now my artwork is being done from a desktop. With the purchase of a laptop and the inkling, I can sketch and record on the go. Then when I'm in my studio I can upload to my Cintiq tablet and produce a work of art.

4-$1,300-Help get my website up and going.

The Impact

Your contribution will make my dreams come true of owning my own business. Doing something I love to do. Fear no longer rules me. I'm going full throttle and nothing can stop me. I realize that by contributing you are putting your faith in me. Those who contribute, your contribution will not go unnoticed, please take a look at the perks. No matter how much you donate, I will add a link to your website on mine.

Other Ways You Can Help

To those who are unable to contribute moneywise thats ok, just you stopping by and reading my campaign means just as much. Please spread the word. Thank you very much
