story:
Who are Print To The People?

We are Jo Stafford and Vicki Johnson, two people who are seriously serious about screen printing. So serious in fact that we started our own non profit social enterprise, called Print To The People, which aims to  promote printmaking to a wider audience.

We are raising funds to move our studio to a new building which will allow us to provide improved open access facilities and broaden our outreach, promoting accessible printmaking to a wider audience within the Eastern region.

We both graduated with creative degrees and with the help of Norwich Co-Op Arts founded Stew Print Rooms, the only open access textile and paper screen printing facility in the region. From here Print To the People was born and we have been running our activities from Stew Print Rooms for five years now.

We have over 150 members and provide affordable and accessible facilities to artists, designers, students, community groups and the public. We also run courses and workshops, provide educational services to schools and do public demonstrations at events.

Our activities have been growing steadily over the years and we have now outgrown our home at Stew so we are raising money to help fund a move to bigger premises.

We have our hearts set on a new building we have found in central Norwich which will allow us to expand our range of services to include a regular course programme and additional printmaking processes. The new space will also allow us to accommodate larger school and community groups which we currently can’t cater for at Stew.

How you can help

Moving is expensive and as a non profit organisation we are looking for help to raise money to make this move happen.

The new building needs a bit of renovation to make it suitable for our activities so we are looking to raise money to pay for paint, wood, plumbing and electrical contractors.

We also need to move all our lovely industrial equipment including the exposure unit, wash out booth, our two paper print beds, our textile table, our drying racks not to mention all our materials and storage units. All this will require hiring big vans and some muscle!  

Moving also involves employing solicitors and surveyors so the money will go towards those also.

We are hoping to raise £3000 to make all this happen.

What we will give you! 

We've gone all Cockney to convince you to give us some of your hard earned Bangers and Mash (cash)! We've created 4 special Cockney rhyming slang screen prints and postcards reflecting your financial contribution towards our move.


£5 ('Deep Sea Diver' Postcard)

£10 ('Cock and Hen' A3 Screen Print)


£25 ('Pony' A3 Screen Print)

£50 ('Bullseye' A3 Screen Print)

£100 (All 4 A3 Screen Prints or a years subscription to a Year in Print)

If you can give us a ton we will give you a ton of prints in return!

Choose between receiving all four of the screen prints at A3 in size

or

Subscribe to a 'Year in Print'

Receive 1 original print, once a month, every month for a whole year! Designed and printed by a different member of our studio each month, delivered to your door.

Other Ways You Can Help

We understand not everybody can help us financially.

If you can't (or even if you can!)

  • Please share our campaign!
  • If you hear of any equipment up for grabs that may be suitable for our studio let us know!                      

    Thanks for your support!
story_txt:
Who are Print To The People?
We are Jo Stafford and Vicki Johnson, two people who are seriously serious about screen printing. So serious in fact that we started our own non profit social enterprise, called Print To The People, which aims to  promote printmaking to a wider audience.
We are raising funds to move our studio to a 
new building which will allow us
to provide improved open access facilities and broaden our outreach, promoting
accessible printmaking to a wider audience within the Eastern region. 

We both graduated with creative degrees and with the help of Norwich Co-Op Arts founded Stew Print Rooms, the only open access textile and paper screen printing facility in the region. From here Print To the People was born and we have been running our activities from Stew Print Rooms for five years now. 
We have over 150 members and provide
affordable and accessible facilities to artists, designers, students, community
groups and the public. We also run courses and workshops, provide educational services to schools and do public demonstrations at events. 



Our activities have been
growing steadily over the years and we have now outgrown our home at Stew so we
are raising money to help fund a move to bigger premises.


We have our hearts set on a
new building we have found in central Norwich which will allow us to expand our
range of services to include a regular course programme and additional
printmaking processes. The new space will also allow us to accommodate larger
school and community groups which we currently can’t cater for at Stew.
How you can help 


Moving is expensive and as
a non profit organisation we are looking for help to raise money to make this
move happen.


The new building needs a bit
of renovation to make it suitable for our activities so we are looking to raise
money to pay for paint, wood, plumbing and electrical
contractors. 
We also need to move all our
lovely industrial equipment including the exposure unit, wash out booth, our
two paper print beds, our textile table, our drying racks not to mention all
our materials and storage units. All this will require hiring big vans and some
muscle!  
Moving also involves employing solicitors and surveyors so the money will go towards those also.
We are hoping to raise £3000 to make all this happen.

What we will give you! 
We've gone all Cockney to convince you to give us some of your hard earned Bangers and Mash (cash)! We've created 4 special Cockney rhyming slang screen prints and postcards reflecting your financial contribution towards our move.




£5 ('Deep Sea Diver' Postcard)


£10 ('Cock and Hen' A3 Screen Print)

£25 ('Pony' A3 Screen Print)



£50 ('Bullseye' A3 Screen Print)


£100 (All 4 A3 Screen Prints or a years subscription to a Year in Print)
If you can give us a ton we will give you a ton of prints in return! 
Choose between receiving all four of the screen prints at A3 in size
or
Subscribe to a 'Year in Print'Receive 1 original print, once a month, every month for a whole year! Designed and printed by a different member of our studio each month, delivered to your door.
 Other Ways You Can Help 
 We understand not everybody can help us financially. 
If you can't (or even if you can!)  Please share our campaign! If you hear of any equipment up for grabs that may be suitable for our studio let us know!                       Thanks for your support!

story:
Hello!

The goal of this fund is to collect enough proceeds to start a Small Glass Melting Studio for public to learn and enjoy creating their own tiny melted glass figures.

(For each help, mom will be sending a pack of tiny figures and a melted key chain anywhere on Earth! :)

 

The Story

And there it is, my mom’s story; a personal curiosity evolving itself for the benefit of others.

It all started 5 years ago when my mom started attending glass melting workshops far away from home. It was just personal at that time but things have started to change when she finally created her small working place at home a year after and started sharing her tiny melted glass figures to her friends/neighbors/colleagues whoever she wanted to share. Right after that short course sessions started at our home to our friends’ sons/daughters (of course for free!). The chain started to get wider (even we got an offer from LA! as a New Year present), we started to think “Why not to start a small studio to share our knowledge and let everybody enjoy it?”.

We have one set of all required equipment for a great start but at least one additional will be required in the near future. All the funding will be used for plain work surface, glass rods, safety equipment, torch, mandrel, kiln, glass cutter, powder, running plier, a part of studio rent etc.

Thank you!

story:
The Color Exchange

The Color Exchange is an interactive, site-specific mural and performance installation that illustrates the importance of communication. We are thrilled to have been accepted as artist representatives at the Build Peace Conference in Nicosia, Cyprus (www.buildpeace.org). Artists Nadia Westcott and Solei will be completing this mural project there in April 2015. 

How does it work?

This piece of art invites the public to participate in the visual outcome of the mural through participating in a question and answer game with other passerby. In front of the mural, we will set up a table and two chairs. This recalls connotations of diplomacy and negotiation, but also family and domesticity. On the table will be displayed a deck of uniquely colored cards. Each card will contain one color and question, to be discussed between the two participants. We will invite participants (preferably strangers) to sit and each pick a card and then discuss. We will deliberately choose a question that are universal, encouraging people to look beyond the current conflict and focusing on our shared humanity. Here is a short list of questions we will include:

-Do you prefer music that makes you think or music that makes you dance?

-Garden or forest?

-First thing you thought about when you woke up today?

-Ocean or pool?

-Strangest dream you've ever had?

-Bridge or boat?

-Favorite meal: Now? / As a kid?

After the conversation is finished, we will combine the colors of the cards they chose to form a new color. This new color will symbolize a novel connection between two previously unconnected people.  We will then use that color to fill a new space in our mural design. The conversations and mural creation will be simultaneous, so that people will be able to see the mural take shape before their very eyes.  Our goal will be to have 50 conversations, which inspire 50 new colors to create the mural. In this way, participants are creating a mural through conversation.

The design will be inspired by a city map aesthetic. It will be original and abstract, but will intentionally remind people of city planning, maps and occupation of space. This will serve as the skeleton for the participants’ creation. The design will be broken up into 50 “sections”, and each section will be numbered so that the creation has an intentional direction of progress. Mimicking the organic growth of urban landscape, the image will progress from the inside, out. It will be an illustration of what we can create through conversation. We hope this will inspire people to value social acts and empower them to pursue them more often in everyday life.


This is an experience that will be unique to Nicosia, but we intend to share it with a larger audience through the use of time lapse video. We will document the entire process and use technology to share the creation on a global scale. 

What will we use the money for?

The Build Peace Conference has provided for our lodging and materials while we are there. The money raised in this campaign will go directly to our travel expenses (approximately $1,000 per person). We are donating our time and effort to this project because we are very passionate about the potential of The Color Exchange; we could see it many other places besides Nicosia! All additional funds will go towards bringing The Color Exchange to other communities around the world.

story:
(English message will follow)

Qui sommes-nous ?

Treize étudiant-e-s en Scénographie à l’École Supérieure  de Théâtre de l’Université du Québec à Montréal (UQAM). Treize étudiant-e-s qui plongent dans le défi que représente l’Expo Scéno. Treize passionnés du métier de scénographe qui souhaitent partager leur enthousiasme et les connaissances acquises dans le cadre de leur formation. 

L’Expo Scéno est réalisée en étroite collaboration avec l’École Supérieure  de Théâtre de l’Université du Québec à Montréal (UQAM). En effet, depuis deux ans, l’exposition est localisée dans l’Agora du Pavillon Judith-Jasmin. Cet emplacement est particulièrement intéressant étant donné qu'il est centralisé et permet de rejoindre un grand nombres de personnes qui y circulent régulièrement. Avec les années, l’exposition est devenue un événement attendu et supporté par l’UQAM. C’est donc avec une grande fierté que les étudiant-e-s de deuxième année en Scénographie plongent dans ce projet devenu tradition.  


L’événement : 

L’Expo Scéno est une exposition originale qui a comme ambition de répondre à des objectifs autant informatifs qu’esthétiques. En premier lieu, l’événement invite le spectateur à vivre une expérience sensorielle et à réfléchir sur les manifestations multiples de la scénographie. En deuxième lieu, les concepteurs de l’exposition veulent susciter une réflexion sur l’organisation spatiale et la composition d’un univers créé par le son, l’éclairage, les costumes ainsi que le décor. Par l’intermédiaire de structures conceptualisées par les étudiant-e-s en deuxième année du profil Scénographie, l’objectif principal reste le même depuis 14 ans : informer sur le métier de scénographe.

Quand ?

Installer dans l’Agora du pavillon Judith-Jasmin de l’UQAM du 9 au 13 mars 2015, l’exposition autoportante a pour but de créer un espace d’échange et de rencontre axé sur la culture et la créativité.

Comment ?

La construction de l’exposition est subventionnée, en partie, par l’École Supérieure  de Théâtre de l’Université du Québec à Montréal (UQAM) et le Service à la Vie Étudiante de l’UQAM. De plus, nous avons accès aux ressources de l’EST tel que l’atelier de décor et le soutien des professeur-e-s. Nous espérons obtenir votre aide financière ainsi que la collaboration  de commandites et de dons pour réussir à mettre sur pied cette exposition. Comme l’exposition est une initiative des étudiant-e-s du profil Scénographie, nous comptons sur la coopération des différents comités de l’UQAM afin de rendre cet événement attrayant. 

------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Who we are?

We are a group of thirteen scenography students from the Advanced Theatre Program of the University of Quebec in Montreal (UQAM) that have undertaken the challenge of hosting the traditional ExpoSceno event. We are passionate and aspiring professionals, studying Scenography, and would love to put into practice our learnings, skill and overall knowledge in an exposition to the public.


The Event

ExpoSceno has been executed in strict collaboration with the Advanced Theatre Program of UQAM. For the last two years, the exposition was held in the agora of the Judith Jasmin Pavilion. This key location is centralized in a busy square which allows us to reach out to a larger public. Over the years, Exposceno has become a much anticipated event by our faculty and is fully supported by the university. It is, therefore, with great pride that we, the second year scenography students, undertake this traditional challenge.

ExpoSceno is an original exposition whose purpose is to break down the foundations of our craft in an easy to understand way. The goal is to inform the audience of what Scenography entails in an innovative and immersive environment. The display invites the viewers to truly experience a sensory journey of dissecting a universe into sounds, lighting, costumes and decor. The physical display allows our viewers to see each of these elements in a compartmentalized way and come to their own conclusions on their melding.

When Is it?

You can find us in the agora of the Judith Jasmin Pavilion of UQAM from March 9th to 13th, 2015.

What We Need

In order to realize this project at the scale we are aspiring to, we are requesting the financial support of the various committees of UQAM. The project is partially funded by our faculty and we have the support of our professors however the donations we receive will help our team acquire the materials we need to provide a breathtaking experience.

story:
The Team 

China, Russia and South Africa unite ! We are a group of four MBA students at IESA International in Paris. Our collective strengths lie in contemporary art, cultural and luxury management. We believe that art makes the world a more interesting place, and strive to showcase artists we believe need to be seen !

 

The Project

Surrounding the infamous Nuit Blanche held in Paris each year, showcasing a wide array of artistic talent throughout the city, Light in the Dark will be running parallel to this exciting event adding an otherworldly dimension to the overall experience. 

As summer fades, and autumn descends upon the city of light, we invite you to explore and experience the intricacies of immersing yourself within the dust of time.  

 

The Artist

Shen Linghao is an emerging global talent with a very unique take on digital photography. By printing his photographs using a noctilucent printing process, and by shining ultraviolet flashlights on to the images, they are further brought to life. It is almost as if the viewer is part of the creation of the image itself, creating a sense of connection. He has achieved international status having been exhibited at numerous locations across Asia and the US, we are proud to introduce him to the European market with his first solo, Light in the Dark: Dust of Time.

 

Budget Breakdown 

As you ask yourself, where is it all going ? Let us assure you that your contributions mean the world to us, and it will help us cover the following costs in order to bring forward a unique experience:

The Venue

After a lengthy search to find the right spot for our artist to be seen, we finally found a space situated in the heart of Le Marais, gallery district of Paris. The gallery opens up to a courtyard where we have a few surprises in store running throughout the entire show ! We welcome you with open arms to take part in this once in a lifetime experience.

Ways You Can Help

Just one more thing... We would love for you to spread the word of this exciting project via your networks, and don't forget to share our page ! 

Your encouragement and support is our motivation and reward. Having you with us will constitute the most significant step in this journey towards achieving our cherished goal of introducing young and talented Chinese artist, Shen Linghao, to the contemporary art scene in Paris. 
Let the success of this project become a stepping stone for many more talents who have yet to be seen and known by the world.

story:
Since 2010 the Annual General Karaoke has attracted the brightest and best artists from across Scotland and beyond, all devising, directing and editing their own karaoke videos, which are then performed on the night for an array of glittering prizes. It’s a karaoke night where the videos are made especially for the event. It’s a karaoke video competition! We’re delighted to announce that this year the AGK will be part of the 2013 NEoN festival. Past AGKs have included dancing milk cartons, fake blood, stripping, screaming, floor rolling, drinking, smashed keyboards, women with moustaches, skeletons and of course some lovely singing too!


Who are Yuck ’n Yum? We are a not for profit constituted group with a history in art zines and hosting events. We promote and distribute art outside the gallery setting.


For the last few months tremendously talented videomakers from all over Scotland and further afield have been sweating over their AGK videos. The deadline is fast approaching, and on November 9th we hope to deliver the best AGK yet… but we need your help.


Despite tremendous support from our volunteers NEoN and the HMC, pulling off our amazing AGK nights is always an expensive enterprise. PA hire, documentation, screen building, prizes, printing and technical equipment all adds up.


If you enjoy or have enjoyed any of our free events, including the last three AGKs or free zines over the last few years, and think “I can spare £5 to help these guys improve upon the already amazing AGK” then please do. Anything you can afford would be brilliant. Don’t underestimate that help, it would be tremendous! If we can find two hundred people who are willing to give us £5 then we are well on our way.


If you can’t give us anything then please just share this page with your friends and family and please please spread the word. And don't forget to 'like' our Yuck ‘n Yum Facebook page.


This year’s AGK promises more karaoke videos made especially for the event, and more moving, unique and downright strange performances! For those who have not made a karaoke video and are too shy to sing, this is your chance to be part of one of the most talked about events in Dundee’s creative calendar.

story:
Short Summary

My name is Ruben Murguia, I'm the director of a new organization (we're working on becoming a non-profit) called Siervos Por Amor (Servants For Love). We have a passion for transformation, starting with our native city of Juarez, Mexico. However we're focusing our aim higher to change the world through acts of love. Our goal is to bring hope to where there is none, happiness to where there is only sorrow and bringing a smile to the face of a child that has lost all hope of a future, at least a bright one that is. 

We are looking for $100,000 dollars so that we can fully start operating all the areas in the ministry plus a couple of projects that will impact directly at the very least 5,000 people in the first year alone.

We are doing this because we know that in order to bring transformation to a city, it's important to act with the characteristics of Christ at all times. This will allow us to positively impact and change many lives through our everyday actions.

With the donations, our first priority is to jumpstart a couple of business ideas so that we can start generating our own income for the years to come. After that we'll be looking to fully fund at least two children festivals for 1,000 children each. These festivals will be set around Christmas time so we'll be looking at introducing the children tu the true meaning of Christmas through games, companionship, and skits that will speak to their hearts. Included in the money set aside for the festivals, is 6 months of follow up for 100 children that have been affected because of the violence that once was here. We'll be helping them with school supplies, food for their families once a month and a psychologist if necessary. 

After all of this has been met, we'll direct whatever money is left towards two goals. The first goal is to rent offices for Siervos Por Amor for one yearas well as focus on generating salaries for at least 4 of the main people in this ministry. The second goal focuses towards the revitalization of one public park in the city through painting and maintenance, which would include organizing a weekly cleanup service. 

All of this without forgetting about giving our offerings at the 11 churches that are now represented in the ministry.

What We Need & What You Get

$35,000 OF THE FUNDS ARE GOING TOWARDS HELPING THE CHILDREN THROUGH THE FESTIVALS AND FOR THE PARK MAINTENANCE

$27,000 IS GOING DIRECTLY TOWARDS BUSINESS STARTUPS FOR THE MNISTRY TO GENERATE ITS OWN MONEY

$28,000 GOES TOWARDS OFFICE RENT AND STAFF PAY.

10% FOR OFFERINGS

AND WHATEVER IS LEFT WILL BE USED FOR MORE PROJECTS THAT WE HAVE IN MIND.


If we don't reach our goal of $100,000 we'll start with whatever we can in the following order.

1.- Offerings
2.- Business startup
3.- Festivals
4.- Office and staff salaries
5.- Park maintenance

The Impact

The full impact is something that is priceless... It fully means that you're helping a ministry to do its job at reaching the lost in all the ways that are possible and opening the possibility in their hearts to tranform their lifes so that they can become beacons of hope, happines, and of God's love for the world. 

Included in all the perks ONLY if you specifically ask for it, we can send you the statements once a month about how we are using the money that we recieved. We want to make it as clear as possible that we are using the money as we said we would and hoping that this will generate more trust towards us and open doors a little more towards future campaigns if they are necessary.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you don't have money,  its no problem, YOU CAN STILL MAKE A DIFFERENCE AND HELP US!!

You can help us by sharing this page with you friends and family through facebook and/or email! That would be a huge help and it really doesn't matter how far around the world this spreads out, the more the merrier!

You can use the indiegogo share tools at the bottom of this page.
story_txt:
Short Summary
My name is Ruben Murguia, I'm the director of a new organization (we're working on becoming a non-profit) called Siervos Por Amor (Servants For Love). We have a passion for transformation, starting with our native city of Juarez, Mexico. However we're focusing our aim higher to change the world through acts of love. Our goal is to bring hope to where there is none, happiness to where there is only sorrow and bringing a smile to the face of a child that has lost all hope of a future, at least a bright one that is. 
We are looking for $100,000 dollars so that we can fully start operating all the areas in the ministry plus a couple of projects that will impact directly at the very least 5,000 people in the first year alone. We are doing this because we know that in order to bring transformation to a city, it's important to act with the characteristics of Christ at all times. This will allow us to positively impact and change many lives through our everyday actions.
With the donations, our first priority is to jumpstart a couple of business ideas so that we can start generating our own income for the years to come. After that we'll be looking to fully fund at least two children festivals for 1,000 children each. These festivals will be set around Christmas time so we'll be looking at introducing the children tu the true meaning of Christmas through games, companionship, and skits that will speak to their hearts. Included in the money set aside for the festivals, is 6 months of follow up for 100 children that have been affected because of the violence that once was here. We'll be helping them with school supplies, food for their families once a month and a psychologist if necessary. After all of this has been met, we'll direct whatever money is left towards two goals. The first goal is to rent offices for Siervos Por Amor for one yearas well as focus on generating salaries for at least 4 of the main people in this ministry. The second goal focuses towards the revitalization of one public park in the city through painting and maintenance, which would include organizing a weekly cleanup service. All of this without forgetting about giving our offerings at the 11 churches that are now represented in the ministry.

The Impact
The full impact is something that is priceless... It fully means that you're helping a ministry to do its job at reaching the lost in all the ways that are possible and opening the possibility in their hearts to tranform their lifes so that they can become beacons of hope, happines, and of God's love for the world. 
Included in all the perks ONLY if you specifically ask for it, we can send you the statements once a month about how we are using the money that we recieved. We want to make it as clear as possible that we are using the money as we said we would and hoping that this will generate more trust towards us and open doors a little more towards future campaigns if they are necessary.


Other Ways You Can Help
If you don't have money,  its no problem, YOU CAN STILL MAKE A DIFFERENCE AND HELP US!! You can help us by sharing this page with you friends and family through facebook and/or email! That would be a huge help and it really doesn't matter how far around the world this spreads out, the more the merrier!
You can use the indiegogo share tools at the bottom of this page.

story:
1. WHAT IS CAPOEIRA?

Capoeira is an Afro-Brazilian form of martial art/dance engaged in at clubs, schools and on the streets. A sport involving intense physical training, it incorporates music, dance and combative movements, fascinating in beauty and form. The game takes place in a roda (circle) formed by the students and involves two players who try to outwit each other through a physical dialog using a combination of kicks, takedowns, escapes and acrobatics, which are wonderfully fluid in appearance.

There are no hard and fast rules, yet capoeira does follow a characteristic protocol, along with having its own music – perhaps its most enduring feature. Through learning the songs of capoeira, students also gain access to learning a new language (Portuguese), instruments and Brazilian history. By binding together these elements of sport, music, dance, martial skills and camaraderie, capoeira comprises one of the richest manifestations of Brazilian culture.

1.1 WHO ARE WE?

We are the Westchester County chapter of the capoeira group Cordão de Ouro. Professor Cabeção, who has been practicing for 16 years under the supervision of Mestre Esquilo, has been offering classes in Tarrytown and Ossining since January 2012. This will be the second batizado for Professor Cabeção’s group in the area.

2. WHAT IS A BATIZADO?

A capoeira batizado is an event that brings capoeiristas from all over the world together with other athletes, fans of sports, art and music, along with friends and family of the local group members to participate in and enjoy workshops, performances and celebrations organized with the intention of promoting capoeira, as well as all elements of music, culture, health, dance and the arts in the area. The purpose of the batizado ceremony is to deliver the first cord (the equivalent of a belt in other martial arts) to the students of the local group. In order to perform this ceremony, the presence of a capoeira Mestre is essential. Numerous capoeira professionals are called to assist in the organization of the ceremony (to play instruments, sing, graduate the students, etc.). The students are involved not only in promoting capoeira and demonstrating what they have learned over the course of their training for the capoeira community, friends and family, but also in elevating the name and image of the city and surrounding areas through capoeira. We also see this event as an opportunity to stimulate activity in the area and bring residents more art, culture, entertainment, health, music and everything associated with capoeira. With each event we grow, both individually and as a group, and improve the quality of our own capoeira and the quality of our local capoeira group.

3. TENTATIVE EVENT SCHEDULE

Tentative Schedule:
Note: All workshops will be divided by level. People who have never trained Capoeira before are welcome and encouraged to attend - wear comfortable clothes!

Thursday October 24th
7:30 - 8:30pm Surprise Class ;)
Location: The Reformed Church of Tarrytown (2nd floor)
42 North Broadway, Tarrytown NY

Friday October 25th
6:30 - 8:30pm Workshops & Roda
Location: White Plains Presbyterian Church (entrance #2)

39 North Broadway, White Plains NY

Saturday October 26th
1:00 - 7:00pm Registration, Workshops (3), Open Rodas, Performance, Batizado & Troca de Cordoes
Location: The Performing Arts Center
735 Anderson Hill Road, Purchase NY

4. OBJECTIVE

We are promoting an event with our students in order to celebrate our work in the area and to bring capoeira practitioners, friends, family and the public to join us in celebration, to enjoy entertainment and culture, and to share our enthusiasm for our existence as a group. We intend to publicize our work related to capoeira, culture, education, and health, along with the work of others in the area who share these values. We are working to bring two people who are recognized and valued in the capoeira community for their importance and talent, in order to enhance the event and attract more practitioners and the community to come to learn more about capoeira, participate in the proposed activities, and ultimately to mobilize more people and to bring an exceptional quality to the information and activities to be presented at the event.

Please contact us if you would like more information regarding our proposal to bring Contra-Mestre Eurico. Eurico Vianna is working on a PhD in Sociology at Griffith University in Australia and has been a junior level master of capoeira since 2004. Throughout his career in capoeira and his academic studies he has given numerous lectures, written articles and a book, participated in documentaries and international projects involving the use of capoeira as a tool for social inclusion. He would like to come to help us with our event, and has offered to give lectures or workshops at other locations in the area to cover his travel expenses.

5. JUSTIFICATION

This event is essential in order to reward the efforts of the students who have been training and preparing to graduate, and through a great ceremony or event, to celebrate while bringing different activities such as capoeira to the area. The event will encourage others in the area with similar work and ideals to come together, and magnify the name and image of the city and locale through capoeira, thus allowing us to develop resources that will aid in our growth, to satisfy the public, and to always be able to bring entertainment, culture, art, health and quality to the area, and to be able to disseminate and develop projects here similar to various projects that already exist in Brazil.

6. SPONSORSHIP OPPORTUNITIES

There are numerous ways to become involved and show support for our event. Below is a list of our needs and estimated expenses your donation will be used for.

  $3,000 – travel expenses (flight, housing, food, etc.) for Mestres (Masters) and distinguished visitors.

  $1,000 – instructors’ fees for workshops ($200 per workshop, 5 workshops)

  $700 – for approximately 180 t-shirts (2 colors, front and back)

  $200 – marketing material (posters, flyers, signs) 

  $100 – other expenses (yarn to make the cords, water for participants at the event, etc.)

We are open to discussing any other arrangements (i.e. donating food, space, t-shirts, marketing material, etc.) that would assist in the organization of our event. Anyone who would be interested in setting up a table at the event to sell or advertise products/services to participants and event guests can contact us.

story:
Create a vision of inspiration and a legacy of creative energy.

I am Robert Woodbury. 

I am a professional sculptor, artist and caricaturist.  I am also president of the sculptors association of Alberta.    

Everything I am as an artist, I owe to my mother, Mary Woodbury. She motivated and guided me, chided and encouraged me to express myself. 

Young people know her for her Polly McDoodle series. The Invisible Polly McDoodle and The Intrepid Polly McDoodle were both "Our Choice" selections of the Canadian Children's Book Centre. She has been short listed for many awards.

Her other young adult books include:

Letting Go, 
Where in the World is Jenny Parker?
Brad's Universe 
A Gift for Johnny Know-It-All 
Jess and the Runaway Grandpa

Mary Woodbury helped found The Books Collective, a publishing house that gave many young authors their start.

Together with Luanne Armstrong and Peggy Graham, she launched the literary magazine Other Voices more than 25 years ago. Published twice a year.

Mary was a member of the founding Board of the Writers Guild of Alberta when it begain in 1979. It's membership today numbers in the hundreds. 

She helped found the local Edmonton chapter of the Canadian Society for Children's Authors, Illustrators, and Performers (CANSCAIP). Until her passing, she served on the board of YABS, the Young Alberta Book Society. 

Mary was honored with the designation Mistress of the Modern in 2012.

Mary passed away at the age of 77 on January 19, 2013.

As an important figure in the Edmonton and Alberta writing community, I want to dedicate a sculpture of a muse to her memory with a bronze plaque.  Any money not spent on the sculpture would go to the Mary Woodbury grant for emerging writers, to support voices that need to tell their stories.

story:
We are a new organization whose mission is to help veterans realize their dreams of working in the arts and we are incredibly excited about our first project; a series of plays written, created, and performed by real military veterans and those who are close to them.

ABOUT THE PROJECT:

Beyond the Deserts & Mountains is a compilation of plays that aims to bring to light the humanity behind the eyes of the men & women defending this country. There have been many stories told about the hardships of war but not many about the humanity of war. These stories shine a light on some of the issues that the men & women of the Armed Forces are faced with while protecting our freedom and are told through the voices of those who have experienced these situations.

The compilation includes three plays written by our Co-Founder and Iraq War veteran, Neath Williams, which tackle multiple issues present throughout military history including Post Traumatic Stress Disorder (PTSD), sexual harassment, and suicide. It also includes Deployed, a musical written by former Army veteran spouse and BMI Musical Theater Workshop alum, Natalie Lovejoy, about an infantry unit's deployment to Iraq as seen through the eyes of a young private.

In addition to the writers having military backgrounds, veterans will also be involved throughout the cast and creative team. A detailed description of the plays and those involved is included below.


OUR GOAL:

Our goal is to raise $5,000 in order to bring these new works to life in the Off-Off Broadway world of New York City. Your donations will go toward the performance space, advertisements, web development, programs, copying costs, costumes, props, & set construction. Without your help this will not be possible. Also, your donation is tax-deductible!

In addition to donating, PLEASE spread the word that there are veterans out there making art by sharing one of our pages online.

Thank you so much for truly supporting those who have served!!!



This will be the first of many productions to come in the future plus when you donate it's tax deductible!!!! In addition to donating we ask that you spread the word about our cause. Share one of our pages online or simply tell a friend there are veterans out there making art!

Discredited -  "A glimpse into the disturbing and complicated topic of sexual assault in the military." 

Director

Moshe Goodman is an actor, writer, and director with Love Creek productions and the Wednesday Repertory Company. Moshe's father is Petty Officer second class Steven Allan Goodman, a Vietnam veteran. Last year Moshe directed an evening of one act plays in honor of Veterans' day titled "Welcome Home" and is honored to be involved with this wonderful and extremely important organization and show.

Playwright - Neath Williams (see bio below)

Jungles of Us -  "A love story overshadowed and complicated by the return of Nicole’s war torn brother."

Director

Paul Markerts is the Artistic Director for Lust & Liberty. Previous company credits include Public Service by David Lawson, Bedtime Stories by Charles Mee and a devised piece entitled Everyday Music (all of whom Paul served as director). Other directing credits include Puppet Shakespeare's Romeo and Juliet and Helen is a Heterosexual by Le Wilhelm. He is an alumni of Marymount Manhattan College and the National Theatre Institute's Advance Director Program. Special thanks to Neath and the group for this wonderful oppurtunity!

Playwright - Neath Williams (see bio below)

Bedlam - "A conversation about military suicides from the perspective of the troops." 

Director

Melissa Farinelli is a directing graduate from The University of Northern Colorado and native Army Brat, due to her Corp of Engineers father and Army Nurse mother. She most recently directed To Buttzville and Beyond, written by Jeanne Chenault Porter, for the Strawberry Theater Festival. Other credits include The Misanthrope for Love Creek Productions and Himmelreich, written by Mark Rosati along with various one acts. She is also the resident Production Manager for Sink or Swim Rep and works as a freelance stage manager with City Show and other non profit companies.

Playwright - Neath Williams (see bio below)

Deployed - "The show follows a young, newlywed army private and his unit during their year-long deployment in Iraq and the subsequent battles they face when they return home."

Director

Celine Rosenthal is an NYU Tisch Alum & Founder of the Neela Theatre Project in Mumbai and currently an MFA Directing Candidate at the New School for Drama. Selected Credits: Director: Rose Pedals (NYMTF), The Post Office (Bank St), Hitgirls: The Musical (Manhattan Theatre Source), The Weird (Manhattan Theatre Source), Hapless Romance (Wings Theater). Producer: Seminar (John Golden), Leap of Faith* (St. James), The Spitfire Grill (The Sage), Turn of the Screw (Bank St). 

*Tony-nominated.

Playwright

Natalie Lovejoy is a composer/lyricist and native Texan whose work has been performed at The Duplex, The Laurie Beechman Theater, Raw Impression's 2006 Musical Theatre Marathon, Greenwich Music House, and the legendary Bluebird Café in Nashville, in addition to Musically Human Theater Production’s “Our Time: An Evening of Songs by the Next Generation of Broadway Songwriters” in 2011. She has a Master of Music in Composition from New York University and was a participant in the Johnny Mercer Foundation’s American Musical Theater Project and the BMI Lehman Engel Musical Theatre Workshop. Natalie was married to a soldier who deployed to Iraq in 2008 with the 101st Airborne Division and is still currently serving. www.natalielovejoymusic.com


SocArtVets:

Mission:

Society of Artistic Veterans seeks to enable military veterans toward careers in the arts and entertainment industry and create a community amongst industry professionals.

SocArtVets is a content creator that provides military veterans the opportunity to work on professional productions in film and theater and learn from industry experts who want to help veterans.  With a growing network based in New York City, SocArtVets helps produce both veteran and civilian-written content and partners with other military veteran and entertainment organizations to inform audiences about the creative abilities and valuable work ethic that military veterans have to offer as they seek to transition into the civilian workforce.

Neath Williams - Co-Founder

Neath is a Hospital Corpsman 2nd Class Petty Officer in the United States Navy Reserves (Sept '09-Current) He served on active duty from '99-'09. Neath did three combat tours in support of Operation Iraqi Freedom. (1) '03 Shock Trauma Platoon 10, (2 & 3) Navy Riverine Squadron One (NECC unit) '07, then again late '08-'09. He also worked as leading field corpsman, and brig corpsman at Marine Corps Officer Candidate School, Quantico,VA. 

Neath was born in southern Illinois, grew up in Houston, TX till age 11, then moved to Bowling Green, KY where he then joined the Navy after high school. He has a BA in Interdisciplinary Studies with focuses in theater arts, international studies, and writing for the stage from Marymount Manhattan College. Neath hopes to use his cumulative academic program and military experiences to create theater, film, and television with a political and social perspective.

Tyler La Marr - Co-Founder

Tyler served as a Sergeant in the Marine Corps from '04-'10 where he worked as an analyst. He served two tours in Iraq, from '06-'07 in Fallujah and '07-'08 in Fallujah & Ramadi, with 2nd Radio Battalion based out of Camp Lejeune, NC. Tyler was born in Washington State and spent most of his life there until he joined the Marines after high school. He began pursuing his acting career in 2009 while living in Baltimore, MD. Tyler is currently attending Marymount Manhattan College in NYC pursuing his BFA in Acting and will be graduating May '14. www.TylerLaMarr.com


Matthew Thomas Burda - Director of Theater Development

Matthew served 6 years in the Air Force Security Forces, and was stationed at Lakenheath Airbase, UK and Altus AFB, Oklahoma.  He deployed to Iraq and Afghanistan, where he earned two Army Achievement Medals. He spent his final 18 months on active duty working as a Combat Skills Instructor. MTB is now an actor living in Brooklyn.  He has been involved in a wide range of theatrical and film projects. Recent NYC stage performances include Moe Axelrod in Awake and Sing! (LCP) Cecil Graham in Lady Windemere’s Fan (EAS) and as the title lead in Anatol (City Show). 


For more information about SocArtVets please visit www.SocArtVets.com 

Like Us on Facebook http://www.facebook.com/SocArtVets 

Follow Us on Twitter http://twitter.com/SocArtVets

Director






Moshe Goodman is an actor, writer, and director with Love Creek productions and the Wednesday Repertory Company. Moshe's father is Petty Officer second class Steven Allan Goodman, a Vietnam veteran. Last year Moshe directed an evening of one act plays in honor of Veterans' day titled "Welcome Home" and is honored to be involved with this wonderful and extremely important organization and show.
Playwright - Neath Williams (see bio below)
Jungles of Us -  "A love story overshadowed and complicated by the
return of Nicole’s war torn brother."
Director




Paul Markerts is the Artistic Director for Lust & Liberty. Previous company credits include Public Service by David Lawson, Bedtime Stories by Charles Mee and a devised piece entitled Everyday Music (all of whom Paul served as director). Other directing credits include Puppet Shakespeare's Romeo and Juliet and Helen is a Heterosexual by Le Wilhelm. He is an alumni of Marymount Manhattan College and the National Theatre Institute's Advance Director Program. Special thanks to Neath and the group for this wonderful oppurtunity!
Playwright - Neath Williams (see bio below)
Bedlam - "A conversation about military suicides from the perspective of the troops." 

Director



Melissa Farinelli is a directing graduate from The University of Northern Colorado and native Army Brat, due to her Corp of Engineers father and Army Nurse mother. She most recently directed To Buttzville and Beyond, written by Jeanne Chenault Porter, for the Strawberry Theater Festival. Other credits include The Misanthrope for Love Creek Productions and Himmelreich, written by Mark Rosati along with various one acts. She is also the resident Production Manager for Sink or Swim Rep and works as a freelance stage manager with City Show and other non profit companies.
Playwright - Neath Williams (see bio below)
Deployed - "The show follows a young, newlywed army private and his unit during their year-long deployment in Iraq and the subsequent battles they face when they return home."

Playwright











Natalie Lovejoy is a composer/lyricist and native Texan whose work has been performed at The Duplex, The Laurie Beechman Theater, Raw Impression's 2006 Musical Theatre Marathon, Greenwich Music House, and the legendary Bluebird Café in Nashville, in addition to Musically Human Theater Production’s “Our Time: An Evening of Songs by the Next Generation of Broadway Songwriters” in 2011. She has a Master of Music in Composition from New York University and was a participant in the Johnny Mercer Foundation’s American Musical Theater Project and the BMI Lehman Engel Musical Theatre Workshop. Natalie was married to a soldier who deployed to Iraq in 2008 with the 101st Airborne Division and is still currently serving. www.natalielovejoymusic.com

SocArtVets:
Mission:

Society of Artistic Veterans seeks to enable military veterans toward careers in the arts and entertainment industry and create a community amongst industry professionals.
SocArtVets is a content creator that provides military veterans the opportunity to work on professional productions in film and theater and learn from industry experts who want to help veterans.  With a growing network based in New York City, SocArtVets helps produce both veteran and civilian-written content and partners with other military veteran and entertainment organizations to inform audiences about the creative abilities and valuable work ethic that military veterans have to offer as they seek to transition into the civilian workforce.


Neath Williams - Co-Founder


Neath is a Hospital Corpsman 2nd Class Petty Officer in the United States Navy Reserves (Sept '09-Current) He served on active duty from '99-'09. Neath did three combat tours in support of Operation Iraqi Freedom. (1) '03 Shock Trauma Platoon 10, (2 & 3) Navy Riverine Squadron One (NECC unit) '07, then again late '08-'09. He also worked as leading field corpsman, and brig corpsman at Marine Corps Officer Candidate School, Quantico,VA. 
Neath was born in southern Illinois, grew up in Houston, TX till age 11, then moved to Bowling Green, KY where he then joined the Navy after high school. He has a BA in Interdisciplinary Studies with focuses in theater arts, international studies, and writing for the stage from Marymount Manhattan College. Neath hopes to use his cumulative academic program and military experiences to create theater, film, and television with a political and social perspective.
Tyler La Marr - Co-Founder



Tyler served as a Sergeant in the Marine Corps from '04-'10 where he worked as an analyst. He served two tours in Iraq, from '06-'07 in Fallujah and '07-'08 in Fallujah & Ramadi, with 2nd Radio Battalion based out of Camp Lejeune, NC. Tyler was born in Washington State and spent most of his life there until he joined the Marines after high school. He began pursuing his acting career in 2009 while living in Baltimore, MD. Tyler is currently attending Marymount Manhattan College in NYC pursuing his BFA in Acting and will be graduating May '14. www.TylerLaMarr.com
Matthew Thomas Burda - Director of Theater Development







Matthew served 6 years in the Air Force Security Forces, and was stationed at Lakenheath Airbase, UK and Altus AFB, Oklahoma.  He deployed to Iraq and Afghanistan, where he earned two Army Achievement Medals. He spent his final 18 months on active duty working as a Combat Skills Instructor. MTB is now an actor living in Brooklyn.  He has been involved in a wide range of theatrical and film projects. Recent NYC stage performances include Moe Axelrod in Awake and Sing! (LCP) Cecil Graham in Lady Windemere’s Fan (EAS) and as the title lead in Anatol (City Show).
